headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Q4 2009 Ducommun Earnings Conference Call. My name is Sally, and I'll be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to your host for today, Mr. Chris Woo
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Q4 2009 Ducommun Earnings Conference Call. My name is Sally, and I'll be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to your host for today, Mr. Chris Woody [ph]. Please proceed.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and welcome to Ducommun's fourth quarter conference call. With me today is Tony Reardon, President and CEO; and Joe Bellino, Vice President and CFO. I would now like to provide a brief safe harbor statement. This conference call may include for
componenttext: Thank you, and welcome to Ducommun's fourth quarter conference call. With me today is Tony Reardon, President and CEO; and Joe Bellino, Vice President and CFO. I would now like to provide a brief safe harbor statement. This conference call may include forward-looking statements that represent the company's expectations and beliefs concerning future events that involve risks and uncertainties that may cause the company's actual performance to be materially different from the performance indicated or implied by such statements. All statements other than statements on historical fact, including this conference call, are forward-looking statements. Although the company believes that the expectations reflected in such forward-looking statements are reasonable, it can give no assurance that such expectations will prove to be have been correct. Important factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from the company's expectations are disclosed in this conference call and in the company's annual report and Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2009. All subsequent written and oral forward-looking statements attributable to the company or persons acting on its behalf are expressly qualified in their entirety by the cautionary statements. Unless otherwise required by law, the company undertakes no obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise after the date of this conference call. I'd now like to turn the call over to Ducommun's President and CEO, Tony Reardon for a review of the operating results. Tony?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chris [ph], and thank you, everyone for joining us today. I'd like to give you a brief overview, after which, I'll turn the call over to Joe Bellino for the financial review. Let me start off by saying that 2009 certainly was a year with it's f
componenttext: Thank you, Chris [ph], and thank you, everyone for joining us today. I'd like to give you a brief overview, after which, I'll turn the call over to Joe Bellino for the financial review. Let me start off by saying that 2009 certainly was a year with it's fair share of challenges. Ducommun, along with the rest of the aerospace and defense industry, faced a number of headwinds with regard to our end markets, and the company reacted by increasing our focus on both cost controls and new business development. We've talked a lot about our benefits of lean manufacturing in the past but it's clearly worked to our advantage this year, as we've been able to generate solid cash flow and stabilize margins, even as our topline revenue was impacted by near-term economic conditions. Ducommun Aerostructures had some major challenges this year with maintaining our margin performance. But at the same time, we can now boost side on the new program development efforts undertaken by this business. This new business development efforts included the RUAG Bombardier fuselage assembly production program, the engineering and design and development of wing movels [ph] for the Embraer new 450 and 550 series aircraft, and the co-development of the exhaust system with Pratt & Whitney on the UCAV's program. Another solid example of our continuous improvement efforts lies within our technology unit, DTI [Diffusion Tensor Imaging]. Our operating margins rose to 9.4% from 5.9% year-over-year on a 6% decline in revenue. We believe Ducommun is well-positioned as our market begins to rebound. I'd like to review a few trends that we see impacting Ducommun in the market as a whole going forward. We expect our Fixed Wing and Rotary Wing businesses to remain strong in 2010. While the Apache production has come down to more normalized pre-war levels, we see continued strong demand for the Blackhawk and Chinook helicopter programs. This is a reflection of the Afghan war which is more suited to their mission profiles. In addition, I've said before, the C17 remains funded into the mid-2011. As we look forward on the C-17, we see additional demand driven by higher foreign sales and lower U.S. sales, which have the potential to fund the lower production rate for the program into 2012 and 2013. The F/A-18 also continues to be a strong program for Ducommun, and we see further room for additional growth. On the commercial side, we are cautiously optimistic about the consistent demand for large fixed wing aircraft. Commercial aircraft is expected to grow to be somewhere between 2% and 4% depending on the model you use. But both Boeing and Airbus has strong backlogs. We expect the major programs, such as the Boeing 737 and the A320, to continue their current projected production rates end to the end of 2010. However, with only 400 aircraft ordered worldwide in 2009, the airline recovery is important to the future build rates and we'll monitor these trends as the year progresses. We have witnessed the airlines reducing their cash expenditures, particularly in their purchase of an inventory per spares, which impacted some of our DTI order base and our backlog in 2009. As they continue to deplete their spares inventory, we expect that there will be a need to replenish supply during the second half of 2010. This should lead to a potential uptick in our Spares business, which typically represents approximately 5% to 7% of our revenue, but has been running at a lower than normal levels. We're cautiously optimistic about the recovery of the regional jet market, but not until later this year and possibly running into 2011. We do not expect it to recover in 2010, but with some pickup later in the years and companies such as us Gulfstream. These markets have historically represented about 10% to 15% of our business, and we're keeping an eye on the end-user demand. As the global economy continues to recover, we believe demand will further stabilize and likely see improvement as we head into the next year. Joe Bellino is going to give you the financial overview, but let me briefly talk about the fourth quarter and the year. We were extremely disappointed in the goodwill impairment charge we took in the fourth quarter. The pretax non-cash charge was taken in the amount of $12.9 million, which equates to $0.74 per diluted share after tax. This charge was taken in recognition of the changing defense market demands on our Ducommun Miltec business. We took the impairment charge as a result of our reassessment of the unit's multi-year sales and cash flow forecast given recent government trends in the RDT&E budgeting, lower plus up in the year-mark spending and trends towards government in-sourcing. We do have a solid strategy to keep the business in this challenging market and to grow this business. We're optimistic that the unit focus is on new customer initiatives, we'll be able to navigate the coming quarters and improve Miltec's margins and long-term potential. For the fourth quarter, excluding the goodwill impairment charge, Ducommun grew net income to $4.6 million or $0.44 per diluted share, from $3.8 million or $0.36 per diluted share a year ago. For the quarter, our cash flow from operations was nearly $40 million and the yearly number was $31 million, reflecting sound working capital management. Even given the top operating environment and the number of one-time events that impacted operating income in the quarter and in the year, Ducommun achieved solid operating margins while generating consistent cash flow. Now I'd like to turn the phone call over to Joe Bellino for the financial review. Joe?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tony, and good morning, everyone. Our fourth quarter results, as Tony just discussed, where we reported results before our goodwill impairment charge during the quarter, posting net income of $0.44 per diluted share versus $0.36 per diluted sha
componenttext: Thank you, Tony, and good morning, everyone. Our fourth quarter results, as Tony just discussed, where we reported results before our goodwill impairment charge during the quarter, posting net income of $0.44 per diluted share versus $0.36 per diluted share a year ago before our goodwill impairment charge in 2008. Typically, our business is seasonal with the fourth quarter having a reduced number of operating days due to the holidays, and this causes unabsorbed overhead allocations impacting our operating margins. That typical scenario did certainly incurred in our fourth quarter year in 2009.I'd like to give you some more color on the quarter, in terms of talking first about sales. Our overall sales for the quarter of $106 million were 4% year-over-year, increased. We experienced a significant increase in sales within our Ducommun Aerostructure segment, DAS, where revenues rose 17% year-over-year, due largely to a nearly $9 million in sales from the late 2008 acquisition of DAS New York and from increases in both commercial and military fixed wing products. Somewhat offsetting this growth was softer sales in business and regional jets and general aviation commercial products, along with lower deliveries for the Apache helicopter program. In the technology segment, DTI, we experienced the 15% decline in sales, a portion of which reflected our cautious efforts to exit certain unprofitable lines later in 2008 was carried over into 2009 and lower regional jet and aftermarket product sales. The remaining decline was primarily attributable to lower services revenue from the Miltec unit that Tony commented upon and as a result of the reduced government funding in certain military markets. If you'd see on our P&L statement, our service revenues were $11 million in the quarter versus about $16 million a year ago, you'll see that we started to feel the impact of that in the fourth quarter, and we expect that kind of run rate to carry over into a good part of 2010.If you look at operating income by business segment, Ducommun's operating income for the quarter, we exclude the goodwill charges, it rose to $7.2 million or 6.8% of revenues from 3.9% of revenues a year ago. Last year's operating income also excludes the goodwill impairment charge. In Ducommun Aerostructures operating business segment, its operating income improved to $7.7 million or 11% of revenues, compared to $5.4 million or 9% of revenues a year ago. This is a result of higher sales and continued productivity gains from our lean manufacturing efforts, which more than offset the impact from the decline in Apache helicopter blade sales and lower demands from business and regional jets in general aviation products. Ducommun Technology, DTI's operating income despite lower sales that I commented upon earlier and excluding the aforementioned impairment charge, the operating income increased to $4.2 million versus $2.9 million a year ago as a result of improved product mix. We were pleased that the operating margins were 11.7% of sales, up nearly 500 basis points from the 6.9% posted in the fourth quarter of 2008.Selling, general and administrative expenses for the quarter. As we look at SG&A, it's a combination of business segment SG&A, which is part of the operating income as it recorded and unallocated corporate expenses. These overall SG&A expenses decreased significantly this quarter and it primarily reflects the corporate wide cost controls that we have had in place since the first part of 2009, along with reductions in environmental reserves that has been established in previous years. Somewhat offsetting these reductions, were additional expenses we incurred with the DAS New York acquisition, primarily related to amortization of intangibles. I'd like to comment a little further on the goodwill impairment charges that Tony discussed previously that involves our recording in the fourth quarter of $12.9 million non-cash goodwill impairment charge, which equates to $0.74 per diluted share. The effective tax rate for this charge was approximately 39%. You might recall in the fourth quarter of 2008, we recorded a pretax non-cash goodwill impairment charge of $13.1 million, which equated to about $0.76 per diluted share. Again, the effective tax rate was approximately 39%.As Tony noted, the 2009 impairment charge was related to external market factors and decreases in government funding related to the Miltec operation. This contrast, significantly from the 2008 impairment charge, which was driven by the weakness in the overall equity market. Having recorded these charges, going forward we are very confident in Miltec's future opportunities. If we turn to the full-year 2009 results, our net income, excluding goodwill, was $18 million or $1.71 per fully diluted share in fiscal 2009 and this compares to $21.1 million or $1.99 per share. Again, excluding the goodwill charge. Our full-year sales in 2009 increased 7% to $431 million from $404 million last year. The 2009 increase in revenue largely reflects sales tied to our acquisition of DAS New York. Ducommun Aerostructure sales increased to $286 million from $250 million, and DTI sales were down about 6% overall reflecting shortfalls in the regional jet and aftermarket sales and the elimination of the unprofitable lines this year, compared to a year ago.Looking at full-year operating income by business segment, Ducommun's operating income, excluding the goodwill impairment charge, was $29 million in 2009 compared to $31 million a year ago. Full-year 2009 results also included the impact of a $5.8 million expenses related to the Eclipse reserve, inventory valuations and sales tax reserves that we've commented upon in the press release as well as the 10-K. DAS' operating income was $29 million compared to $35 million a year ago. On a pro forma basis, if we backed out those inventory adjustments I just mentioned, the 2009 DAS operating income, as a percentage sales, would have been nearly 12% that does compare to nearly 14% of revenues in 2008. The reduction in Apache helicopter delivery business and regional jets and higher levels of unabsorbed operating costs were the primary factors impacting the decline in this adjusted DAS segment operating profitability.DTI's realized higher operating income in 2009, excluding the goodwill impairment charge, resulted in operating income rising to $13.5 million or 9.3% of revenues from $9 million or 5.9% of revenues. And this again, as the quarter was depicted earlier, was a result of improved product mix, elimination of unprofitable lines and improved operations. We are pleased to see the sustainability of higher operating margins in the DTI segment, reflecting a successful execution of our strategies in 2009. Overall selling, general and administrative expenses as I defined earlier, those for the full year, were slightly lower year over year as a result of the aforementioned cost controls, reduction in the environmental reserves, and these were partially offset by the year-over-year higher amortization expenses related to our acquisition. As a key measure that we monitor closely, SG&A as a percentage of sales, was 11.5% down 100 basis points from the 2008 numbers.Turning to our backlog in our business mix. In the current economic environment, we have seen our business mix continued to shift to a greater increase in military sales. And for the year, our business was comprised of 62% military, 36% commercial and 2% space. At year end 2009, our backlog stood at $367 million. We have had no major program losses, some delay but have experienced delays in follow-on orders for a number of programs, including the F-18, Apache, Blackhawk, 737 and regional jets. We expect that follow-on orders and new program wins that Tony spoke about will favorably impact our backlog levels going forward. Finally, in terms of liquidity and capital resources, we generated strong positive cash flow from operations improved for the full year, cash from operations was $31 million, which is about equal to or five-year average of $30 million per year since 2005. We finished the year with very effective working capital management, which along with our normalized earnings, was a large contributor to our strong cash generation. We are managing our working capital levels very aggressively in this softer markets. Along with the new credit facility that we put in place last June of 2009, we continue to maintain a low leverage position at year end, our net debt to capital ratio was just 4%. We feel that given the current economic environment and uncertainty in the credit markets, this is an excellent position for us to be in. We expect CapEx for fiscal 2010 to be in the $11 million range, that compares to slightly less than $8 million for 2009, and most of that increase in investment is into new business development programs. Before turning the call back over to Tony, I would just like to comment that as we enter 2010, we believe our strong financial position and credit profile will allow us to take advantage of several market opportunities positioning the company for future growth and improved operating performance. Now I'd like to ask Tony Reardon to make some additional remarks. Tony?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Joe. Before turning the call over to questions, let me just summarize a few things. We see 2010 as one of correction, with overall market improvement coming in the second half of the year. Most importantly, as we continue to generate strong cas
componenttext: Thank you, Joe. Before turning the call over to questions, let me just summarize a few things. We see 2010 as one of correction, with overall market improvement coming in the second half of the year. Most importantly, as we continue to generate strong cash flow and expand our margins, we are positioning the company for even stronger performance in 2011, which should benefit from some late improvement in the regional jet market, growth in after market demand and the success of such programs as the 787. We are very optimistic about the outlook of the Boeing 787, believing that another redesign it looks like less likely, and the timing of deliveries is becoming more certain. If the FAA gives certification in September, as anticipated, this program should be a solid contributor to our growth, going into 2011. That's why while we are currently facing some headwinds with the Apache and the C-17 in particular, we believe our aggressive effort to cut costs, improved productivity and win new contract awards will result in solid growth as the global economy moves forward. Sally,  I think now we could turn it over for some questions, please?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Troy Lahr with Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Troy Lahr with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering if you could just elaborate a little more on the margins and technologies, how much of this is kind of sustainable? And maybe could you give us a little understanding of this mix shift, is this just some near-term mix shift issues or if this
componenttext: I'm wondering if you could just elaborate a little more on the margins and technologies, how much of this is kind of sustainable? And maybe could you give us a little understanding of this mix shift, is this just some near-term mix shift issues or if this is go back to you, consciously trying to kind of move away from some of those lower floor margin programs?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, this is Tony. I think a couple of issues, first of all, the margins are sustainable. And some of the mix issues are subject to the changes that we made with regards to exiting some of the lower margin business. But in addition, we've got some new
componenttext: I think, this is Tony. I think a couple of issues, first of all, the margins are sustainable. And some of the mix issues are subject to the changes that we made with regards to exiting some of the lower margin business. But in addition, we've got some new business growth there. We also have some new development going on there that we see will, from a spare standpoint, should put us in the position to be more competitive in that marketplace. So we've seen a little bit of that in 2009. We anticipate that there'll be some more growth in that side of business in 2010. So as we look forward, we think that from a margin standpoint, we believe we can sustain that margins and improve the margins that we have in place.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I guess, just digging deeper into that, how all of a sudden -- I mean you guys had been running that 8.5% margins almost all year, how did the mix shift issue just occur in one quarter and it ramps about that materially? And so just so I'm clear, this
componenttext: And I guess, just digging deeper into that, how all of a sudden -- I mean you guys had been running that 8.5% margins almost all year, how did the mix shift issue just occur in one quarter and it ramps about that materially? And so just so I'm clear, this is a -- because we should sound now think of Ducommun Technology segment as a 11%, 12% type margin business?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Troy, when Tony talked about mix shift, we did experience that. When we look at the overall sales in the fourth quarter of the technology segment of a little over $35 million, that was comprised of $24 million of our Technologies Manufactured product segm
componenttext: Troy, when Tony talked about mix shift, we did experience that. When we look at the overall sales in the fourth quarter of the technology segment of a little over $35 million, that was comprised of $24 million of our Technologies Manufactured product segment and $11 million of the Service Revenue segment, which you can pull the service revenues off of our consolidated P&L. That compares to about $35 million a quarter before, but in the quarter before, certainly the service revenues were in the $16 million range. Broad stroke, we had $5 million worth of manufactured product sales and we had $5 million less of service revenues, which the service revenues, like most government businesses are lower operating margin part of the business. So that was a favorable mix. And I commented that we're running at the rate of $11 million to $12 million a quarter and the service revenues going forward here -- what we see the first half at least of 2010, but we still see sustainability with the manufactured products. And in addition to operating improvements that we've made and we've reposition the portfolio, our orders for products on the F-18 and other ones aftermarket products look very good here in the near term, and most of those are replacement for military products. So we do believe that, that number of -- the 11.8% is certainly a more realistic number than the mid-eights that we experienced in the first half of '09.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: And did I read in your K rate that your amortization expense is going up by about $1 million next year?
componenttext: And did I read in your K rate that your amortization expense is going up by about $1 million next year?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Our amortization expense really kicked in, in the second half of 2009. It's up, yes. Once we watched through the DAS acquisition purchase accounting, we flushed through it, we stepped up in basis of inventory in the first half, and then after we depl
componenttext: Yes. Our amortization expense really kicked in, in the second half of 2009. It's up, yes. Once we watched through the DAS acquisition purchase accounting, we flushed through it, we stepped up in basis of inventory in the first half, and then after we depleted that, then we started amortizing the goodwill and we've scheduled that in the footnotes.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Why the delay in the orders that you mentioned like Blackhawk and some other programs and do you think that, that comes through kind of next quarter or I mean, the current quarter that we're in?
componenttext: Why the delay in the orders that you mentioned like Blackhawk and some other programs and do you think that, that comes through kind of next quarter or I mean, the current quarter that we're in?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: It looks to be spread out, Troy. A couple of things. One is as we look at each one of the programs, it depends on where they sit. The Blackhawk program, we would anticipate probably in the second quarter more than the first quarter, the way the request fo
componenttext: It looks to be spread out, Troy. A couple of things. One is as we look at each one of the programs, it depends on where they sit. The Blackhawk program, we would anticipate probably in the second quarter more than the first quarter, the way the request for quote is being managed. And then with regards to the Apache program, what's happening there is that that'll probably be the second quarter also. I believe we're scheduled to finalize our package there with them in April. And then as you look at the 737, they've actually changed their model in terms of order releases. So what we see in the 737 now is releases quarter-over-quarter. So you'll see, as opposed to seeing a one-time large order that we've had in the past, unlike we did at the end of 2008, we're seeing quarterly releases to pick up the annual buys. So we'll get a release at the end of the first quarter to cover the second quarter of 2011. So those will be pushed out a little bit. We should pick up hopefully the F-18 follow on order this quarter. So I'm going to say probably half the orders will come in, in this quarter, and then the other half will be in the second quarter.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Lewis with BB&T Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Lewis with BB&T Capital Markets.

componenttext: Joe, just a follow-up on Troy's question. On the backlog, would you anticipate to have a full year book-to-bill in excess of one times when we exit out 2010?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then, if I can just kind of dig in a little bit more on the Miltec issue, in the impairment. If we look back to 2006, I think you paid about $48 million for the property. At that time, the company, Miltec, had I believe around $43 million in revenue.
componenttext: And then, if I can just kind of dig in a little bit more on the Miltec issue, in the impairment. If we look back to 2006, I think you paid about $48 million for the property. At that time, the company, Miltec, had I believe around $43 million in revenue. Over the past two years, we've seen about $20 million write-down on this asset and you have reevaluated the long-term plan that you have outlined for this company. Can you talk to us a little bit about what that plan looks like? What the expectation is, with regard to specific topline growth over the next two to three years? Is this is a 3% to 5% grower or 5% to 7% grower? Can you help us understand what the revision look like and help us quantify this a little bit better?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, Mike, Let me start off by saying that as you look at the analysis of the goodwill impairment, it's certainly based off your long-range plans. So in 2008, we had specific programs that actually some were canceled and some were defunded, if you will,
componenttext: Sure, Mike, Let me start off by saying that as you look at the analysis of the goodwill impairment, it's certainly based off your long-range plans. So in 2008, we had specific programs that actually some were canceled and some were defunded, if you will, they stopped funding. And so what happened to us in terms of the forecast going forward was that we had a pretty good adjustment for 2010. So the base actually dropped in 2010 from the 2009 original forecast and we executed a growth strategy that puts us at about somewhere between 5% and 8% per year, year-over-year going forward. But that was lower than the previous anticipated forecast in terms of the out year, the terminal year and that's what actually drives the goodwill analysis, not only the revenue forecast but of course the cash flow, the resulting cash flows from that. So the analysis has taken from the terminal year and in perpetuity. So as we look at that, we forecast together, based on our realistic projection of what 2010 would look like and then the forecasted growth rate has some particular targeted programs, a little shift in our engineering development technology base, and then we look at about 5% to 8% going forward.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then, just with regard to the margin expectation, because we have seen some of these lower margin services work exit out, this is what's having this beneficial impact to the margin profile in DTI and again, I want to just clarify that, you do anticipa
componenttext: And then, just with regard to the margin expectation, because we have seen some of these lower margin services work exit out, this is what's having this beneficial impact to the margin profile in DTI and again, I want to just clarify that, you do anticipate a north of 11% margin as the sustainable level, can you just reiterate that for us?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Mike, when we'd look at the -- if you would go back and review the trends for the technology segment in the first three quarters, it was actually very steady at about 8.5% of sales and that compares, it compares to about 5.5% of sales in the first th
componenttext: Yes. Mike, when we'd look at the -- if you would go back and review the trends for the technology segment in the first three quarters, it was actually very steady at about 8.5% of sales and that compares, it compares to about 5.5% of sales in the first three quarters of '08 reflecting those really strategic changes to the portfolio that I talked about. In terms of -- we do get quarterly variations depending on the orders and deliveries in these pools by our customers. I would look at it as a longer-term view. For the full year, we certainly would expect to be in that 11% range although recognizing that seasonality and cyclicality within quarters may not make it a flat line 11% each quarter.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Two more quick questions for you. With regard to tax expectations, what should we be modeling in 2010 and also, with regard to the CapEx of $11 million in 2010, will this be the last big year for additional investment and can we expect to see this rate le
componenttext: Two more quick questions for you. With regard to tax expectations, what should we be modeling in 2010 and also, with regard to the CapEx of $11 million in 2010, will this be the last big year for additional investment and can we expect to see this rate less than in 2011 from 2010?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: The question on the tax rate, if you're modeling it I would probably use 31% for the full year but we internally are modeling at 33% each quarter including the first quarter until the federal R&D tax credits were approved by Congress. I read something jus
componenttext: The question on the tax rate, if you're modeling it I would probably use 31% for the full year but we internally are modeling at 33% each quarter including the first quarter until the federal R&D tax credits were approved by Congress. I read something just last Friday were Senator Reid is working on the smaller jobs bill and they're going to address that first and get through that legislation and the next priority is the R&D. So I can't tell exactly when that will be approved. It goes back to the Reagan days as you know, so it could be the first quarter, it could be the second quarter. But in terms of our own accounting properly, we will record the 33% and not reflect the benefit of that until that legislation is passed and then,  but the full year will be 31%. Your question on the CapEx, a lot of it is driven by new program development. As you might know, our depreciation and amortization is probably about $11 million to $12 million so we've been very modest with our CapEx and we can grow our base without having to have substantial increases in investments and capacity but most of our CapEx of above a minimum level of maintenance within our whole operations, which is really relatively small is for growth-oriented programs and business development. Your question about in the future, well we don't see it going to a quantum leap if we stay in this general range of businesses, we do see it probably in this $10 million to $12 million range.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would say, Mike, let me just give you a little color. The jump this year into 2010 is directed at a particular investment that we're making into a market and as we look at that market and we're successful in some of our prototype developments, we antici
componenttext: I would say, Mike, let me just give you a little color. The jump this year into 2010 is directed at a particular investment that we're making into a market and as we look at that market and we're successful in some of our prototype developments, we anticipated that to fully be able to take advantage of the marketplace we put the capital equipment in place to do that. As we go forward, there's some new programs that we're looking at but we would anticipate that capital to be in the $9 million to $10 million to $11 million range assuming that we're successful going forward, we always tried to take capital or creativity before capital so it's the last thing that we look at. But as we look at the business and run through the advantages that we have on the new business side, there are opportunities and we'll take advantage of them.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Edward Marshall with Sidoti & Company.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: The follow-up on the previous question on CapEx. You said you're expanding into a new market, is that a market that you already have business for? Or recently have won business for? Or is this something that you're building out capacity that kind of fit?
componenttext: The follow-up on the previous question on CapEx. You said you're expanding into a new market, is that a market that you already have business for? Or recently have won business for? Or is this something that you're building out capacity that kind of fit?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: We have business in that marketplace and what we're doing is we're enhancing our capability to grow that.
componenttext: We have business in that marketplace and what we're doing is we're enhancing our capability to grow that.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Could I ask if it's similar to titanium?
componenttext: Could I ask if it's similar to titanium?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010

componenttext: Yes.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question, you'd kind of highlighted the headwinds that you face rolling into 2010 especially with the Apache programs and other programs coming down as a percent of sales, but can you discuss, I think you've touched on it but reiterate what you s
componenttext: The next question, you'd kind of highlighted the headwinds that you face rolling into 2010 especially with the Apache programs and other programs coming down as a percent of sales, but can you discuss, I think you've touched on it but reiterate what you see, first half to second half, is second-half improving and first half and then pitfalls that may happen on that as we move into the remainder of this year?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: We do see the second half stronger as we go forward. A couple of the pitfalls that we have in front of us are the recovery of the Spares business. We're looking forward to that. That impacted us, actually in the fourth quarter last year and coming into th
componenttext: We do see the second half stronger as we go forward. A couple of the pitfalls that we have in front of us are the recovery of the Spares business. We're looking forward to that. That impacted us, actually in the fourth quarter last year and coming into the first quarter and also, the Miltec, the drop in their revenue base is something that we'll have forecasted forward so we think, we're relatively solid there. I don't see any major, anything that we have in front of us right now other than the things that we mentioned with regards to possible C-17 slowdown. We don't, we're looking at that and then the 737 market is the possibility of -- if the order base doesn't come in. Right now, we're not anticipating either one of those things in our plan but those are opportunities for us to be creative.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then I guess on the pipeline, you've booked quite a bit of new business recently. A lot of new worked. Specially at the top of the year. Is that it? Or should we kind of expect this trend to continue obviously, we hope it continues but realistically,
componenttext: And then I guess on the pipeline, you've booked quite a bit of new business recently. A lot of new worked. Specially at the top of the year. Is that it? Or should we kind of expect this trend to continue obviously, we hope it continues but realistically, will it continue throughout the remainder of 2010 and into 2011?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: So let me talk, first of all, we do have some unannounced orders that we have in the queue right now that we're waiting for approval from the customer to announce. So we do have some business that we've been awarded. We also have a number of RFQs, open qu
componenttext: So let me talk, first of all, we do have some unannounced orders that we have in the queue right now that we're waiting for approval from the customer to announce. So we do have some business that we've been awarded. We also have a number of RFQs, open quotes that we've been down selected on major applications across-the-board. So I would anticipate that we will see some other rewards this year that would be significant. So we have a couple of packages that we're very close on right now and we're working on the programs that are the usual suspects we have RFQs that we're working on the 787, and JSF, the A350, we have an A321 program that we're working on, so we have a number of applications that we're working across the board on the commercial as well as some of the military aircraft.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then following up to that, I guess is it associated with the RFQs, the major applications, the unannounced orders that you talked about, is it related to the core base of business that Ducommun has? Or is it through the acquisition that you made last
componenttext: And then following up to that, I guess is it associated with the RFQs, the major applications, the unannounced orders that you talked about, is it related to the core base of business that Ducommun has? Or is it through the acquisition that you made last year of now DAS New York?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Most of it is through the core, but some of it is affiliated with the acquisition because we're utilizing the one Ducommun philosophy so we have two business units that we've combined at the end of the year that are operating. New York has been combined w
componenttext: Most of it is through the core, but some of it is affiliated with the acquisition because we're utilizing the one Ducommun philosophy so we have two business units that we've combined at the end of the year that are operating. New York has been combined with our Parson's facility from a management standpoint and we've actually sharing some work right now. The V-22 program that we just announced, part of the materials are being manufactured at in our Parsons facility and has been completed in the assembly at our New York facility. Some will come out of the New York but there's growth on both sides.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then you talked about, you just touched on the assembly piece which is part of my next question. As you move in more into the assembly role, I understand that's going to bring a little bit more pricing power and probably a little bit higher margin. Un
componenttext: And then you talked about, you just touched on the assembly piece which is part of my next question. As you move in more into the assembly role, I understand that's going to bring a little bit more pricing power and probably a little bit higher margin. Understanding the role of an Apache and that brings as we roll into 2010 and then into 2011, when do you start to see the double-digit margins that we've talked about as a business as a whole kind of develop? I mean, is this something that could hit in 2011 or is it more like a 2012 event?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: The issue that we have is we're still in development on a couple of programs going into '10 and into '11, Embraer in particular. The RUAG program were coming down the learning curve and we're actually performing pretty well in that program so that's movin
componenttext: The issue that we have is we're still in development on a couple of programs going into '10 and into '11, Embraer in particular. The RUAG program were coming down the learning curve and we're actually performing pretty well in that program so that's moving forward. In terms of moving into the double digits, we certainly would like to have that in 2011 but I would anticipate that our goal is to get there before 2012.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: And to add to that further, through the first three quarters of 2008, we were averaging nearly 9.5% and we had said our goal longer term is to get on a sustainable basis above 10%. We think most likely, when the next commercial cycle expands, it'll be coi
componenttext: And to add to that further, through the first three quarters of 2008, we were averaging nearly 9.5% and we had said our goal longer term is to get on a sustainable basis above 10%. We think most likely, when the next commercial cycle expands, it'll be coincident with the increase in builds of the 787 and that could be either latter part of 2011 or 2012. We think that's the best opportunities for us to expand our overall operating margins. Until that time, it'll be somewhat of a challenge for us as Tony noted.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: And on the 787, have you defined your exposure there? And if not, if you have, can you add some additional color, probably reiterate the -- how you see that program ramping up for you?
componenttext: And on the 787, have you defined your exposure there? And if not, if you have, can you add some additional color, probably reiterate the -- how you see that program ramping up for you?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think as we indicated before, we've actually delivered about 30 shipsets on average on the equipment that we're on right now. And so we would anticipate that some of that will be ramping down. We don't actually have a high volume of revenue antici
componenttext: Well, I think as we indicated before, we've actually delivered about 30 shipsets on average on the equipment that we're on right now. And so we would anticipate that some of that will be ramping down. We don't actually have a high volume of revenue anticipated on the 787 for 2010, but we do ramp up in 2011. So we would expect to see possibly in the fourth quarter some pick up on the 787. We actually have the varying applications that we have, we're actually doing some work right now, we've realigned our engine requirements and we're working on some of the sell work right now that we hadn't anticipated for Rolls-Royce engines versus the GE engine so there's some work that's coming out right now, but I would anticipate that we'll get into steady rate production in 2011 and then pretty solid ramp up in 2012.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is a follow-up from a Troy Lahr with Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: Your next question is a follow-up from a Troy Lahr with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: For Technologies, you kind of pointed out that you'd like to be in the 11% range, how should we think about Aerostructures next year? Is this 12% margin or is that what we should expect?
componenttext: For Technologies, you kind of pointed out that you'd like to be in the 11% range, how should we think about Aerostructures next year? Is this 12% margin or is that what we should expect?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: In my prepared remarks, I talked about when we sort out some of the noise, 12% put a context on it that it wasn't too long going '08 where our margins for the Aerostructure business were fairly sustainable in the 14% to 15% range. But certainly, the impac
componenttext: In my prepared remarks, I talked about when we sort out some of the noise, 12% put a context on it that it wasn't too long going '08 where our margins for the Aerostructure business were fairly sustainable in the 14% to 15% range. But certainly, the impact of Apache and the overhang of potential reduced builds for the C-17 effects that so while we have goals, the 12% probably is not a bad range, 11.5% to 13% depending on the quarter and the cyclicality, those are the kind of things we target recognizing again until the commercial build come out substantially, which gives us an opportunity to increase our incremental margins. We'll be living in that range for the foreseeable future.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I know you generally don't give guidance. But on the sales line, could you maybe just see directionally, how you think that, that's flowing? Are you just trying to keep sales flat? Do you think you might give up a little bit sales? Sales might decline
componenttext: And I know you generally don't give guidance. But on the sales line, could you maybe just see directionally, how you think that, that's flowing? Are you just trying to keep sales flat? Do you think you might give up a little bit sales? Sales might decline in 2010 for the full year?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, it's important when you model sales, Troy, as I talked about it, if you go to our consolidated income, our product sales, I think that's one model you would build into service revenues and other and the service revenue as we said, the $11 million to
componenttext: Well, it's important when you model sales, Troy, as I talked about it, if you go to our consolidated income, our product sales, I think that's one model you would build into service revenues and other and the service revenue as we said, the $11 million to $12 million in the fourth quarter of 2009, we look at that as that kind of run rate going forward here in 2010. But your product revenue sales, I think, I just suggest and Tony will add to this, but I suggest that you go back and review the comments that we talked about, the outlook for these markets and build your models from our commentary.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me just give you a little color, Troy, so that I'll help you take a look at it. As we look into 2010, as Joe indicated, there's some headwinds on the service side of the business, we've adjusted and talked to that. But in terms of the product business
componenttext: Let me just give you a little color, Troy, so that I'll help you take a look at it. As we look into 2010, as Joe indicated, there's some headwinds on the service side of the business, we've adjusted and talked to that. But in terms of the product business going forward, the things that we look at is from the market place standpoint, we talked about the Apache program, coming down a little bit more so there's a steady state there that would be going forward, but as you look at some of the other programs adding on the horizon, pretty much they stay from a production standpoint on a steady rise. We did see a dip, what we're looking out in the regional jet side as you look at the programs, it's pretty steady state from the third and fourth quarter. I wouldn't back up to the last first two quarters of 2009 because they were at higher rates than we anticipate going forward so the market place and then we had a couple of major one-time sales like the UCAS program in 2009, which will not repeat itself and we anticipate that program to start again about late 2010 or mid-2011 depending on how the testing goes in that program. So those are things that we look at from a standpoint of going forward, but as you look at the conversation that we had about the marketplace, and you understand that the regional jet business typically was about 10% to 15% of our base, that should give you a good picture of what the revenue should look like.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: But the drill down on the programs, is Blackhawk ramping up? Or is that kind of a steady $9 million to $10 million a quarter?
componenttext: But the drill down on the programs, is Blackhawk ramping up? Or is that kind of a steady $9 million to $10 million a quarter?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: They're trying to ramp up whether or not, they have the ability to do that, yes, you've seen, but right now, I would anticipate that it's in our web forecast, it's pretty flat.
componenttext: They're trying to ramp up whether or not, they have the ability to do that, yes, you've seen, but right now, I would anticipate that it's in our web forecast, it's pretty flat.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then also Chinook? I mean, I guess I'm trying to figure out if you look at the DOD budget that came out, a lot of focus Secretary Gates is talking about, the importance of helicopters and then those budgets were actually up nicely, but then you're say
componenttext: And then also Chinook? I mean, I guess I'm trying to figure out if you look at the DOD budget that came out, a lot of focus Secretary Gates is talking about, the importance of helicopters and then those budgets were actually up nicely, but then you're saying these programs are actually going to be flat not growing?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Here's the problem, Troy. And that is, it's not -- it's a function of how well Sikorsky and Boeing can ramp up. So the issue becomes their ramp-up capability whether or not we think that the program's going to grow. Clearly on the Chinook, if they can ram
componenttext: Here's the problem, Troy. And that is, it's not -- it's a function of how well Sikorsky and Boeing can ramp up. So the issue becomes their ramp-up capability whether or not we think that the program's going to grow. Clearly on the Chinook, if they can ramp up their schedule and improve then we would see higher revenues same thing with the Blackhawk. It's solely dependent on how well Sikorsky can ramp up and hit the production range.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then, what are you hearing from the business check customers? Do you think that there's still some production cuts left out there? Or do you think that they feel a little more comfortable?
componenttext: And then, what are you hearing from the business check customers? Do you think that there's still some production cuts left out there? Or do you think that they feel a little more comfortable?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would say that it stabilized somewhat. There could be production cuts coming, but it all depends on the airline industry. And what we're seeing from them they've certainly hoarding our cash and they're putting themselves in a position from a capitalizat
componenttext: I would say that it stabilized somewhat. There could be production cuts coming, but it all depends on the airline industry. And what we're seeing from them they've certainly hoarding our cash and they're putting themselves in a position from a capitalization standpoint and if they're profitable and they need those aircraft, they're going to move out. But right now, I would say it's relatively stable. You have to remember that they carried a lot of inventories so that we believe in some inventory down so we may see some fluctuation in the revenue base from that standpoint, on the production side, but we think they're at a rate where they probably maintain, that's what I would guess.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then lastly, again on the Apache, I think you did about $7 million this quarter. Is that, that the low point here or do you think that the quarterly run rate continues to decline below that?
componenttext: And then lastly, again on the Apache, I think you did about $7 million this quarter. Is that, that the low point here or do you think that the quarterly run rate continues to decline below that?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: We did. We actually did $8.6 million of sales on the Apache in the fourth quarter and almost $30 million for the year. We believe that, that number will be probably $6.5 million to $7 million a quarter going forward. They're at reduced levels even slightl
componenttext: We did. We actually did $8.6 million of sales on the Apache in the fourth quarter and almost $30 million for the year. We believe that, that number will be probably $6.5 million to $7 million a quarter going forward. They're at reduced levels even slightly lower than the pre-Iraq war levels on the main rotor blade. However, there is good content on the detail of rotor blades and some other parts just because the blades, the main rotors came down from a peak of 50 that we had for about three or four years to the 25 level by the end of the fourth quarter and then we see some further reductions, if not a proportionate drop.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of David Cohen with Midwood.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of David Cohen with Midwood.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a wanted to ask a housekeeping question in terms of the different, nonrecurring charges occurred that you have realized during the year. Obviously the goodwill impairment which you had this quarter, but can you identify other nonrecurring items that
componenttext: Just a wanted to ask a housekeeping question in terms of the different, nonrecurring charges occurred that you have realized during the year. Obviously the goodwill impairment which you had this quarter, but can you identify other nonrecurring items that you've recorded throughout the year? Because I'm kind of over the numbers that actually somewhat equated than you've alluded to in the press release?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: I commented upon it and we put it in our release indicated, the total amount of inventory adjustments came to $5.8 million, that was a combination of three things. One is the Eclipse charge we wrote off the inventories there in our first quarter and that
componenttext: I commented upon it and we put it in our release indicated, the total amount of inventory adjustments came to $5.8 million, that was a combination of three things. One is the Eclipse charge we wrote off the inventories there in our first quarter and that was $4.3 million. Second quarter, we had about an $800,000 inventory valuation adjustment at one of our operations and then here in the fourth quarter, we changed our accounting treatment on tooling and we've actually put that onto our balance sheet to show the investment community, the investments that we're making in more complex assembly for customers on the balance sheet, we call that production cost of contracts, generically, it's tooling investment. But on that in the quarter, it triggered a sales tax reserve of about $700,000 I believe so that's comes up to the $5.8 million. There are a couple of other things that we noted. When we flushed through the inventory from the DAS New York acquisition through the first half of the year, which I mentioned earlier, that amount was about $1.5 million. We had also -- the schedule, we had increases in amortization of expenses. On the other side, we had lower, I think you'll have to dig for, we had lower accrued compensation because of lower operating performance this year versus last year and we also had a change in our environmental reserves of $2.2 million from previous reserves in the quarter. So you have a bunch of pluses and minuses but those are the major ones, I think some of that information is detailed in the K more extensively to confirm.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: On a go forward basis, I'm also looking at your DNA and excluding the amortization of intangibles and that number stepped up from 8.8% to 10.7% and then in your footnotes, you highlight that the depreciation of fixed assets was 8.7% so what's the addition
componenttext: On a go forward basis, I'm also looking at your DNA and excluding the amortization of intangibles and that number stepped up from 8.8% to 10.7% and then in your footnotes, you highlight that the depreciation of fixed assets was 8.7% so what's the additional $2 million of depreciation I guess in the 10.7%.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, on our statement of cash flows, we have two things, we have the DNA and then we have the amortization of intangible assets, which is related to New York and other ones like our Miltec business. But in the DNA, it's not only traditional depreciation
componenttext: Well, on our statement of cash flows, we have two things, we have the DNA and then we have the amortization of intangible assets, which is related to New York and other ones like our Miltec business. But in the DNA, it's not only traditional depreciation for fixed assets but it's amortization of some of that tooling that's embedded in there.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: That should not included that in the fixed assets? Where is that...
componenttext: That should not included that in the fixed assets? Where is that...

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, in looking at the balance sheet, the tooling is synonymous with production cost of contract, it's $12.8 million on the book. When we look at cash flow year-to-year, our additional investment in tooling less the amortization of customer tooling based o
componenttext: No, in looking at the balance sheet, the tooling is synonymous with production cost of contract, it's $12.8 million on the book. When we look at cash flow year-to-year, our additional investment in tooling less the amortization of customer tooling based on deliveries of shipsets then it comes up with a residual amount.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Lewis with BB&T Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Lewis with BB&T Capital Markets.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: If I look at RUAG, this was a revenue item that was probably less than 1% total sales. If you look at 2010 and 2011, it starts to approach a little bit less than 5% of total revenue, is that a correct assumption to make on our part? That type of ramp?
componenttext: If I look at RUAG, this was a revenue item that was probably less than 1% total sales. If you look at 2010 and 2011, it starts to approach a little bit less than 5% of total revenue, is that a correct assumption to make on our part? That type of ramp?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Have you disclosed exactly what you think the -- what the RUAG will look like in 2010?
componenttext: Have you disclosed exactly what you think the -- what the RUAG will look like in 2010?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think so.
componenttext: No, I don't think so.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can I take a shot, is it around $15 million of contribution?
componenttext: Can I take a shot, is it around $15 million of contribution?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our baseline is we ship. We have some shipments in the fourth quarter, our total shipment of RUAG were 2 million last year.
componenttext: Our baseline is we ship. We have some shipments in the fourth quarter, our total shipment of RUAG were 2 million last year.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Here's what I think it's going to happen in the program. We have a ramp up that we have to hit and so you'll see some higher revenue in the first half of the year and then that'll flatten out a little bit in the last two quarters as we get to raise so we
componenttext: Here's what I think it's going to happen in the program. We have a ramp up that we have to hit and so you'll see some higher revenue in the first half of the year and then that'll flatten out a little bit in the last two quarters as we get to raise so we have some catch up to do, we picked the program up from the another supplier and so we're working at a higher rate right now than would be level loaded for the -- it goes on the Bombardier 700 and 900 it's a common fuselage, so you can check those rates out and that's pretty much what we would look at from our range standpoint, but we anticipate that would be a little lower than the $15 million.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: But the sustainable level of that spend, looking further out in the contract term, would be appropriate to the 2010 level?
componenttext: But the sustainable level of that spend, looking further out in the contract term, would be appropriate to the 2010 level?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would think so, yes. Depending on the rate of the aircraft, right?
componenttext: I would think so, yes. Depending on the rate of the aircraft, right?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, of course, of course and we'll check that but just for general purposes on figuring out, the different components of the revenue '10, one more question for you, Joe, I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about the free cash flow expectation.
componenttext: Yes, of course, of course and we'll check that but just for general purposes on figuring out, the different components of the revenue '10, one more question for you, Joe, I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about the free cash flow expectation. We're seeing some increase, well, sustainable level of the CapEx that are say $11 million per year. However, you made a comment earlier talking about operating cash flow should be sustainable around $30 million, I would expect that we would see an incremental up where it move in free cash flow generation as you invest more? Am I looking at this correctly? Should we expect to see free cash flow improve sequentially on a year-over-year basis?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, when we define, let's make sure we have same definition, free cash flow would be the cash flow from operations less CapEx less dividends. Correct? And yes, we pay about the current rate of $0.075 a quarter, it's $3 million we said $11 million so you
componenttext: Well, when we define, let's make sure we have same definition, free cash flow would be the cash flow from operations less CapEx less dividends. Correct? And yes, we pay about the current rate of $0.075 a quarter, it's $3 million we said $11 million so you have $14 million you need to subtract from our net cash from operations. There's two factors in addition to net income that impair tax cash flow from operations. It's our effective working capital management and software cycles, we'll pair our inventories and we'll have lower levels of receivable and convert to previous year's to cash so, that's certainly good but when we expand our business as we saw in '06 and '07, those are working capital users. So your model, you'd play with that depending on what your expectations to where our sales are going and where our business is going. The other component has to do with primarily on our technology side, Michael, is when we receive we call milestone payments, customer deposits in advance of doing work and in '08, we received about $15 million of those in the fourth quarter and in '09, we received about $7 million of those in the fourth quarter. It just depends on our ability to obtain those and that's a function of backlogs in getting purchase orders to do that kind of work. It's primarily the replacement rate or a type of business. So that's really the big swing.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: There are no more  questions in queue at this time, Mr. Reardon.
componenttext: There are no more  questions in queue at this time, Mr. Reardon.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you, Sally. I would just like to close. I wanted to say that Ducommun looks forward to announcing new additional business wins in 2010 and we see strengthening of our business heading into 2011. We'll continue to effectively manage our working
componenttext: Okay, thank you, Sally. I would just like to close. I wanted to say that Ducommun looks forward to announcing new additional business wins in 2010 and we see strengthening of our business heading into 2011. We'll continue to effectively manage our working capital and believe that the company is in excellent financial shape with just 4% net debt to capital, to position us for continued growth as the global economy improves. Our goals this year are fourfold: Drive margin improvement; continue to penetrate new programs; generate strong levels of cash and look for some great acquisitions that will enhance our product portfolio going forward. I'd like to thank each and everyone of you for joining the call today. Thank you, Sally.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2010
