headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Ducommun First Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Maria and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the presentation over to Mr. Chris Witty,
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Ducommun First Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Maria and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the presentation over to Mr. Chris Witty, Investor Relations. Please proceed.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and welcome to Ducommun's First Quarter Conference Call. With me today is Tony Reardon, President and CEO; and Joe Bellino, Vice President and CFO. I would now like to provide a brief Safe Harbor statement. This conference call may include fo
componenttext:
Thank you, and welcome to Ducommun's First Quarter Conference Call. With me today is Tony Reardon, President and CEO; and Joe Bellino, Vice President and CFO. 
I would now like to provide a brief Safe Harbor statement. This conference call may include forward-looking statements that represent the company's expectations and beliefs concerning future events that involve risks and uncertainties, and may cause the company's actual performance to be materially different from the performance indicated or implied by such statements.
All statements other than statements of historical facts included in this conference call are forward-looking statements. Although the company believes that the expectations reflected in such forward-looking statements are reasonable, it can give no assurance that such expectations will prove to be have been correct. Important factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from the company's expectations are enclosed in this conference call and in the company's annual report and Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2009.
All subsequent written and oral forward-looking statements attributable to the company or persons acting on its behalf are expressly qualified in their entirety by the cautionary statements. Unless otherwise required by law, the company undertakes no obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statement, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise after the day of this conference call. 
I'd now like turn it over to Ducommun's President and CEO, Tony Reardon for a review of the operating results. Tony?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chris, and good morning everybody. And thank you for joining us today. I'd like to give you a brief overview of this quarter. After which, I'll turn the call over to Joe Bellino to discuss our financial results in detail. Let me start off by sa
componenttext:
Thank you, Chris, and good morning everybody. And thank you for joining us today. I'd like to give you a brief overview of this quarter. After which, I'll turn the call over to Joe Bellino to discuss our financial results in detail. Let me start off by saying that this quarter, the first quarter of 2010, included a fair amount of positive developments internally that underscored our commitment to the company's future through a continued investment in new programs. Ducommun, along with the rest of the aerospace and defense industry, faced a good deal of headwinds over the past year. But we're now seeing signs of stabilization.
In the Military market, our fixed and rotary wing business remain solid as we expect it to be throughout the year. And particularly, we see a continued strong demand for the Black Hawk and Chinook helicopter programs due to the U.S. activity in Afghanistan, which is clearly suited for their mission profiles. In the commercial market, we see the overall environment improving, with global pasture in traffic expected to rebound somewhere between 2% and 4% this year. Recent announcements by Boeing and Airbus have been favorable, and commercial end markets appear to be strengthening.
As the global economy improves and assuming fuel prices remain relatively stable, we expect to see a recovery in new order bookings for the aircraft manufacturers. That said, we conservatively plan for the major programs such as the Boeing 737 and Airbus A320 to continue their current rate of production through the end of 2010. With increased rates on the Boeing 777 and 747 in 2011 and 2012 respectively.
For the Boeing 787 Dreamliner, recent developments makes us feel more comfortable that things are moving in the right direction. We believe that destocking of inventory for the Dreamliner is progressing, and we expect to begin shipping products once again late in the third or fourth quarter after nearly a two-year hiatus.
During the quarter, we experienced only modest recovery in demand for the aftermarket of spares, which impacted our DTI bookings, margin of sales, margins in backlog. However, we're seeing a slight uptick in margin and would expect that the aftermarket recovery will accelerate in the second half of 2010. We are also cautiously optimistic about the recovery of the regional jet market, but not until later of this year and possibly running into 2011.
With the exception of the large executive jet class market, we expect the general aviation market to remain soft at the foreseeable future. The regional jet and general aviation markets have historically represented between 10% and 15% of our business. However, we are lower than that this year.
Let me briefly give you some color to our revenue and margins this quarter versus last year. Our AeroStructures business was off nearly 3% in the first quarter of 2010 versus 2009 due to lower Apache and regional jet sales, partially offset by higher sales to RUAG on the Bombardier 700 and 900 series aircraft and on higher commercial fixed wings product. Our margins within this segment were impacted, as expected, by startup investment costs associated with several new products. This margin compression reflects the short-term impact of new applications and programs, which are considered to be key to drive future growth. We expect better operating performance as we ramp up production on new subassemblies while focusing on productivity improvements. Our main initiatives will help improve our operating leverages. Production volume increases in the second half of 2010.
In terms of specific new business development initiatives, I'm speaking of the RUAG Bombardier Fuselage Assembly program, the engineering, design and development of wing movables for the Embraer new 450 and 550 series aircraft and the V-22 contract with Bell Helicopter, as well as some other previously announced and unannounced new business development programs. While we continue to be driving operating performance improvements across the existing business, we recognize the importance of investing in these programs to position the company for future profitable growth. 
As you probably know, there is sometimes the lag between the time that Ducommun wins an award and when it is announced, following customer approval. For example, we do currently have several unannounced new program wins in-house. We continue to work diligently on new program growth as we execute our internal growth strategy and are optimistic about the new business opportunity. 
Moving to Ducommun Technology. We saw a sales slide of 13% year-over-year, primarily reflecting a decline in our Engineering Service businesses. This has been due to lower levels of funding on the RDT&E projects, delays in order releases of new projects and more government insourcing. Our manufactured technology product sales were up slightly as we fare better with increased deliveries of radar rack products, somewhat offset by the lower military and commercial spare sales for electronic components. 
While margins within DTI reflect overall lower sales on spares, they are also impacted by investments made during the quarter and product development, in particular, for a new radar assembly. As with the aerostructures unit, we are investing in new programs that will lead to the higher growth and improvement in the operating performance in the future. 
Now I'd like to turn the call over to Joe Bellino for our financial review.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tony, and good morning, everyone. As Tony just discussed, we reported solid results for the quarter, posting net income of $4.2 million or $0.40 per diluted share versus $2.6 million $0.25 per diluted share a year ago. Now I'd like to provide some
componenttext:
Thanks, Tony, and good morning, everyone. As Tony just discussed, we reported solid results for the quarter, posting net income of $4.2 million or $0.40 per diluted share versus $2.6 million $0.25 per diluted share a year ago. Now I'd like to provide some more color. Sales in the quarter were $104 million or about 6% year-over-year. As Tony noted earlier, we experienced a 3% decrease in our aerostructures or DAS segment, primarily from softer sales in business and regional jets and lower delivery for the Apache helicopter program. While on the positive side, our large aircraft programs and our commercial helicopter products showed solid growth.
In the technology segment, DTI, we saw a 13% decline in sales. A large portion of which was primarily attributed to a 32% decrease in our engineering services revenue. We commented upon this in our fourth quarter earnings call, and was a result of the reduced funding in Military market. Our technology's manufacture products did show a slight increase and higher shipments in radar rack products, which more than offset the continuing softness that we've seen for the last several months in aftermarket products.
Turning to our operating income. Overall, it rose to $6.8 million or 6.6% of revenue from $4.5 million or 4% of revenue a year ago. We estimated that our startup costs associated with several new programs, which generated $3.1 million in revenues during the quarter, affected our operating income by $1.8 million or 240 basis points. To note, last year's operating income included a $4.4 million inventory reserve charge for the Eclipse Aviation bankruptcy filing in March of 2009. Otherwise, if we add that back in on an adjusted basis, operating income last year would have been 8.9% or 8% of our revenues. 
I'll address the decline in this year's first quarter to last year's adjusted operating income in my segment breakdown. Per segment breakdown is in the Ducommun AeroStructures. The operating income improved to $7.5 million or 10.6% of revenues, compared to $4 million or 5.5% of revenues a year ago. On an adjusted operating income basis, excluding the inventory reserve that I just mentioned earlier, the income last year was $8.3 million or 11.5% of revenues. So this year's operating income was off 90 basis points from the adjusted results a year ago. These were primary results of the lower volumes and startup costs related to development of new business on several programs including the RUAG/Bombardier fuselage assembly, engineering work on the Embraer, the V-22 contract with the Bell Helicopter and a few other programs.
We expect these startup costs to continue to the balance of the year, although at a lower impact level going forward than we experienced and noted in the first quarter. Further, margin declines from lower sales in the other areas were somewhat offset by productivity gains that we continue to realize from our lean manufacturing initiatives.
Looking at the Ducommun Technologies operating income, that decreased to $2.4 million or 7.1% of sales versus last year's numbers of $3.3 million or 8.5% operating margins, a drop of 140 basis points. The drop was primarily a result of investments we made during the quarter in product development, related to a new radar rack assembly. Otherwise, we saw declining margins from the lower revenues at our Engineering Services business and reduced sales of aftermarket products. We offset a large portion of these items through increased shipments of radar rack products and continuing efficiency from lean manufacturing initiatives.
Our selling, general and administrative expenses were about 3% lower than last year, despite a $600,000 increase in expenses related to amortization of intangible assets. We continue to manage the cost environment very effectively.
Turning to our business mix and backlog in the current economic environment, we saw our business mix shift to a greater increase in commercial sales. And for the quarter, our business was comprised of 58% military, 40% commercial and 2% space, compared to where we were a year ago, which was 61% military, 37% commercial and 2% space in last year's first quarter. At quarter end, the company's backlog stood at 332 million.
We have had no major program losses, but we have experienced delays from our customers and follow-on orders for a variety of programs including the F-18, the Apache and C-17 programs. We expect follow-on orders for these programs now that it about to be booked in the second quarter and/or in the third quarter. We are optimistic with regards to additional new program wins. And with recent new programs ramping up in 2010, we expect increased backlog levels going forward.
During the quarter, as a normal reflection of our cash flow and business cycle, we used $21 million in cash from operations. It is $2 million improvement over last year, and this is a consistent pattern we have experienced over the last several years. Typically, we are cash users in the first six months of the year. And in the second half of the year, we are a significant cash generator. We continue to focus on effective working capital management by improving inventory turns and increasing our efforts and success in accounts receivable collection.
We continue to maintain a low leverage position regarding our debt, and at quarter end, our net debt to cap ratio was 12%. We feel that given the current economic environment, which still is improving but it is an environment that still has certain amount of uncertainty in the credit market, that we're in an excellent position to be in to weather this environment. We expect our CapEx for the year to be about $11 million, as compared to slightly less than $8 million a year ago. And the increase reflects primarily to new program growth.
Before turning the call back over to Tony, let me just say this, we entered the second quarter of 2010. We believe our strong financial position and our credit profile will allows us to take advantage of several market opportunities to position the company for future growth, improving operating performance and allowing us to make successful acquisition. 
With that, I'd like to ask Tony Reardon to make some additional remarks.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Joe. Before turning the call over to questions, let me summarize a few key points about the state of our business. As Joe mentioned, we ended the first quarter of 2010 with a backlog of $332 million, down slightly from year end. We have a numbe
componenttext:
Thank you, Joe. Before turning the call over to questions, let me summarize a few key points about the state of our business. As Joe mentioned, we ended the first quarter of 2010 with a backlog of $332 million, down slightly from year end. We have a number of follow-on contracts, which Joe discussed, we anticipate booking in the second and third quarters of this year. In addition, we are currently bidding on a strong pipeline of opportunities on multiple high-profile platforms, which will enhance our future growth.
We're also actively pursuing appropriate acquisition candidates to complement our current product offering and in line with our strategic growth objectives. Going forward, we're very optimistic about the commercial aerospace outlet, including the Boeing 787. This program is likely to be a solid contributor to our internal growth heading into next year. We are becoming more positive about 2010 and 2011 as the overall market improvement gains traction.
The company will continue to focus on the fundamentals, so that we are favorably positioned for possible growth as the market turns. We are winning new awards and expanding the breadth and depth of our applications while still managing costs and continuing to focus on operational lessons and effective working capital management. These steps are expected to lead to improvement in our operational performance, particularly as the commercial markets rebound. Management at Ducommun is very much align with the shareholders as we take all the steps necessary to strengthen the company as a leading Aerospace supplier on key programs that expand the benefit from a stronger global economy. And now, Maria, I'd like to turn the call over for questions, please.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Troy Lahr with Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Troy Lahr with Stifel, Nicolaus.

componenttext: When looking at the orders that you're expecting to come through, either the second quarter or the third quarter, do you think you can search production quickly enough to capture the full year revenues or do you think some of the revenues now in 2010 are going to slip out into 2011?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Troy, this is Tony. The question was, are we going to be able to catch new orders coming through? We don't see a lag, Troy, in terms of the order receipts from the existing backlog orders. So we have sufficient backlog, in particular, on the aerospace sid
componenttext: Troy, this is Tony. The question was, are we going to be able to catch new orders coming through? We don't see a lag, Troy, in terms of the order receipts from the existing backlog orders. So we have sufficient backlog, in particular, on the aerospace side to cover existing production run. There are some new orders that are coming in, there are new applications that will require us to ship in 2010 and we're expecting to do that. With regard to the DTI aftermarket, we anticipate that if we have orders by the, let's say, the end of the third quarter, we'll be able to support production requirements on those fair sales for the fourth quarter.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010

componenttext: But if you look at Apache, I thought Apache would be more than $5 million a quarter. Is that kind of the run rate that we should expect now, at least maybe into the second or the third quarter for Apache C-17 and F-18s?

componenttext: On the Apache, Troy, I think in the first quarter, what we saw was a slight dip, because we had some engineering change that were incorporated. And we would expect the run rate on the Apache to be close to $6.5 million to $7 million in the quarter. And we should see a pickup in the second quarter that showed some of the delay in the first quarter. So I'm not sure exactly how much that's going to be. But we'll see an increase in the second quarter over the [indiscernible].

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: And then, I just wanted to lastly drill down on Technologies a little bit. I think last quarter, we had talked about if these margins were sustainable. I kind of got the impression that they were sustainable. In that 12% range, maybe giving some back, giv
componenttext: And then, I just wanted to lastly drill down on Technologies a little bit. I think last quarter, we had talked about if these margins were sustainable. I kind of got the impression that they were sustainable. In that 12% range, maybe giving some back, given some margin mix. But I'm kind of surprised that margins were down, even kind of excluding some of the one-time investments, I think margins were 8.5%. Manufacturing at Technologies and the service mix really didn't change that much sequentially from the fourth quarter. So can you tell me how margins go from, say, 12% in the fourth quarter with a similar mix down to, say, 8.5% adjusted at Technologies.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Troy, with regards to the margins dropping on the Technologies side, I think that there were two primary causes. One, of course, we invested in a program for a radar assembly.
componenttext: Troy, with regards to the margins dropping on the Technologies side, I think that there were two primary causes. One, of course, we invested in a program for a radar assembly.

componenttext: And then, we were certainly impacted by aftermarket revenue, which typically those margins run between, let's say, above 45%, so that had an impact on us, even though the revenue base was slightly off. headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Lewis of BB&T Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Lewis of BB&T Capital Markets.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: With regard to backlog, backlog is the lowest level we've witnessed since 2006. I know that you had just discussed that you would expect the backlog to increase. I just wanted to get a definition, what's your definition of the increase? Because the way I
componenttext: With regard to backlog, backlog is the lowest level we've witnessed since 2006. I know that you had just discussed that you would expect the backlog to increase. I just wanted to get a definition, what's your definition of the increase? Because the way I see it, unless we see a book-to-bill of at least 1x, it's going to be the second year in a row that we could potentially witness year-over-year declines in backlog. So I just want to try and understand the flow of the backlog, what the expectation is by year end and to get a level of comfort that we will indeed see a book-to-bill north of 1x. Could you address that?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, here's what we've seen. We've seen a structural change from some of our customers over the last 12 months. And people like, even Sikorsky and Boeing were seeing more releases on a quarterly basis than an annual basis. So we're not booking the purcha
componenttext: Mike, here's what we've seen. We've seen a structural change from some of our customers over the last 12 months. And people like, even Sikorsky and Boeing were seeing more releases on a quarterly basis than an annual basis. So we're not booking the purchase order for an entire year necessarily all the time. In addition, relative to the whole area of bookings, we talked specifically in our prepared remarks that's related to the radar rack business that we have secured for years, then we announced that back in October of '08 and it has helped buoy our sales during the quarter. So it's just been the customer there. Raytheon hasn't issued us the purchase orders and the way we book them on an accounting basis, they don't show up. As well as the C-17, Boeing is looking at, right now, they're looking at about three years out, with more of the awards on the foreign military sales as opposed to looking at it one year at a time, that and some other programs. We're very positive and very optimistic about it. We continue to ship and fulfill and improve our customer deliveries. Certainly that has the short-term effect of reducing our backlog. But our pipeline looks really quite good in sustainability. And so we feel very positive about it that at some point in time, especially when the commercial aircraft cycle begins to surge up and we start seeing more bookings for the 777 [Boeing 777] and the 787 [Boeing 787], that will be a key to seeing our backlogs improve appreciably.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me just ask you a different question, a different way then. Is your current expectation that you can have a book-to-bill north of 1x by the end of this year?
componenttext: Let me just ask you a different question, a different way then. Is your current expectation that you can have a book-to-bill north of 1x by the end of this year?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Michael, generally, we do. But going into the year, let me, there are a lot of programs, there's a lot of business units within the company that don't generally walk into the year with 1x the backlog for the revenue. In other words, you don't throw all th
componenttext: Michael, generally, we do. But going into the year, let me, there are a lot of programs, there's a lot of business units within the company that don't generally walk into the year with 1x the backlog for the revenue. In other words, you don't throw all the spares business, for example, and some of the other technology businesses. Our backlog is booked and shipped. So if you just take the Engineering Services business, for example, we'll experience bookings this year that will support the revenue base for this year, anything on the technology side. But with regard to the overall bookings, we're expecting in the second and third quarter some pretty significant bookings on the C-17. We've got a multi-year contract that we're working on that. We expect that Apache tail rotors and main rotors to be booked in the second, if possible, and then possibly the third quarter for a follow on. And then the F-18 program will we booked in the second quarter. So of the major programs that we have in the coming -- will be put into the backlog in the second and third quarter. With regards to the Blackhawk, when that program is being booked, this is primarily being booked by the 737 quarter-over-quarter, so we continue to see that growth. And we're under a long-term contract on that program through 2012 right now.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I do understand the book-to-ship work does make it difficult to see in between the quarters, and I respect that. Let me shift gears here real fast. And, Joe, could you talk a little bit about the margin expectation by quarter, by segment. The cor
componenttext: Yes, and I do understand the book-to-ship work does make it difficult to see in between the quarters, and I respect that. Let me shift gears here real fast. And, Joe, could you talk a little bit about the margin expectation by quarter, by segment. The core business typically has its two weakest quarters, are usually the first and fourth quarter, the two strongest quarters are the second and third. But how are the specific segments working with regard to the margin that we can expect in for quarter? Can you help us out with that?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mike. If we break it down by the bad side of it, because of the manufacturing cycle that the AeroStructure business is in, our strongest two quarters are the second and the third. The fourth quarter is typically our weakest quarter because of the hol
componenttext: Yes, Mike. If we break it down by the bad side of it, because of the manufacturing cycle that the AeroStructure business is in, our strongest two quarters are the second and the third. The fourth quarter is typically our weakest quarter because of the holidays and our customers don't pool inventory at the end of the year, and that gets carried over into the following year. And then, our first quarter is about our third strongest quarter. We've had that same cycle through the ends of the year. So the implications are, we ought to get operating the leverage in the second and third quarter from expansion of our business. And then, in the fourth quarter and in the first quarter, we have some margin compression. So we see a variation sequentially during the year. On the DTI side, because a big portion of our products are in the manufacturing products, the radar racks and these other products, we generally see a lot stronger growth in the third quarter and fourth quarter, with emphasis on the fourth quarter. So the DTI cycle builds through sequentially from the first quarter to the fourth quarter typically, and that's what we would expect this year. We have programs onboard like for the APG-79, for the F-18, and we also have 63-V program for the F-15, and the customer usually pulls those in the fourth quarter of the year at a greater rate than the three previous.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: So it's typically along the same lines as the revenue ramp quarter-to-quarter by segment. So it essentially matches that on a margin basis?
componenttext: So it's typically along the same lines as the revenue ramp quarter-to-quarter by segment. So it essentially matches that on a margin basis?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Just to talk about the increased investment that we or at least, I did not anticipate in the quarter. I guess the question is, when were you aware of the need to have the higher investment? And if you knew about this last quarter, was there a reason why y
componenttext: Just to talk about the increased investment that we or at least, I did not anticipate in the quarter. I guess the question is, when were you aware of the need to have the higher investment? And if you knew about this last quarter, was there a reason why you didn't disclose that we would expect a ramp in cost as a result of this preparation work for the contracts? Can you talk about that a little bit?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, the reason for the increased investment was primarily because we had a couple of pull ins on the programs. So I think that if you go back, Michael, we talked in the third quarter and the fourth quarter last year about investing in new programs and th
componenttext: Yes, the reason for the increased investment was primarily because we had a couple of pull ins on the programs. So I think that if you go back, Michael, we talked in the third quarter and the fourth quarter last year about investing in new programs and that, that was coming forward. But what we had in the first quarter, quite frankly, was a couple of accelerations on two programs, which caused us to invest higher than we anticipated. But the investment was part of the process that we've been looking at in terms of growing the business. And I think I've been pretty consistent about talking about the -- our requirements to invest in programs, going forward. I'm very comfortable that we're on target with regards to the type of investments that we're making and that we're in line with our cost expectations. And I believe that we're in a position where these programs will generate future growth, going forward, for us. So I'm real comfortable that we're doing exactly what we said we would do. With regards to knowledge at the last quarter, we saw some accelerations but the impact, we didn't fully anticipate as we came down the curve on a couple of programs. So we did have three programs in-house that were accelerated somewhat in the quarter, which caused us to invest higher than we anticipated.

componenttext: What's happening positively for us is we're picking up some wins that we anticipated, and we're still on the hunt and a couple of others that have not been let yet. So we are actively pursuing some significant growth opportunities and our capture rate is improving in a couple of our business units that are putting us in a position to be successful going forward. So we're very optimistic right now about currently what we have and how to have execution against that. And then we've got a couple of other programs that we're anticipating that will down to final two and hopefully we bag those.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: To give you an opportunity here, there's nothing unusual about your backlog being lumpy? I mean from quarter-to-quarter, we've seen that kind of jump around historically.
componenttext: To give you an opportunity here, there's nothing unusual about your backlog being lumpy? I mean from quarter-to-quarter, we've seen that kind of jump around historically.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: No, not at all. And actually, it happens every year this way. We dip and then we come back. And what's happened -- the unusual portion of it is kind of the delay that we've seen year-over-year. And then, the Boeing shift from going from an annual buy to q
componenttext: No, not at all. And actually, it happens every year this way. We dip and then we come back. And what's happened -- the unusual portion of it is kind of the delay that we've seen year-over-year. And then, the Boeing shift from going from an annual buy to quarterly buys and then the Blackhawk manages that way as well. So we don't see that big spike up in the backlog. What we should see is a comfortable growth going forward. But you're absolutely correct and I appreciate the talk.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010

componenttext: So the question is, what are our thoughts? What's the market like? And do we have the firepower to do it? So Joe will answer the firepower issue and not that I can't. With regards to the thoughts, what we've done and I think we've explained this a little bit, in particular at the conferences. But we put together a strategy on the AeroStructure side, for example, that killed the gaps. And we're looking at companies that fill gaps that would give us more technology base. In the composite site, for example, we're looking at other applications that would take us to higher level of assemblies and some more engineering content. So we're actively pursuing companies that are out there. On the technology side, we have two elements going. We're re-evaluating how we can grow that side of the business. We're looking for solid platform to grow from. We have a couple of excellent opportunities that we have in front of us that we're looking to pursue. So I think that we're moving out. It's been a high focus of this management team for the last year and a half and we haven't pulled the trigger. On a couple, we've been very close. But we have some opportunities we have in front of us that we're pretty focused on right now. And, Joe, on top of the...

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: On accounting side of it, we model it. And look, we could have handle and absorb the demand but primarily through debt. Two acquisitions that are in the $75 million to $100 million range. And with our -- on the debt to EBITDA over 3x, given our cash flows
componenttext: On accounting side of it, we model it. And look, we could have handle and absorb the demand but primarily through debt. Two acquisitions that are in the $75 million to $100 million range. And with our -- on the debt to EBITDA over 3x, given our cash flows. And we've been running through those exercises and we tried to scale up. The last acquisition we made, as you know, it was $45 million, and we're looking to double the size to create more economic mass as a player in the supply chain.

componenttext: Each. We look at either one could be combined or it could be each or it could be -- that's just for modeling purposes. But we've run the analysis on that and we've looked at our, given, our current bank capacity now, which we have about $95 million on our current line. We could expand that another $50 million, at least, and even -- because the debt markets are very robust today. The more leveraged loan markets are such and we studied this -- and this is with Wall Street on these things and the capital availability and the cost of debt financing is very attractive to us that could optimize our capital structure.

componenttextpreview: No, we would not consider an equity offering.With our run rate EBITDA of about $44 million, $45 million now, assuming we purchased companies that have a significant EBITDA, that will allow us to expand our credit facility. We'd figure to an excess of $2
componenttext:
No, we would not consider an equity offering.
With our run rate EBITDA of about $44 million, $45 million now, assuming we purchased companies that have a significant EBITDA, that will allow us to expand our credit facility. We'd figure to an excess of $200 million. And that's with our current debt outstanding would allow us to digest all of those things.

componenttext: What would be -- as we lower. As we see sequentially coming down. I think that basically what we're at, David, is to kind of accelerate the learning curve, if you will, in the first quarter and a couple of programs. And so, we would see that investment coming down sequentially, and anticipate that it would have lower impacts in the quarter and reduce impact going forward.

But the impact of those will abate sequentially over the year. But we'll have them probably continuing in the second, third and fourth quarter albeit at lower rates than during the first quarter, certainly.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] You have a follow-up from the line of Troy Lahr with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: If Boeing does raise production on the 737, do you guys need additional tooling or do you have enough capacity to handle that?
componenttext: If Boeing does raise production on the 737, do you guys need additional tooling or do you have enough capacity to handle that?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: No, Troy. If Boeing does raise the rates on the 737, we're well positioned to manage that going forward. So we've modeled that and actually been pull us by Boeing to go to a rate of somewhere between 34 and 36. And we don't see any additional tooling requ
componenttext: No, Troy. If Boeing does raise the rates on the 737, we're well positioned to manage that going forward. So we've modeled that and actually been pull us by Boeing to go to a rate of somewhere between 34 and 36. And we don't see any additional tooling requirements or expenses other than inventory to grow.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: You could even handle 36 of the current tooling, you said?
componenttext: You could even handle 36 of the current tooling, you said?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Also, can you talk a little bit about the A350 win. How material is that? And how should we think about that program and the investments needed going forward?
componenttext: Also, can you talk a little bit about the A350 win. How material is that? And how should we think about that program and the investments needed going forward?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: It's a good win for us and it has two elements to it right now. It's the skins that we won with some minor assembly on it, and we're looking for participation in the full assembly. So it's in the early stages. As you know, the A350 is in development, so i
componenttext: It's a good win for us and it has two elements to it right now. It's the skins that we won with some minor assembly on it, and we're looking for participation in the full assembly. So it's in the early stages. As you know, the A350 is in development, so it's the initial contract award. And as we wrap up, I think that the aircraft is expected to roll out in late 2012 or 2013. We're in the developing phases of that, if you will. But what we see, the opportunity there is that, that's the in-road into the program, and it's going to give us another opportunity for other applications as we come down the line. So it would be premature right now to tell you that it's going to be a significantly large program for us. But we're working that model to do that.

componenttext: We had picked up a little additional work, and it is more than four components. And we are working out another, a few other applications right now, and it speaks that we're working through that. But we're pretty well positioned on the 787 right now.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Should the tax rates, should that just continue for the next couple of quarters at 33%? Is there an R&D tax credit, that if it comes through, you'd see a benefit there?
componenttext: Should the tax rates, should that just continue for the next couple of quarters at 33%? Is there an R&D tax credit, that if it comes through, you'd see a benefit there?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I suggest modeling at 33% until the federal R&D tax credit is approved by Congress. That may happen in the second quarter, probably more likely the third quarter. And then when it does, I would suggest you model it at 33% until that event occurs. It'
componenttext: Yes, I suggest modeling at 33% until the federal R&D tax credit is approved by Congress. That may happen in the second quarter, probably more likely the third quarter. And then when it does, I would suggest you model it at 33% until that event occurs. It'll drive down to a full year rate that we've enjoyed the last couple of years, of about 31%.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Maria. To close, I just wanted to say that we appreciate our investors' patience, as we face some headwinds this past year and made investments on new programs. We believe the future looks bright. The company is in excellent financial shape and
componenttext:
Thank you, Maria. To close, I just wanted to say that we appreciate our investors' patience, as we face some headwinds this past year and made investments on new programs. We believe the future looks bright. The company is in excellent financial shape and well-positioned for growth and improved performance as we look forward to the global economy's rebound. 
Thank you very much for joining us today, and we appreciate the questions.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and welcome to Ducommun's First Quarter Conference Call. With me today is Tony Reardon, President and CEO; and Joe Bellino, Vice President and CFO. I would now like to provide a brief Safe Harbor statement. This conference call may include fo
componenttext:
Thank you, and welcome to Ducommun's First Quarter Conference Call. With me today is Tony Reardon, President and CEO; and Joe Bellino, Vice President and CFO. 
I would now like to provide a brief Safe Harbor statement. This conference call may include forward-looking statements that represent the company's expectations and beliefs concerning future events that involve risks and uncertainties, and may cause the company's actual performance to be materially different from the performance indicated or implied by such statements.
All statements other than statements of historical facts included in this conference call are forward-looking statements. Although the company believes that the expectations reflected in such forward-looking statements are reasonable, it can give no assurance that such expectations will prove to be have been correct. Important factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from the company's expectations are enclosed in this conference call and in the company's annual report and Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2009.
All subsequent written and oral forward-looking statements attributable to the company or persons acting on its behalf are expressly qualified in their entirety by the cautionary statements. Unless otherwise required by law, the company undertakes no obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statement, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise after the day of this conference call. 
I'd now like turn it over to Ducommun's President and CEO, Tony Reardon for a review of the operating results. Tony?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chris, and good morning everybody. And thank you for joining us today. I'd like to give you a brief overview of this quarter. After which, I'll turn the call over to Joe Bellino to discuss our financial results in detail. Let me start off by sa
componenttext:
Thank you, Chris, and good morning everybody. And thank you for joining us today. I'd like to give you a brief overview of this quarter. After which, I'll turn the call over to Joe Bellino to discuss our financial results in detail. Let me start off by saying that this quarter, the first quarter of 2010, included a fair amount of positive developments internally that underscored our commitment to the company's future through a continued investment in new programs. Ducommun, along with the rest of the aerospace and defense industry, faced a good deal of headwinds over the past year. But we're now seeing signs of stabilization.
In the Military market, our fixed and rotary wing business remain solid as we expect it to be throughout the year. And particularly, we see a continued strong demand for the Black Hawk and Chinook helicopter programs due to the U.S. activity in Afghanistan, which is clearly suited for their mission profiles. In the commercial market, we see the overall environment improving, with global pasture in traffic expected to rebound somewhere between 2% and 4% this year. Recent announcements by Boeing and Airbus have been favorable, and commercial end markets appear to be strengthening.
As the global economy improves and assuming fuel prices remain relatively stable, we expect to see a recovery in new order bookings for the aircraft manufacturers. That said, we conservatively plan for the major programs such as the Boeing 737 and Airbus A320 to continue their current rate of production through the end of 2010. With increased rates on the Boeing 777 and 747 in 2011 and 2012 respectively.
For the Boeing 787 Dreamliner, recent developments makes us feel more comfortable that things are moving in the right direction. We believe that destocking of inventory for the Dreamliner is progressing, and we expect to begin shipping products once again late in the third or fourth quarter after nearly a two-year hiatus.
During the quarter, we experienced only modest recovery in demand for the aftermarket of spares, which impacted our DTI bookings, margin of sales, margins in backlog. However, we're seeing a slight uptick in margin and would expect that the aftermarket recovery will accelerate in the second half of 2010. We are also cautiously optimistic about the recovery of the regional jet market, but not until later of this year and possibly running into 2011.
With the exception of the large executive jet class market, we expect the general aviation market to remain soft at the foreseeable future. The regional jet and general aviation markets have historically represented between 10% and 15% of our business. However, we are lower than that this year.
Let me briefly give you some color to our revenue and margins this quarter versus last year. Our AeroStructures business was off nearly 3% in the first quarter of 2010 versus 2009 due to lower Apache and regional jet sales, partially offset by higher sales to RUAG on the Bombardier 700 and 900 series aircraft and on higher commercial fixed wings product. Our margins within this segment were impacted, as expected, by startup investment costs associated with several new products. This margin compression reflects the short-term impact of new applications and programs, which are considered to be key to drive future growth. We expect better operating performance as we ramp up production on new subassemblies while focusing on productivity improvements. Our main initiatives will help improve our operating leverages. Production volume increases in the second half of 2010.
In terms of specific new business development initiatives, I'm speaking of the RUAG Bombardier Fuselage Assembly program, the engineering, design and development of wing movables for the Embraer new 450 and 550 series aircraft and the V-22 contract with Bell Helicopter, as well as some other previously announced and unannounced new business development programs. While we continue to be driving operating performance improvements across the existing business, we recognize the importance of investing in these programs to position the company for future profitable growth. 
As you probably know, there is sometimes a lag between the time that Ducommun wins an award and when it is announced, following customer approval. For example, we do currently have several unannounced new program wins in-house. We continue to work diligently on new program growth as we execute our internal growth strategy and are optimistic about the new business opportunity. 
Moving to Ducommun Technology. We saw sales slide 13% year-over-year, primarily reflecting a decline in our Engineering Service businesses. This has been due to lower levels of funding on the RDT&E projects, delays in order releases of new projects and more government insourcing. Our manufactured technology product sales were up slightly as we fare better with increased deliveries of radar rack products, somewhat offset by the lower military and commercial spare sales for electronic components. 
While margins within DTI reflect overall lower sales on spares, they are also impacted by investments made during the quarter in product development, in particular, for a new radar assembly. As with the aerostructures unit, we are investing in new programs that will lead to the higher growth and improvement in the operating performance in the future. 
Now I'd like to turn the call over to Joe Bellino for our financial review.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tony, and good morning, everyone. As Tony just discussed, we reported solid results for the quarter, posting net income of $4.2 million or $0.40 per diluted share versus $2.6 million or $0.25 per diluted share a year ago. Now I'd like to provide s
componenttext:
Thanks, Tony, and good morning, everyone. As Tony just discussed, we reported solid results for the quarter, posting net income of $4.2 million or $0.40 per diluted share versus $2.6 million or $0.25 per diluted share a year ago. Now I'd like to provide some more color. Sales in the quarter were $104 million. They were down 6% year-over-year. As Tony noted earlier, we experienced a 3% decrease in our aerostructures or DAS segment, primarily from softer sales in business and regional jets and lower delivery for the Apache helicopter program. While on the positive side, our large aircraft programs and our commercial helicopter products showed solid growth.
In the technology segment, DTI, we saw a 13% decline in sales, a large portion of which was primarily attributed to a 32% decrease in our engineering services revenue. We commented upon this on our fourth quarter earnings call and was a result of the reduced funding in Military market. Our technology's manufacture products did show a slight increase and higher shipments in radar rack products, which more than offset the continuing softness that we've seen for the last several months in aftermarket products.
Turning to our operating income. Overall, it rose to $6.8 million or 6.6% of revenue from $4.5 million or 4% of revenue a year ago. We estimated that our startup costs associated with several new programs, which generated $3.1 million in revenues during the quarter, affected our operating income by $1.8 million or 240 basis points. To note, last year's operating income included a $4.4 million inventory reserve charge for the Eclipse Aviation bankruptcy filing in March of 2009. Otherwise, if we add that back in on an adjusted basis, operating income last year would have been 8.9% or 8% of our revenues. 
I'll address the decline in this year's first quarter to last year's adjusted operating income in my segment breakdown. Per segment breakdown is in the Ducommun AeroStructures. The operating income improved to $7.5 million or 10.6% of revenues, compared to $4 million or 5.5% of revenues a year ago. On an adjusted operating income basis, excluding the inventory reserve that I just mentioned earlier, the income last year was $8.3 million or 11.5% of revenues. So this year's operating income was off 90 basis points from the adjusted results a year ago. These were primary results of the lower volumes and startup costs related to development of new business on several programs including the RUAG/Bombardier fuselage assembly, engineering work on the Embraer, the V-22 contract with the Bell Helicopter and a few other programs.
We expect these startup costs to continue to the balance of the year, although at a lower impact level going forward than we experienced and noted in the first quarter. Further, margin declines from lower sales in the other areas were somewhat offset by productivity gains that we continue to realize from our lean manufacturing initiatives.
Looking at the Ducommun Technologies operating income, that decreased to $2.4 million or 7.1% of sales versus last year's numbers of $3.3 million or 8.5% operating margins, a drop of 140 basis points. The drop was primarily a result of investments we made during the quarter in product development, related to a new radar rack assembly. Otherwise, we saw declining margins from the lower revenues at our Engineering Services business and reduced sales of aftermarket products. We offset a large portion of these items through increased shipments of radar rack products and continuing efficiency from lean manufacturing initiatives.
Our selling, general and administrative expenses were about 3% lower than last year, despite a $600,000 increase in expenses related to amortization of intangible assets. We continue to manage the cost environment very effectively.
Turning to our business mix and backlog in the current economic environment, we saw our business mix shift to a greater increase in commercial sales. And for the quarter, our business was comprised of 58% military, 40% commercial and 2% space, compared to where we were a year ago, which was 61% military, 37% commercial and 2% space in last year's first quarter. At quarter end, the company's backlog stood at 332 million.
We have had no major program losses, but we have experienced delays from our customers and follow-on orders for a variety of programs including the F-18, the Apache and C-17 programs. We expect follow-on orders for these programs now that it about to be booked in the second quarter and/or in the third quarter. We are optimistic with regards to additional new program wins. And with recent new programs ramping up in 2010, we expect increased backlog levels going forward.
During the quarter, as a normal reflection of our cash flow and business cycle, we used $21 million in cash from operations. It is $2 million improvement over last year, and this is a consistent pattern we have experienced over the last several years. Typically, we are cash users in the first six months of the year. And in the second half of the year, we are a significant cash generator. We continue to focus on effective working capital management by improving inventory turns and increasing our efforts and success in accounts receivable collection.
We continue to maintain a low leverage position regarding our debt, and at quarter end, our net debt to cap ratio was 12%. We feel that given the current economic environment, which still is improving but it is an environment that still has certain amount of uncertainty in the credit market, that we're in an excellent position to be in to weather this environment. We expect our CapEx for the year to be about $11 million, as compared to slightly less than $8 million a year ago. And the increase reflects primarily to new program growth.
Before turning the call back over to Tony, let me just say this, we entered the second quarter of 2010. We believe our strong financial position and our credit profile will allows us to take advantage of several market opportunities to position the company for future growth, improving operating performance and allowing us to make successful acquisition. 
With that, I'd like to ask Tony Reardon to make some additional remarks.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Joe. Before turning the call over to questions, let me summarize a few key points about the state of our business. As Joe mentioned, we ended the first quarter of 2010 with a backlog of $332 million, down slightly from year end. We have a numbe
componenttext:
Thank you, Joe. Before turning the call over to questions, let me summarize a few key points about the state of our business. As Joe mentioned, we ended the first quarter of 2010 with a backlog of $332 million, down slightly from year end. We have a number of follow-on contracts, which Joe discussed, which we anticipate booking in the second and third quarters of this year. In addition, we are currently bidding on a strong pipeline of opportunities on multiple high-profile platforms, which will enhance our future growth.
We're also actively pursuing appropriate acquisition candidates to complement our current product offering and in line with our strategic growth objectives. Going forward, we're very optimistic about the commercial aerospace outlook, including the Boeing 787. This program is likely to be a solid contributor to our internal growth heading into next year. We are becoming more positive about 2010 and 2011 as the overall market improvement gains traction.
The company will continue to focus on the fundamentals so that we are favorably positioned for possible growth as the market turns. We are winning new awards and expanding the breadth and depth of our applications while still managing costs and continuing to focus on operational lessons and effective working capital management. These steps are expected to lead to improvement in our operational performance, particularly as the commercial markets rebound. Management at Ducommun is very much aligned with the shareholders as we take all the steps necessary to strengthen the company as a leading aerospace supplier on key programs that stand to benefit from a stronger global economy. And now, Maria, I'd like to turn the call over for questions, please.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Troy, this is Tony. The question was, are we going to be able to catch new orders coming through? We don't see a lag, Troy, in terms of the order receipts from the existing backlog orders. So we have sufficient backlog, in particular, on the aerospace sid
componenttext: Troy, this is Tony. The question was, are we going to be able to catch new orders coming through? We don't see a lag, Troy, in terms of the order receipts from the existing backlog orders. So we have sufficient backlog, in particular, on the aerospace side to cover existing production run. There are some new orders that are coming in that are new applications that will require us to ship in 2010 and we're expecting to do that. With regard to the DTI aftermarket, we anticipate that if we have orders by the, let's say, the end of the third quarter, we'll be able to support production requirements on those fair sales for the fourth quarter.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010

componenttext: On the Apache, Troy, I think in the first quarter, what we saw was a slight dip, because we had some engineering change that were incorporated. And we would expect the run rate on the Apache to be close to $6.5 million to $7 million in the quarter. And we should see a pickup in the second quarter that showed some of the delay in the first quarter. So I'm not sure exactly how much that's going to be. But we'll see an increase in the second quarter over the normal.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: And then, I just wanted to lastly drill down on Technologies a little bit. I think last quarter, we had talked about if these margins were sustainable. I kind of got the impression that they were sustainable in that 12% range, maybe giving some back given
componenttext: And then, I just wanted to lastly drill down on Technologies a little bit. I think last quarter, we had talked about if these margins were sustainable. I kind of got the impression that they were sustainable in that 12% range, maybe giving some back given there's some margin mix. But I'm kind of surprised that margins were down, even kind of excluding some of the onetime investments, I think margins were 8.5%. Manufacturing at Technologies and the service mix really didn't change that much sequentially from the fourth quarter. So can you tell me how margins go from, say, 12% in the fourth quarter with a similar mix down to, say, 8.5% adjusted at Technologies.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Lewis of BB&T Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Lewis of BB&T Capital Markets.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: With regard to backlog, backlog is the lowest level we've witnessed since 2006. I know that you had just discussed that you would expect the backlog to increase. I just wanted to get a definition, what's your definition of the increase? Because the way I
componenttext: With regard to backlog, backlog is the lowest level we've witnessed since 2006. I know that you had just discussed that you would expect the backlog to increase. I just wanted to get a definition, what's your definition of the increase? Because the way I see it, unless we see a book-to-bill of at least 1x, it's going to be the second year in a row that we could potentially witness year-over-year declines in backlog. So I just want to try and understand the flow of the backlog, what the expectation is by year end and to get a level of comfort that we will indeed see a book-to-bill north of 1x. Could you address that?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, here's what we've seen. We've seen a structural change from some of our customers over the last 12 months. And people like, even Sikorsky and Boeing were seeing more releases on a quarterly basis than an annual basis. So we're not booking the purcha
componenttext: Mike, here's what we've seen. We've seen a structural change from some of our customers over the last 12 months. And people like, even Sikorsky and Boeing were seeing more releases on a quarterly basis than an annual basis. So we're not booking the purchase order for an entire year necessarily all the time. In addition, relative to the whole area of bookings, we talked specifically in our prepared remarks that's related to the radar rack business that we have secured for years, then we announced that back in October of '08 and it has helped buoy our sales during the quarter. So it's just been the customer there. Raytheon hasn't issued us the purchase orders and the way we book them on an accounting basis, they don't show up. As well as the C-17, Boeing is looking at, right now, they're looking at about three years out, with more of the awards on the foreign military sales as opposed to looking at it one year at a time, that and some other programs. We're very positive and very optimistic about it. We continue to ship and fulfill and improve our customer deliveries. Certainly that has the short-term effect of reducing our backlog. But our pipeline looks really quite good in sustainability. And so we feel very positive about it that at some point in time, especially when the commercial aircraft cycle begins to surge up and we start seeing more bookings for the 777 [Boeing 777] and the 787 [Boeing 787], that will be a key to seeing our backlogs improve appreciably.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me just ask you a different question, a different way then. Is your current expectation that you can have a book-to-bill north of 1x by the end of this year?
componenttext: Let me just ask you a different question, a different way then. Is your current expectation that you can have a book-to-bill north of 1x by the end of this year?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Michael, generally, we do. But going into the year, let me, there are a lot of programs, there's a lot of business units within the company that don't generally walk into the year with 1x the backlog for the revenue. In other words, you don't throw all th
componenttext: Michael, generally, we do. But going into the year, let me, there are a lot of programs, there's a lot of business units within the company that don't generally walk into the year with 1x the backlog for the revenue. In other words, you don't throw all the spares business, for example, and some of the other technology businesses. Our backlog is booked and shipped. So if you just take the Engineering Services business, for example, we'll experience bookings this year that will support the revenue base for this year, anything on the technology side. But with regard to the overall bookings, we're expecting in the second and third quarter some pretty significant bookings on the C-17. We've got a multi-year contract that we're working on that. We expect that Apache tail rotors and main rotors to be booked in the second, if possible, and then possibly the third quarter for a follow on. And then the F-18 program will we booked in the second quarter. So of the major programs that we have in the coming -- will be put into the backlog in the second and third quarter. With regards to the Blackhawk, when that program is being booked, this is primarily being booked by the 737 quarter-over-quarter, so we continue to see that growth. And we're under a long-term contract on that program through 2012 right now.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I do understand the book-to-ship work does make it difficult to see in between the quarters, and I respect that. Let me shift gears here real fast. And, Joe, could you talk a little bit about the margin expectation by quarter, by segment. The cor
componenttext: Yes, and I do understand the book-to-ship work does make it difficult to see in between the quarters, and I respect that. Let me shift gears here real fast. And, Joe, could you talk a little bit about the margin expectation by quarter, by segment. The core business typically has its two weakest quarters, are usually the first and fourth quarter, the two strongest quarters are the second and third. But how are the specific segments working with regard to the margin that we can expect in for quarter? Can you help us out with that?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mike. If we break it down by the bad side of it, because of the manufacturing cycle that the AeroStructure business is in, our strongest two quarters are the second and the third. The fourth quarter is typically our weakest quarter because of the hol
componenttext: Yes, Mike. If we break it down by the bad side of it, because of the manufacturing cycle that the AeroStructure business is in, our strongest two quarters are the second and the third. The fourth quarter is typically our weakest quarter because of the holidays and our customers don't pool inventory at the end of the year, and that gets carried over into the following year. And then, our first quarter is about our third strongest quarter. We've had that same cycle through the ends of the year. So the implications are, we ought to get operating the leverage in the second and third quarter from expansion of our business. And then, in the fourth quarter and in the first quarter, we have some margin compression. So we see a variation sequentially during the year. On the DTI side, because a big portion of our products are in the manufacturing products, the radar racks and these other products, we generally see a lot stronger growth in the third quarter and fourth quarter, with emphasis on the fourth quarter. So the DTI cycle builds through sequentially from the first quarter to the fourth quarter typically, and that's what we would expect this year. We have programs onboard like for the APG-79, for the F-18, and we also have 63-V program for the F-15, and the customer usually pulls those in the fourth quarter of the year at a greater rate than the three previous.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: So it's typically along the same lines as the revenue ramp quarter-to-quarter by segment. So it essentially matches that on a margin basis?
componenttext: So it's typically along the same lines as the revenue ramp quarter-to-quarter by segment. So it essentially matches that on a margin basis?

componenttext: Yes.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Just to talk about the increased investment that we or at least, I did not anticipate in the quarter. I guess the question is, when were you aware of the need to have the higher investment? And if you knew about this last quarter, was there a reason why y
componenttext: Just to talk about the increased investment that we or at least, I did not anticipate in the quarter. I guess the question is, when were you aware of the need to have the higher investment? And if you knew about this last quarter, was there a reason why you didn't disclose that we would expect a ramp in cost as a result of this preparation work for the contracts? Can you talk about that a little bit?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, the reason for the increased investment was primarily because we had a couple of pull ins on the programs. So I think that if you go back, Michael, we talked in the third quarter and the fourth quarter last year about investing in new programs and th
componenttext: Yes, the reason for the increased investment was primarily because we had a couple of pull ins on the programs. So I think that if you go back, Michael, we talked in the third quarter and the fourth quarter last year about investing in new programs and that, that was coming forward. But what we had in the first quarter, quite frankly, was a couple of accelerations on two programs, which caused us to invest higher than we anticipated. But the investment was part of the process that we've been looking at in terms of growing the business. And I think I've been pretty consistent about talking about the -- our ability or our requirements to invest in programs going forward. I'm very comfortable that we're on target with regards to the type of investments that we're making and that we're in line with our cost expectations. And I believe that we're in a position where these programs will generate future growth, going forward, for us. So I'm real comfortable that we're doing exactly what we said we would do. With regards to knowledge at the last quarter, we saw some accelerations but the impact, we didn't fully anticipate as we came down the curve on a couple of programs. So we did have three programs in-house that were accelerated somewhat in the quarter, which caused us to invest higher than we anticipated.

componenttext: We think it will be lower than that. And we think that as you're coming down the curve, we project lower investments. And I think we satisfied the acceleration requirements that the customers had. So I would expect this to be not as significant as the first quarter, of course.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010

componenttext: And then, kind of looking strategically, you talked about some bidding on multiple opportunities. We saw a recent contract win for about $8 million. But there are a couple of really sizable ones out there that moved a needle for you?

componenttextpreview: Let me put it to you this way. We actually have five new programs that are in-house, that are unannounced. And as you would imagine, a few of them are larger than $8 million and a couple of them are lower. But not significantly larger on the revenue base,
componenttext: Let me put it to you this way. We actually have five new programs that are in-house, that are unannounced. And as you would imagine, a few of them are larger than $8 million and a couple of them are lower. But not significantly larger on the revenue base, it's the same. But they're pretty good contracts and we're anticipating that we'll be pushing those announcements on the next quarter. And we're very comfortable, I think, right now, that from a new business standpoint, that we're doing exactly what we said we would do in terms of going after some sequential growth across the board.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: What's happening positively for us is we're picking up some wins that we anticipated, and we're still on the hunt and a couple of others that have not been let yet. So we are actively pursuing some significant growth opportunities and our capture rate is
componenttext: What's happening positively for us is we're picking up some wins that we anticipated, and we're still on the hunt and a couple of others that have not been let yet. So we are actively pursuing some significant growth opportunities and our capture rate is improving in a couple of our business units that are putting us in a position to be successful going forward. So we're very optimistic right now about currently what we have and how to have execution against that. And then we've got a couple of other programs that we're anticipating that will down to final two and hopefully we bag those.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: To give you an opportunity here, there's nothing unusual about your backlog being lumpy? I mean from quarter-to-quarter, we've seen that kind of jump around historically.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: No, not at all. And actually, it happens every year this way. We dip and then we come back. And what's happened -- the unusual portion of it is kind of the delay that we've seen year-over-year. And then, the Boeing shift from going from an annual buy to q
componenttext: No, not at all. And actually, it happens every year this way. We dip and then we come back. And what's happened -- the unusual portion of it is kind of the delay that we've seen year-over-year. And then, the Boeing shift from going from an annual buy to quarterly buys and then the Blackhawk manages that way as well. So we don't see that big spike up in the backlog. What we should see is a comfortable growth going forward. But you're absolutely correct and I appreciate the talk.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010

componenttext: So the question is, what are our thoughts? What's the market like? And do we have the firepower to do it? So Joe will answer the firepower issue and not that I can't. With regards to the thoughts, what we've done and I think we've explained this a little bit, in particular at the conferences. But we put together a strategy on the AeroStructure side, for example, that killed the gaps. And we're looking at companies that fill gaps that would give us more technology base. In the composite site, for example, we're looking at other applications that would take us to higher level of assemblies and some more engineering content. So we're actively pursuing companies that are out there. On the technology side, we have two elements going. We're re-evaluating how we can grow that side of the business. We're looking for solid platform to grow from. We have a couple of excellent opportunities that we have in front of us that we're looking to pursue. So I think that we're moving out. It's been a high focus of this management team for the last year and a half and we haven't pulled the trigger. On a couple, we've been very close. But we have some opportunities we have in front of us that we're pretty focused on right now. And, Joe, on top of the...

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: On accounting side of it, we model it. And look, we could have handle and absorb the demand but primarily through debt. Two acquisitions that are in the $75 million to $100 million range. And with our -- on the debt to EBITDA over 3x, given our cash flows
componenttext: On accounting side of it, we model it. And look, we could have handle and absorb the demand but primarily through debt. Two acquisitions that are in the $75 million to $100 million range. And with our -- on the debt to EBITDA over 3x, given our cash flows. And we've been running through those exercises and we tried to scale up. The last acquisition we made, as you know, it was $45 million, and we're looking to double the size to create more economic mass as a player in the supply chain.

componenttext: Each. We look at either one could be combined or it could be each or it could be -- that's just for modeling purposes. But we've run the analysis on that and we've looked at our, given, our current bank capacity now, which we have about $95 million on our current line. We could expand that another $50 million, at least, and even -- because the debt markets are very robust today. The more leveraged loan markets are such and we studied this -- and this is with Wall Street on these things and the capital availability and the cost of debt financing is very attractive to us that could optimize our capital structure.

componenttext:
No, we would not consider an equity offering.
With our run rate EBITDA of about $44 million, $45 million now, assuming we purchased companies that have a significant EBITDA, that will allow us to expand our credit facility. We'd figure to an excess of $200 million. And that's with our current debt outstanding would allow us to digest all of those things.
