componenttextpreview: No, Troy. If Boeing does raise the rates on the 737, we're well positioned to manage that going forward. So we've modeled that and actually been pull us by Boeing to go to a rate of somewhere between 34 and 36. And we don't see any additional tooling requ
componenttext: No, Troy. If Boeing does raise the rates on the 737, we're well positioned to manage that going forward. So we've modeled that and actually been pull us by Boeing to go to a rate of somewhere between 34 and 36. And we don't see any additional tooling requirements or expenses other than inventory to grow.

componenttext: Also, can you talk a little bit about the A350 win. How material is that? And how should we think about that program and the investments needed going forward?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: It's a good win for us and it has two elements to it right now. It's the skins that we won with some minor assembly on it, and we're looking for participation in the full assembly. So it's in the early stages. As you know, the A350 is in development, so i
componenttext: It's a good win for us and it has two elements to it right now. It's the skins that we won with some minor assembly on it, and we're looking for participation in the full assembly. So it's in the early stages. As you know, the A350 is in development, so it's the initial contract award. And as we wrap up, I think that the aircraft is expected to roll out in late 2012 or 2013. We're in the developing phases of that, if you will. But what we see, the opportunity there is that, that's the in-road into the program, and it's going to give us another opportunity for other applications as we come down the line. So it would be premature right now to tell you that it's going to be a significantly large program for us. But we're working that model to do that.

componenttextpreview: Yes, I suggest modeling at 33% until the federal R&D tax credit is approved by Congress. That may happen in the second quarter, probably more likely the third quarter. And then when it does, I would suggest you model it at 33% until that event occurs. It'
componenttext: Yes, I suggest modeling at 33% until the federal R&D tax credit is approved by Congress. That may happen in the second quarter, probably more likely the third quarter. And then when it does, I would suggest you model it at 33% until that event occurs. It'll drive down to a full year rate that we've enjoyed the last couple of years, of about 31%.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Maria. To close, I just wanted to say that we appreciate our investors' patience, as we face some headwinds this past year and made investments on new programs. We believe the future looks bright. The company is in excellent financial shape and
componenttext:
Thank you, Maria. To close, I just wanted to say that we appreciate our investors' patience, as we face some headwinds this past year and made investments on new programs. We believe the future looks bright. The company is in excellent financial shape and well-positioned for growth and improved performance as we look forward to the global economy's rebound. 
Thank you very much for joining us today, and we appreciate the questions.

componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Q2 2010 Ducommun Earnings Conference Call. My name is Jeremy, and I'll be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to your host for today, Mr. Chris Witty, Head of Investor Relations. Please proceed, sir.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and welcome to Ducommun's Second Quarter Conference Call. With me today is Tony Reardon, President and CEO; and Joe Bellino, Vice President and CFO.I would now like to provide a brief Safe Harbor statement. This conference call may include fo
componenttext:
Thank you, and welcome to Ducommun's Second Quarter Conference Call. With me today is Tony Reardon, President and CEO; and Joe Bellino, Vice President and CFO.
I would now like to provide a brief Safe Harbor statement. This conference call may include forward-looking statements that represent the company's expectations and beliefs concerning future events that involve risks and uncertainties and may cause the company's actual performance to be materially different from the performance indicated or implied by such statements. All statements other than statements of historical facts included in this conference call are forward-looking statements. Although the company believes that the expectations reflected in such forward-looking statements are reasonable, it can give no assurance that such expectations will prove to be have been correct. Important factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from the company's expectations are disclosed in this conference call and in the company's annual report and Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2009. All subsequent written and oral forward-looking statements attributable to the company or persons acting on its behalf are expressly qualified in their entirety by the cautionary statements. Unless otherwise required by law, the company undertakes no obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise after the date of this conference call.
I'd like to turn it over now to Ducommun's President and CEO, Tony Reardon, for a review of the operating results. Tony?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chris, and thank you, everyone, for joining us today. I'd like to give you a brief overview of this quarter, after which, I'll turn the call over to Joe Bellino to discuss our financial results in detail. As expected, Ducommun is seeing signs
componenttext:
Thank you, Chris, and thank you, everyone, for joining us today. I'd like to give you a brief overview of this quarter, after which, I'll turn the call over to Joe Bellino to discuss our financial results in detail. 
As expected, Ducommun is seeing signs of improvement within our commercial markets and continued stabilization in a large portion of our military markets heading into the second half of 2010. This is setting the stage for growth for next year. 
Our overall revenue fell slightly due primarily to lower sales of our Engineering Services division. We posted 4% growth in our manufactured products, and our margins improved across-the-board. 
More importantly, we were very pleased by the number of contract wins this quarter, particularly with regard to the new business development initiatives which is expected to drive revenue acceleration going forward. These awards show the depth of our partnerships with top-tier OEMs, as Ducommun is called upon to provide integrated next-generation solutions across the broad spectrum of aerospace applications. Many of these awards have not yet shown a surge in the company's backlog either because they are under development, or because the associated purchase orders will take place in installments. But we are winning long-term development and production contracts with an excellent array of key customers.
As an example, Ducommun Technologies received an award from Boeing for the retrofit of the Caution Light Panels on the F-18 cockpits, as the U.S. Navy warning system upgrade. DTI was also awarded a contact on the new engine starts which is on the next generation Boeing 737. These rotary switches will support all miles in production and aftermarket spares, including Boeing classic platforms,  and the production will begin in 2011. 
Likewise, at Ducommun AeroStructures, we were awarded several exciting contracts to illustrate our growth in a more complex sub-assembly. The Latecoere Group selected us for stretch-formed nose-fairing assembly panels in the Airbus A350 and also awarded us contract to supply fuselage and door skins on the Embraer or the ERJ-170 and 190 through 2015. 
In addition, we received a contract from TIGHITCO for the upturned exhaust system sub-assemblies and another components for the Sikorsky Blackhawk helicopter. This is a system that will help lower the helicopters' exhaust IR [infrared] signature. It will be used not only in the production, but will support a significant retrofit program.
We view these wins as a validation that we're doing what we set out to do: play a greater role in the critical aerospace programs and in doing so, make Ducommun a leading Tier 2 player, boosting the company's long-term organic growth. 
As the year progresses, we expect our backlog to grow due to these program wins and as well as follow-on orders from existing programs, including the F-18, F-15, Apache, C-17 and Carson helicopter programs. We also expect the commercial market's upward momentum will accelerate the second half of this year. And we'd see increased rates on the Boeing 737, 747 and 777 programs, as well as start-up on the 787 program and the Airbus A320. These programs will see higher rates in 2011 and 2012. At the same time, we do anticipate a modest rebound in demand of the aftermarket spares in the second half of 2010.
Now before turning the call over to Joe Bellino, let me briefly add some color to our revenue and margins for this quarter. 
Our AeroStructures business was off about 2% in the second quarter of 2010 versus 2009 due to lower military and commercial helicopter sales, partially offset by higher sales to RUAG on the Bombardier 700 and 900 series aircraft and on higher fixed wing and commercial programs. We were pleased to see our margins within this segment improve sequentially. 
Moving to Ducommun Technologies. We saw sales increase 2% year-over-year, despite a 29% decline in our Engineering Services business. A 25% increase occurred within manufactured technology products, boosted by deliveries of radar racks and other electronic components. We're pleased to see DTI operating margins expand, both year-over-year and sequentially from the first quarter, reflecting a more favorable revenue mix and continued productivity enhancements. As with our AeroStructures units, we are investing in new programs that will lead to higher growth and improved operating performance. 
Now I'd like to turn the call over to Joe Bellino. Joe?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tony, and good morning, everyone. Yesterday, we reported solid results in the second quarter, posting net income of $5.7 million or $0.53 per fully diluted share compared to $4.6 million or $0.44 per diluted share a year ago. Now let me give
componenttext:
Thank you, Tony, and good morning, everyone. Yesterday, we reported solid results in the second quarter, posting net income of $5.7 million or $0.53 per fully diluted share compared to $4.6 million or $0.44 per diluted share a year ago. 
Now let me give some color. Some of the financial highlights I will touch upon are the following. Operating income and margins improved both sequentially and year-over-year. We generated $12 million in cash flow from operations during the quarter, and we expect our backlogs to increase in the second half of 2010. 
In terms of sales, second quarter sales of $102 million were down 1% year-over-year. We experienced a 2% decline in sales within our Ducommun AeroStructures segment, DAS, primarily from softer sales in military and commercial helicopter products; while our large fixed wing commercial and fixed wing military aircraft programs showed solid growth. 
In the Technologies segment, we saw a 2% increase in revenues despite a 29% decrease in Engineering Services revenues as a result of reduced government funding. Our manufactured products posted a 25% increase, with higher shipments in replacement radar racks and electronic component.
Looking at our operating income by segment. Ducommun's operating income for the quarter rose 19% to $9 million or 8.8% of revenue from $7.6 million or 7.3% of revenue, as we experienced operating margin improvement in both segments. The 8.8% overall margin for the quarter marked an uptick not only year-over-year, but also sequentially from the first quarter's 6.6%. 
As noted in our release, we had a favorable adjustment during the period of approximately $1.1 million related to the reversal of certain accounts payables accruals recorded in prior periods. 
In addition, we absorbed a $1.1 million expense in start-up and development costs for several new programs which generated sales during the quarter of $2.8 million, and these program were started and we reported on them in the first quarter of 2010. The amount of these costs were down from the first quarter, and we expect them to be reduced sequentially to the balance of the year.
Operating income for the second quarter of 2009 was adversely impacted by an inventory valuation adjustment of $800,000. Excluding these items, adjusted operating income for the second quarter of 2010 would have been $9 million or 9% of revenues compared to an adjusted $8.4 million or 8% of revenues in 2009. 
While gross margins improved, operating income was adversely impacted by an increase of $600,000 in amortization expenses and higher accrued compensation compared to last year's second quarter. 
DAS' operating income improved to $9.2 million and resulted in 13.5% of revenue compared to $7 million or 10.2% of revenue a year ago. This higher operating income reflects a more favorable product mix, driven by increases in the commercial aerospace sector and military fixed wing products and continued operating efficiencies.
DTI's operating income increased to $3.4 million or 9.7% of sales versus $2.9 million or 8.4% last year. This improvement of margin of 130 basis points year-over-year was primarily a result of increased shipments of radar rack products and increases in technology products and continuing efficiencies that we are benefiting from our lean manufacturing activity. 
In terms of looking at our business mix and backlog, in the current economic environment, we saw our business mix shift slightly to a greater percentage of commercial sales; such at the end of the second quarter, our mix of business was 58% military, 40% commercial and 2% space compared to last year's 58% military, 39% commercial and 3% space.
At quarter end, the backlog stood at $306 million. We have had no major program losses, but we have experienced some delays, as Tony reported on, and on follow-on orders for the F-18, F-15, the Apache, C-17 and the Carson helicopter programs. We expect the follow-on orders for these programs to be booked in the third or fourth quarters. We are also optimistic with regard to additional new program wins. And with the recent new programs ramping up in 2010, we expect increased backlog levels going forward.
Now if I may comment on the first half 2010 results. Ducommun's net income was $9.9 million or $0.94 a share, per fully diluted share, in fiscal 2010 versus $7.2 million or $0.69 per fully diluted share a year ago. Our first half sales decreased 4% to $207 million from $215 million in 2009, primarily as a result of a 31% decrease in Engineering Services revenues, while our manufacturing products revenues increased slightly for the first six months. 
DAS' sales decreased about 2.5% to $138 million from $142 million in the first six months, as solid growth in fixed wing products, both large commercial and military aircraft, were not enough to offset lower revenue from military helicopter products and regional and business jets. 
DTI's first half revenues were down about 6%, reflecting shortfalls in aftermarket sales and Engineering Services revenues despite significant growth in radar rack products. DTI posted 13% growth in manufactured technology products, and that more than offset the 31% drop in the Engineering Services revenues. 
Our first half operating income for Ducommun showed an increase by 31% to $15.9 million or 7.7% of revenues compared to $12 million or 5.6% of revenues a year ago. First half results included a favorable inventory adjustment of $1.1 million, which I mentioned earlier, offset by approximately $2.9 million in accumulative start-up and development costs which generated nearly $6 million in sales in the first half. About 90% of the 2010 start-up and development costs can be attributable to the DAS business segment. 
First half 2009 results were negatively impacted by $5.1 million or 2.4 percentage points due to an inventory reserve of $4.3 million related to the bankruptcy filing and an inventory valuation adjustment of $800,000 that I mentioned in the second quarter's report. On an adjusted basis, operating income for the first half would have been $17.7 million or 8.8% of revenues, contrasting that to $17.3 million or 8% of revenues in the prior six months.
DAS' first half 2010 reporting operating income was $16.6 million or 12% of revenues, compared to the reported results of $11 million or 7.8% of revenue a year ago. On a pro forma basis, if we back out the first half development costs in 2010, it's related sales of $5.9 million and the inventory adjustments in both 2010 and 2009, DAS' operating income would have been $18 million or 13.5% of revenue compared to $16.2 million or 11.4% of revenue in 2009. We were pleased to see that DAS' operating margin has improved over 200 basis points on an adjusted basis year-over-year.
For DTI, despite the favorable revenue shift in higher-margin technology products compared to Engineering Services revenues, first half 2010 operating income of $5.8 million, which was 8.4% of revenues, was lower as compared to the $6.3 million or 8.6% of revenues in 2009. 
You will note in my earlier comments that DTI's operating margins in the second quarter of 2010 was 9.7%, up sequentially both from this year's first quarter and higher than the comparable 2009 quarter. We have significant momentum going there, and we expect to continue this momentum in operating margin improvement throughout the balance of 2010.
Selling, general and administrative expenses for the first six months are running at 12.4% as compared to 11.6% for the first half of 2009, and they're largely as a result of expenses related to amortization of intangible expenses and slightly higher compensation accruals. Cost controls remain in effect. 
Commenting now on liquidity and capital resources. During the quarter, we generated nearly $12 million in cash flow from operations, bringing our year-to-date cash from operations to a negative $9 million, which is $6 million better than the comparable period last year. The improvements during the quarter were the result of increased amounts of operating income, depreciation and amortization as well as improved receivables management. 
Typically, we are a cash user in the first six months of the year, as we're seeing this year and in the past. And in the second half of the year, we are a cash generator. We continue to focus on effective working capital management by improving inventory turns and increasing accounts receivable management. 
We also continue to maintain a low-leverage position. At quarter end, our net-debt-to-capital ratio was 9%. We feel that given the current static economic environment and uncertainty in the credit markets, this is an excellent position for us to be in. We expect CapEx in 2010 to be approximately $9 million and compares to slightly less than $8 million a year ago. 
Now I would like to ask Tony Reardon to make some additional remarks. Tony?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Joe. Before turning the call over to questions, let me just hit a few key points. First, our operating margins continue to improve, and we will take every measure necessary to ensure optimum asset utilization. In that vein, we're currently ev
componenttext:
Thank you, Joe. Before turning the call over to questions, let me just hit a few key points. 
First, our operating margins continue to improve, and we will take every measure necessary to ensure optimum asset utilization. In that vein, we're currently evaluating additional facility consolidations and capacity rationalization as part of our productivity enhancement initiatives. More specifically, we're reviewing the implementation of a plan to move certain operations and in doing so, improve facility utilization in support of our growth for many new programs. We see this starting in the second half of 2010, to be completed no later than the first quarter of 2011. While total expenses and payback scenarios are still being analyzed, we envision the cost to be around $1 million to $1.5 million, spreading over the next three quarters, with significant positive ROI beginning in 2011. 
Second, we're winning new business programs which will fuel growth for 2011. We will continue to invest in the development programs as a means to broaden our product offering and drive our internal growth objectives. As Joe mentioned, we have a number of follow-on contracts which we anticipate will be booked in the second half of 2010, increasing our backlog for this year. 
And third, we're optimistic that the commercial aerospace recovery is taking hold, and that the impact will position Ducommun for higher revenue in the quarters to come. 
In summary, 2010 is playing out as expected, and we're pleased that our business units are improving their operating performance and as demand trends begin to turn in our favor. 
Now Jeremy, I'd like to open up the call for questions, please.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Michael Lewis from BB&T.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Can we talk about the start-up costs for a second? In Q1, the revenue was $3.1 million. Q2 came in at $2.8 million, so I'm wondering why the revenue was down. And is this more as a result of seasonality or...
componenttext: Can we talk about the start-up costs for a second? In Q1, the revenue was $3.1 million. Q2 came in at $2.8 million, so I'm wondering why the revenue was down. And is this more as a result of seasonality or...

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Those are just timing difference in terms of getting deliveries out at quarter end, Michael. We're really at the same run rate, and that will continue through the balance of the year.
componenttext: Those are just timing difference in terms of getting deliveries out at quarter end, Michael. We're really at the same run rate, and that will continue through the balance of the year.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And we're seeing that the costs to EBIT is progressively coming down quarter-over-quarter. And should you expect to see that trend continue here through the remainder of this year?
componenttext: And we're seeing that the costs to EBIT is progressively coming down quarter-over-quarter. And should you expect to see that trend continue here through the remainder of this year?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: We expect to continue to have these start-up costs and development costs throughout the balance of the year, although we think they're going to abate a bit. That being said, we still have some additional new programs coming on the second half of the year.
componenttext: We expect to continue to have these start-up costs and development costs throughout the balance of the year, although we think they're going to abate a bit. That being said, we still have some additional new programs coming on the second half of the year. I mean, we were pleased that the costs came down from $1.8 million to $1.1 million. And down the learning curve, we should continue to show progress. But we've done some things in terms of more accountability from our suppliers, doing ties and events and lean things. So we're very active in reducing those costs, and we should be at a much more manageable level come the first quarter of 2011.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Tony had talked about the $1 million to $1.5 million in additional costs from facility rationalization costs, things like that. Are there any other additional costs or charges that we can expect? Over the last few quarters, we have witnessed some costs th
componenttext: Tony had talked about the $1 million to $1.5 million in additional costs from facility rationalization costs, things like that. Are there any other additional costs or charges that we can expect? Over the last few quarters, we have witnessed some costs that we did not expect between the line items. I'm just trying to understand the costs in the business here over the next few quarters, and what we can expect in addition to what our model's currently showing.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Michael, this is Tony. We don't see any additional costs. I mean, obviously, we had the discussion in the first quarter with regards to the start-up costs on these programs, which we tried to forecast last year. But as we progress through the year, I thin
componenttext: Michael, this is Tony. We don't see any additional costs. I mean, obviously, we had the discussion in the first quarter with regards to the start-up costs on these programs, which we tried to forecast last year. But as we progress through the year, I think Joe forecasted that we will have investments going forward on new programs. And we anticipate that as we go forward because as we step into the Tier 2, it's more and more of a requirement to be a player in that market. We anticipate that coming down the learning curve on some of these programs will be faster. We've got programs in place to be able to enhance that. The reason that we mentioned the facility consolidation was exactly to --  given the information that we are anticipating some costs going forward and has a significant payback. It's part of our program to take a look at how best utilize the capital assets that we have in place and to support the growth facility, the growth programs that we have in front of us. So I think that as we look at the business, we're doing everything that we possibly can to optimize the growth of the business, as well as optimize the profitability of the business. And to us, this is a prudent move. But in terms of moving forward, we don't see any other extraneous costs that are in front of us that we would anticipate, other than those costs associated with development of new programs.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: With regard to backlog expectation in fiscal year '10, you've already talked about that you expect that we will see some type of reacceleration in the metric. But I think the most important question here is in the second half of the year, would you antici
componenttext: With regard to backlog expectation in fiscal year '10, you've already talked about that you expect that we will see some type of reacceleration in the metric. But I think the most important question here is in the second half of the year, would you anticipate a book-to-bill of around 1.1x in order to equate a full year book-to-bill of around 1x?

componenttext: Yes, pretty close to that. We do have some issues with regards to Ducommun Technologies that you know that we have shorter booking periods. But we would anticipate some of these major programs would come in, and the comfort would be there that the backlog is closer to the 1x.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it looks like you're getting some more book-to-billed type contracts in there which does impact the total backlog...
componenttext: Yes, it looks like you're getting some more book-to-billed type contracts in there which does impact the total backlog...

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's a slower growth and it's a sequential, so you don't see the big impact like we had in the past. But as we mentioned in the Q, and I think that's on Page 21 in the Q, we talked about the backlog. I think that we've got a pretty good understanding
componenttext: Yes. It's a slower growth and it's a sequential, so you don't see the big impact like we had in the past. But as we mentioned in the Q, and I think that's on Page 21 in the Q, we talked about the backlog. I think that we've got a pretty good understanding of where we're at with the backlog and what we anticipate going forward, and every one of these major programs is in final negotiations now.

componenttext: What is the proportion of your revenue that is now attributable to contracts that are -- you book the revenue and you pretty much immediately ship it out?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Edward Marshall from Sidoti & Company.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Edward Marshall from Sidoti & Company.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I don't know if you already went through this. I'm kind of on multiple calls here. But I for one appreciate and look at the start-up costs in the quarter, and I like that you're incurring them at this point. You haven't hit this kind of operating margin a
componenttext: I don't know if you already went through this. I'm kind of on multiple calls here. But I for one appreciate and look at the start-up costs in the quarter, and I like that you're incurring them at this point. You haven't hit this kind of operating margin at this revenue base since we were kind of in the boom cycle of 2008. So it kind of looks like to me, the drop-through from these programs is a little bit higher margin than some of your, maybe, legacy programs. Can you kind of help me work with that a little bit?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, we're getting more efficiency out of some of the legacy programs, and that's what I think you're seeing. And then we're getting good growth on some of the start-up programs and moving faster on some of those. So the 747-8 program, for example, i
componenttext: Actually, we're getting more efficiency out of some of the legacy programs, and that's what I think you're seeing. And then we're getting good growth on some of the start-up programs and moving faster on some of those. So the 747-8 program, for example, is accelerating through at a nicer rate than we anticipated earlier. But I would say overall, we're getting the margins we anticipate on start-up programs versus legacy programs. I don't think there's any big shift there.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And then clearly, the commercial cycle is improving, Tony. And you were just in Farnborough, and I don't know if you commented on this in your prepared remarks. I mean, obviously, we all saw the order activity and so forth. But could you comment on kind o
componenttext: And then clearly, the commercial cycle is improving, Tony. And you were just in Farnborough, and I don't know if you commented on this in your prepared remarks. I mean, obviously, we all saw the order activity and so forth. But could you comment on kind of the pulse, if you will, that you saw at the show, obviously, order rates being good?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Overall, I think that we saw on the commercial side a very, very positive swing. I'm not sure if a lot of the orders that we saw come out of Farnborough or a more acknowledgment of existing orders that Boeing and Airbus had. But clearly, we're seeing
componenttext: Yes. Overall, I think that we saw on the commercial side a very, very positive swing. I'm not sure if a lot of the orders that we saw come out of Farnborough or a more acknowledgment of existing orders that Boeing and Airbus had. But clearly, we're seeing a pretty solid backlog that came through. The real buzz was around whether or not Boeing and Airbus were going to either re-engine or new aircraft on the single aisle to replace 737 and A320. But having said that, they both announced higher rates, talked about higher rate production on their commercial aircraft program. The military side was more conversations around higher requirements for military sales. And that's where, I think, they see their market growth opportunities, which we encourage obviously and we'll support. And then, not much talk on the space side obviously and with the budget influx. So the big push was on the commercial side. I think probably the biggest disappointment was no major orders on the C-series aircraft announcements from the show. But primarily on the commercial side, I think we saw a big push there.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And working so close with Boeing, I mean, your thoughts with kind of the 737. Where would you stand in line if we did kind of redesign that aircraft? Obviously, probably re-engining is better off in the near term for you. But any comments you can add to t
componenttext: And working so close with Boeing, I mean, your thoughts with kind of the 737. Where would you stand in line if we did kind of redesign that aircraft? Obviously, probably re-engining is better off in the near term for you. But any comments you can add to that?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I think we would look to participate heavily on that aircraft. We're a major player on the 737 right now in terms of our current chipset value, and we would look to play a role on that aircraft. And as we grow more towards Tier 2, hopefully we will be abl
componenttext: I think we would look to participate heavily on that aircraft. We're a major player on the 737 right now in terms of our current chipset value, and we would look to play a role on that aircraft. And as we grow more towards Tier 2, hopefully we will be able to expand that. So we see lots of opportunities coming out now as they expand their production rate or get ready to do that, so we would look to enhance our roles there.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And then finally, this is a question I've asked several times before, and I'm not going to hold out on this call either. But can you comment kind of on acquisitions and what you're thinking about? And what you can kind of give comfort to maybe the investo
componenttext: And then finally, this is a question I've asked several times before, and I'm not going to hold out on this call either. But can you comment kind of on acquisitions and what you're thinking about? And what you can kind of give comfort to maybe the investor base about not making just an acquisition, just for the sake of making an acquisition?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: We have four criteria that we've really been focusing on, and they have to be a strategic fit. It has to be in line with as part of that, just in line with our strategic goals of getting to more complex assemblies and positioning us stronger in the supply
componenttext: We have four criteria that we've really been focusing on, and they have to be a strategic fit. It has to be in line with as part of that, just in line with our strategic goals of getting to more complex assemblies and positioning us stronger in the supply chain as a Tier 2. That's one key point. The other one is that we have to be able to effectively integrate these and see the synergies that make sense.  The next one is obviously, it has to be complementary products, whether it's another leg to the stool here, or whether it fits in well with our existing product offerings. And then finally fourth, the way we look at it is fair value. If we do the three things that precede that, then we will know by definition it will fair value. Tony?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And Ed, I think in response to the question of just doing it to do it, we're not doing that. I mean, we're actively looking. We have identified on the structure side of the business gaps that we would like to fill in order to enhance our product offering
componenttext: And Ed, I think in response to the question of just doing it to do it, we're not doing that. I mean, we're actively looking. We have identified on the structure side of the business gaps that we would like to fill in order to enhance our product offering along the engineering, more engineering growth and larger assemblies. And on a technology side, we're looking for a consolidation of the solid platform to grow from. So we're looking to grow this business, and we believe that acquisitions will play a role in that.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: But looking at kind of the valuations in the space, do you think -- I mean, would it be a year dilutive, maybe two years dilutive? Obviously, that's a tough question to say at this stage, but kind of just...
componenttext: But looking at kind of the valuations in the space, do you think -- I mean, would it be a year dilutive, maybe two years dilutive? Obviously, that's a tough question to say at this stage, but kind of just...

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: It's difficult to answer until we have the acquisition in play and have the ability to analyze it.
componenttext: It's difficult to answer until we have the acquisition in play and have the ability to analyze it.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Maybe I'd ask you a different way. How long would you be willing to dilute the earnings for an acquisition that made sense?
componenttext: Maybe I'd ask you a different way. How long would you be willing to dilute the earnings for an acquisition that made sense?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I really can't say without having the specific acquisition in front of me and how that plays into the strategic growth of the company. I think I would gladly answer that question once I have identified and we've honed in and closed on an acquisition, and
componenttext: I really can't say without having the specific acquisition in front of me and how that plays into the strategic growth of the company. I think I would gladly answer that question once I have identified and we've honed in and closed on an acquisition, and I'll clearly address that issue going forward. But without having the ability to analyze that and understand the strategic positioning of that business within our business, I think it would be imprudent to try and speculate.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Michael Lewis with BB&T.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Michael Lewis with BB&T.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: With regard to the third quarter, it typically plays out as one with stronger revenue and margin quarters. And Joe, you had offered some commentary on March, and I think I missed it a little bit. Did you say that you anticipate that margin would continue
componenttext: With regard to the third quarter, it typically plays out as one with stronger revenue and margin quarters. And Joe, you had offered some commentary on March, and I think I missed it a little bit. Did you say that you anticipate that margin would continue the current positive trends that we've witnessed over the prior few quarters?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I think the question relates to how sustainable our second quarter margins, and we are very pleased that they're up year-over-year and they were improved sequentially from some things we've done. I think when we look at the modeling, we have to factor in
componenttext: I think the question relates to how sustainable our second quarter margins, and we are very pleased that they're up year-over-year and they were improved sequentially from some things we've done. I think when we look at the modeling, we have to factor in the start-up and development costs, plus the spread of this $1 million to $1.5 million costs over the next three quarters for our capacity expansions and rationalizations and better asset utilization. So that being said -- and the environment still is somewhat stabilized in some sectors, as we talked about. I'm giving you a little backdrop on it. But what we do expect in the third quarter in terms of overall deliveries, we expect a good continued modest increase in the Large Aircraft segment and some nominal growth in the Regional and Business Aircraft segment; and also in the fixed wing military, which is C-17 is stable but F-15 and F-18. So we do see some nominal growth there. We still have the issue of where the Apache now did about $7 million this quarter. We're still looking at $6 million to $6.5 million. And without going through all the programs, we see a slight improvement in sales here in the third quarter, but not robust or a step change yet. So as we manage through our psychology, as we recognize the costs we're going to incur, we continue to work on improving our revenue mix and also continued focus on operating efficiencies to try to keep these margins normally where they are, but modestly expand them in this environment.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Joe, is that a slight improvement in revenue in Q3 year-over-year or sequentially?
componenttext: Joe, is that a slight improvement in revenue in Q3 year-over-year or sequentially?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I think sequentially.
componenttext: I think sequentially.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And then what is -- the company has talked about this in the past. But what is the margin goal, core, company-wide, say, two to two and a half, three years out? Are we looking at mid-9% levels, closer to 10%?
componenttext: And then what is -- the company has talked about this in the past. But what is the margin goal, core, company-wide, say, two to two and a half, three years out? Are we looking at mid-9% levels, closer to 10%?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: When I look at those margins, I just want to give a little historic perspective, if I may, where we were. At one time in '08, for the first three quarters, we were averaging about 9.5%. And at that time, we had said 10%. I think those have been modified.
componenttext: When I look at those margins, I just want to give a little historic perspective, if I may, where we were. At one time in '08, for the first three quarters, we were averaging about 9.5%. And at that time, we had said 10%. I think those have been modified. I mean, I think our goal is still to get at above 10%. I think what our conversation has been, recently in this environment since the fourth quarter of '08, is that it'll take us a little longer to get there, but within the context of our current environment, where during the quarter we had 8.8%. In the intermediate term, we certainly look to exceed that anomaly, the 9%, the 9.25% for now and eventually get to 10% as these newer products and new programs mature.

[Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to your host for today, Mr. Chris Witty, title: Investor Relations. Please proceed, sir.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and welcome to Ducommun's Second Quarter Conference Call. With me today is Tony Reardon, President and CEO; and Joe Bellino, Vice President and CFO.I would now like to provide a brief Safe Harbor statement. This conference call may include fo
componenttext:
Thank you, and welcome to Ducommun's Second Quarter Conference Call. With me today is Tony Reardon, President and CEO; and Joe Bellino, Vice President and CFO.
I would now like to provide a brief Safe Harbor statement. This conference call may include forward-looking statements that represent the company's expectations and beliefs concerning future events that involve risks and uncertainties and may cause the company's actual performance to be materially different from the performance indicated or implied by such statements. All statements other than statements of historical facts included in this conference call are forward-looking statements. Although the company believes that the expectations reflected in such forward-looking statements are reasonable, it can give no assurance that such expectations will prove to be have been correct. Important factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from the company's expectations are disclosed in this conference call and in the company's annual report and Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2009. All subsequent written and oral forward-looking statements attributable to the company or persons acting on its behalf are expressly qualified in their entirety by the cautionary statements. Unless otherwise required by law, the company undertakes no obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise after the date of this conference call.
I'd like to turn it over now to Ducommun's President and CEO, Tony Reardon, for a review of the operating results. Tony?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chris, and thank you, everyone, for joining us today. I'd like to give you a brief overview of this quarter, after which, I'll turn the call over to Joe Bellino to discuss our financial results in detail. As expected, Ducommun is seeing signs
componenttext:
Thank you, Chris, and thank you, everyone, for joining us today. I'd like to give you a brief overview of this quarter, after which, I'll turn the call over to Joe Bellino to discuss our financial results in detail. 
As expected, Ducommun is seeing signs of improvement within our commercial markets and continued stabilization in a large portion of our military markets heading into the second half of 2010. This is setting the stage for growth for next year. 
Our overall revenue fell slightly due primarily to lower sales of our Engineering Services division. We posted 4% growth in our manufactured products, and our margins improved across-the-board. 
More importantly, we were very pleased by the number of contract wins this quarter, particularly with regard to the new business development initiatives which is expected to drive revenue acceleration going forward. These awards show the depth of our partnerships with top-tier OEMs, as Ducommun is called upon to provide integrated next-generation solutions across the broad spectrum of aerospace applications. Many of these awards have not yet shown a surge in the company's backlog either because they are under development, or because the associated purchase orders will take place in installments. But we are winning long-term development and production contracts with an excellent array of key customers.
As an example, Ducommun Technologies received an award from Boeing for the retrofit of the Caution Light Panels on the F-18 cockpits, as the U.S. Navy warning system upgrade. DTI was also awarded a contract on the new engine starts which is on the next-generation Boeing 737. These rotary switches will support all miles in production and aftermarket spares, including Boeing classic platforms, and the production will begin in 2011. 
Likewise, at Ducommun AeroStructures, we were awarded several exciting contracts to illustrate our growth in a more complex sub-assembly. The Latecoere Group selected us for stretch-formed nose-fairing assembly panels in the Airbus A350 and also awarded us contract to supply fuselage and door skins on the Embraer or the ERJ-170 and 190 through 2015. 
In addition, we received a contract from TIGHITCO for the upturned exhaust system sub-assemblies and other components for the Sikorsky Blackhawk helicopter. This is a system that will help lower the helicopters' exhaust IR [infrared] signature. It will be used not only in the production, but will support a significant retrofit program.
We view these wins as a validation that we're doing what we set out to do: play a greater role in the critical aerospace programs and in doing so, make Ducommun a leading Tier 2 player, boosting the company's long-term organic growth. 
As the year progresses, we expect our backlog to grow due to these program wins and as well as follow-on orders from existing programs, including the F-18, F-15, Apache, C-17 and Carson Helicopter programs. We also expect the commercial market's upward momentum will accelerate the second half of this year, and we see increased rates on the Boeing 737, 747 and 777 programs, as well as start-up on the 787 program and the Airbus A320. These programs will see higher rates in 2011 and 2012. At the same time, we do anticipate a modest rebound in demand of the aftermarket spares in the second half of 2010.
Now before turning the call over to Joe Bellino, let me briefly add some color to our revenue and margins for this quarter. 
Our AeroStructures business was off about 2% in the second quarter of 2010 versus 2009 due to lower military and commercial helicopter sales, partially offset by higher sales to RUAG on the Bombardier 700 and 900 series aircraft and on higher fixed wing and commercial programs. We were pleased to see our margins within this segment improve sequentially. 
Moving to Ducommun Technologies. We saw sales increase 2% year-over-year, despite a 29% decline in our Engineering Services business. A 25% increase occurred within manufactured technology products, boosted by deliveries of radar racks and other electronic components. We're pleased to see DTI operating margins expand, both year-over-year and sequentially from the first quarter, reflecting a more favorable revenue mix and continued productivity enhancements. As with our AeroStructures units, we are investing in new programs that will lead to higher growth and improved operating performance. 
Now I'd like to turn the call over to Joe Bellino. Joe?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tony, and good morning, everyone. Yesterday, we reported solid results in the second quarter, posting net income of $5.7 million or $0.53 per fully diluted share compared to $4.6 million or $0.44 per diluted share a year ago. Now let me give
componenttext:
Thank you, Tony, and good morning, everyone. Yesterday, we reported solid results in the second quarter, posting net income of $5.7 million or $0.53 per fully diluted share compared to $4.6 million or $0.44 per diluted share a year ago. 
Now let me give some color. Some of the financial highlights I will touch upon are the following: Operating income and margins improved both sequentially and year-over-year. We generated $12 million in cash flow from operations during the quarter, and we expect our backlogs to increase in the second half of 2010. 
In terms of sales, second quarter sales of $102 million were down 1% year-over-year. We experienced a 2% decline in sales within our Ducommun AeroStructures segment, DAS, primarily from softer sales in military and commercial helicopter products; while our large fixed wing commercial and fixed wing military aircraft programs showed solid growth. 
In the Technologies segment, we saw a 2% increase in revenues despite a 29% decrease in Engineering Services revenues as a result of reduced government funding. Our manufactured products posted a 25% increase, with higher shipments in replacement radar racks and electronic components.
Looking at our operating income by segment, Ducommun's operating income for the quarter rose 19% to $9 million or 8.8% of revenue from $7.6 million or 7.3% of revenue, as we experienced operating margin improvement in both segments. The 8.8% overall margin for the quarter marked an uptick not only year-over-year, but also sequentially from the first quarter's 6.6%. 
As noted in our release, we had a favorable adjustment during the period of approximately $1.1 million related to the reversal of certain accounts payables accruals recorded in prior periods. 
In addition, we absorbed a $1.1 million expense in start-up and development costs for several new programs which generated sales during the quarter of $2.8 million, and these programs were started and we reported on them in the first quarter of 2010. The amount of these costs were down from the first quarter, and we expect them to be reduced sequentially through the balance of the year.
Operating income for the second quarter of 2009 was adversely impacted by an inventory valuation adjustment of $800,000. Excluding these items, adjusted operating income for the second quarter of 2010 would have been $9 million or 9% of revenues compared to an adjusted $8.4 million or 8% of revenues in 2009. 
While gross margins improved, operating income was adversely impacted by an increase of $600,000 in amortization expenses and higher accrued compensation compared to last year's second quarter. 
DAS' operating income improved to $9.2 million and resulted in 13.5% of revenue compared to $7 million or 10.2% of revenue a year ago. This higher operating income reflects a more favorable product mix, driven by increases in the commercial aerospace sector and military fixed wing products and continued operating efficiencies.
DTI's operating income increased to $3.4 million or 9.7% of sales versus $2.9 million or 8.4% last year. This improvement of margin of 130 basis points year-over-year was primarily a result of increased shipments of radar rack products and increases in technology products and continuing efficiencies that we are benefiting from our lean manufacturing activity. 
In terms of looking at our business mix and backlog, in the current economic environment, we saw our business mix shift slightly to a greater percentage of commercial sales; such at the end of the second quarter, our mix of business was 58% military, 40% commercial and 2% space compared to last year's 58% military, 39% commercial and 3% space.
At quarter end, the backlog stood at $306 million. We have had no major program losses, but we have experienced some delays, as Tony reported on, and on follow-on orders for the F-18, F-15, the Apache, C-17 and the Carson Helicopter programs. We expect the follow-on orders for these programs to be booked in the third or fourth quarters. We are also optimistic with regard to additional new program wins. And with the recent new programs ramping up in 2010, we expect increased backlog levels going forward.
Now if I may comment on the first half 2010 results. Ducommun's net income was $9.9 million or $0.94 a share, per fully diluted share, in fiscal 2010 versus $7.2 million or $0.69 per fully diluted share a year ago. Our first half sales decreased 4% to $207 million from $215 million in 2009, primarily as a result of a 31% decrease in Engineering Services revenues, while our manufacturing products revenues increased slightly for the first six months. 
DAS' sales decreased about 2.5% to $138 million from $142 million in the first six months, as solid growth in fixed wing products, both large commercial and military aircraft, were not enough to offset lower revenue from military helicopter products and regional and business jets. 
DTI's first half revenues were down about 6%, reflecting shortfalls in aftermarket sales and Engineering Services revenues despite significant growth in radar rack products. DTI posted 13% growth in manufactured technology products, and that more than offset the 31% drop in the Engineering Services revenue. 
Our first half operating income for Ducommun showed an increase by 31% to $15.9 million or 7.7% of revenues compared to $12 million or 5.6% of revenues a year ago. First half results included a favorable inventory adjustment of $1.1 million, which I mentioned earlier, offset by approximately $2.9 million in accumulative start-up and development costs which generated nearly $6 million in sales in the first half. About 90% of the 2010 start-up and development costs can be attributable to the DAS business segment. 
First half 2009 results were negatively impacted by $5.1 million or 2.4 percentage points due to an inventory reserve of $4.3 million related to the bankruptcy filing and an inventory valuation adjustment of $800,000 that I mentioned in the second quarter's report. On an adjusted basis, operating income for the first half would have been $17.7 million or 8.8% of revenues, contrasting that to $17.3 million or 8% of revenues in the prior six months.
DAS' first half 2010 reporting operating income was $16.6 million or 12% of revenues, compared to the reported results of $11 million or 7.8% of revenue a year ago. On a pro forma basis, if we back out the first half development costs in 2010, its related sales of $5.9 million and the inventory adjustments in both 2010 and 2009, DAS' operating income would have been $18 million or 13.5% of revenue compared to $16.2 million or 11.4% of revenue in 2009. We were pleased to see that DAS' operating margins had improved over 200 basis points on an adjusted basis year-over-year.
For DTI, despite the favorable revenue shift in higher-margin technology products compared to Engineering Services revenues, first half 2010 operating income of $5.8 million, which was 8.4% of revenues, was lower as compared to the $6.3 million or 8.6% of revenues in 2009. 
You will note in my earlier comments that DTI's operating margins in the second quarter of 2010 was 9.7%, up sequentially both from this year's first quarter and higher than the comparable 2009 quarter. We have significant momentum going there, and we expect to continue this momentum in operating margin improvement throughout the balance of 2010.
Selling, general and administrative expenses over the first six months are running at 12.4% as compared to 11.6% for the first half of 2009, and they're largely as a result of expenses related to amortization of intangible expenses and slightly higher compensation accruals. Cost controls remain in effect. 
Commenting now on liquidity and capital resources. During the quarter, we generated nearly $12 million in cash flow from operations, bringing our year-to-date cash from operations to a negative $9 million, which is $6 million better than the comparable period last year. The improvements during the quarter were the result of increased amounts of operating income, depreciation and amortization as well as improved receivables management. 
Typically, we are a cash user in the first six months of the year, as we're seeing this year and in the past. And in the second half of the year, we are a cash generator. We continue to focus on effective working capital management by improving inventory turns and increasing accounts receivable management. 
We also continue to maintain a low-leverage position. At quarter end, our net-debt-to-capital ratio was 9%. We feel that given the current static economic environment and uncertainty in the credit markets, this is an excellent position for us to be in. We expect CapEx in 2010 to be approximately $9 million and compares to slightly less than $8 million a year ago. 
Now I would like to ask Tony Reardon to make some additional remarks. Tony?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Joe. Before turning the call over to questions, let me just hit a few key points. First, our operating margins continue to improve, and we will take every measure necessary to ensure optimum asset utilization. In that vein, we're currently ev
componenttext:
Thank you, Joe. Before turning the call over to questions, let me just hit a few key points. 
First, our operating margins continue to improve, and we will take every measure necessary to ensure optimum asset utilization. In that vein, we're currently evaluating additional facility consolidations and capacity rationalization as part of our productivity enhancement initiatives. More specifically, we're reviewing the implementation of a plan to move certain operations and in doing so, improve facility utilization in support of our growth for many new programs. We see this starting in the second half of 2010, to be completed no later than the first quarter of 2011. While total expenses and payback scenarios are still being analyzed, we envision the cost to be around $1 million to $1.5 million, spreading over the next three quarters, with significant positive ROI beginning in 2011. 
Second, we're winning new business programs which will fuel growth for 2011. We will continue to invest in the development programs as a means to broaden our product offering and drive our internal growth objectives. As Joe mentioned, we have a number of follow-on contracts which we anticipate will be booked in the second half of 2010, increasing our backlog for this year. 
And third, we're optimistic that the commercial aerospace recovery is taking hold, and that the impact will position Ducommun for higher revenue in the quarters to come. 
In summary, 2010 is playing out as expected, and we're pleased that our business units are improving their operating performance and as demand trends begin to turn in our favor. 
Now, Jeremy, I'd like to open up the call for questions, please.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And we're seeing that the cost impact to EBIT is progressively coming down quarter-over-quarter. And should you expect to see that trend continue here through the remainder of this year?
componenttext: And we're seeing that the cost impact to EBIT is progressively coming down quarter-over-quarter. And should you expect to see that trend continue here through the remainder of this year?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: We expect to continue to have these start-up costs and development costs throughout the balance of the year, although we think they're going to abate a bit. That being said, we still have some additional new programs coming on in the second half of the ye
componenttext: We expect to continue to have these start-up costs and development costs throughout the balance of the year, although we think they're going to abate a bit. That being said, we still have some additional new programs coming on in the second half of the year. I mean, we were pleased that the costs came down from $1.8 million to $1.1 million. And down the learning curve, we should continue to show progress. But we've done some things in terms of more accountability from our suppliers, doing ties and events and lean things. So we're very active in reducing those costs, and we should be at a much more manageable level come the first quarter of 2011.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And let me ask you another question about the -- Tony had talked about the $1 million to $1.5 million in additional costs from facility rationalization costs, things like that. Are there any other additional costs or charges that we can expect? Over the l
componenttext: And let me ask you another question about the -- Tony had talked about the $1 million to $1.5 million in additional costs from facility rationalization costs, things like that. Are there any other additional costs or charges that we can expect? Over the last few quarters, we’ve witnessed some costs that we did not expect between the line items. I'm just trying to understand the cost of the business here over the next few quarters, and what we can expect in addition to what our model's currently showing.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Michael, this is Tony. We don't see any additional cost. I mean, obviously, we had the discussion in the first quarter with regards to the start-up costs on these programs, which we tried to forecast last year. But as we progress through the year, I think
componenttext: Michael, this is Tony. We don't see any additional cost. I mean, obviously, we had the discussion in the first quarter with regards to the start-up costs on these programs, which we tried to forecast last year. But as we progress through the year, I think Joe forecasted that we will have investments going forward on new programs. And we anticipate that as we go forward because as we step into the Tier 2, it's more and more of a requirement to be a player in that market. We anticipate that coming down the learning curve on some of these programs will be faster. We've got programs in place to be able to enhance that. The reason that we mentioned the facility consolidation was exactly to --  given the information that we are anticipating some costs going forward, it has a significant payback. It's part of our program to take a look at how best utilize the capital assets that we have in place and to support the growth facility, the growth programs that we have in front of us. So I think that as we look at the business, we're doing everything that we possibly can to optimize the growth of the business, as well as optimize the profitability of the business. And to us, this is a prudent move. But in terms of moving forward, we don't see any other extraneous costs that are in front of us that we would anticipate, other than those costs associated with development of new programs.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I don't know if you already went through this. I'm kind of on multiple calls here. But I for one appreciate and look at the start-up costs in the quarter, and I like that you're incurring them at this point. You haven't hit this kind of operating margin a
componenttext: I don't know if you already went through this. I'm kind of on multiple calls here. But I for one appreciate and look at the start-up costs in the quarter, and I like that you're incurring them at this point. You haven't hit this kind of operating margin at this revenue base since we were kind of in the boom cycle of 2008. So it kind of looks like to me, the drop-through from these programs is a little bit higher margin than some of your, maybe, legacy programs. Can you kind of help me work with that a little bit?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, we're getting more efficiency out of some of the legacy programs, and that's what I think you're seeing. And then we're getting good growth on some of the start-up programs and moving faster on some of those. So the 747-8 program, for example, i
componenttext: Actually, we're getting more efficiency out of some of the legacy programs, and that's what I think you're seeing. And then we're getting good growth on some of the start-up programs and moving faster on some of those. So the 747-8 program, for example, is accelerating through at a nicer rate than we anticipated earlier. But I would say overall, we're getting the margins we anticipate on start-up programs versus legacy programs. I don't think there's any big shift there.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And then clearly, the commercial cycle is improving, Tony. And you were just in Farnborough, and I don't know if you commented on this in your prepared remarks. But I mean, obviously, we all saw the order activity and so forth. But could you comment on ki
componenttext: And then clearly, the commercial cycle is improving, Tony. And you were just in Farnborough, and I don't know if you commented on this in your prepared remarks. But I mean, obviously, we all saw the order activity and so forth. But could you comment on kind of the pulse, if you will, that you saw at the show, obviously, order rates being good?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Overall, I think that we saw on the commercial side a very, very positive swing. I'm not sure if a lot of the orders that we saw come out of Farnborough were more acknowledgment of existing orders that Boeing and Airbus had. But clearly, we're seeing
componenttext: Yes. Overall, I think that we saw on the commercial side a very, very positive swing. I'm not sure if a lot of the orders that we saw come out of Farnborough were more acknowledgment of existing orders that Boeing and Airbus had. But clearly, we're seeing a pretty solid backlog that came through. The real buzz was around whether or not Boeing and Airbus were going to either re-engine or new aircraft on the single aisle to replace 737 and A320. But having said that, they both announced higher rates, talked about higher rate production on their commercial aircraft program. The military side was more conversations around higher requirements for military sales. And that's where, I think, they see their market growth opportunities, which we encourage obviously and we'll support. And then, not much talk on the space side, obviously, and with the budget influx. So the big push was on the commercial side. I think probably the biggest disappointment was no major orders on the C-series aircraft announcements from the show. But primarily on the commercial side, I think we saw a big push there.

componenttext: And working so close with Boeing, I mean, your thoughts with kind of the 737. Where would you stand in line if we did kind of redesign that aircraft? Obviously, probably re-engining is better off in the near term for you. But any comments you can add to that?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010

componenttext: I think we would look to participate heavily on that aircraft. We're a major player on the 737 right now in terms of our current chipset value, and we would look to play a role on that aircraft. And as we grow more towards Tier 2, hopefully we’ll be able to expand that. So we see lots of opportunities coming out now as they expand their production rate or get ready to do that, so we would look to enhance our roles there.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And then finally, this is a question I've asked several times before, and I'm not going to hold out on this call either. But can you comment kind of on acquisitions and what you're thinking about? And what you can kind of give comfort to maybe the investo
componenttext: And then finally, this is a question I've asked several times before, and I'm not going to hold out on this call either. But can you comment kind of on acquisitions and what you're thinking about? And what you can kind of give comfort to maybe the investor base about, not making just an acquisition, just for the sake of making an acquisition?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: We have four criteria that we've really been focusing on, and they have to be a strategic fit. It has to be in line with as part of that, just in line with our strategic goals of getting to more complex assemblies and positioning us stronger in the supply
componenttext: We have four criteria that we've really been focusing on, and they have to be a strategic fit. It has to be in line with as part of that, just in line with our strategic goals of getting to more complex assemblies and positioning us stronger in the supply chain as a Tier 2. That's one key point. The other one is that we have to be able to effectively integrate these and see the synergies that make sense.  The next one is, obviously, it has to be complementary products, whether it's another leg to the stool here, or whether it fits in well with our existing product offerings. And then finally fourth, the way we look at it is fair value. If we do the three things that precede that, then we will know by definition it’ll fair value. Tony?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And, Ed, I think in response to the question of just doing it to do it, we're not doing that. I mean, we're actively looking. We have identified on the structure side of the business gaps that we would like to fill in order to enhance our product offering
componenttext: And, Ed, I think in response to the question of just doing it to do it, we're not doing that. I mean, we're actively looking. We have identified on the structure side of the business gaps that we would like to fill in order to enhance our product offering along the engineering, more engineering growth and larger assemblies. And on the technology side, we're looking for a consolidation of the solid platform to grow from. So we're looking to grow this business, and we believe that acquisitions will play a role in that.

componenttext: I really can't say without having the specific acquisition in front of me and how that plays into the strategic growth of the company. I think I would gladly answer that question once I’ve identified and we've honed in and closed on an acquisition, and I'll clearly address that issue going forward. But without having the ability to analyze that and understand the strategic positioning of that business within our business, I think it would be imprudent to try and speculate.

componenttext: Let me just ask a quick follow-up here with regard to the third quarter, typically plays out as one of the stronger revenue and margin quarters. Did you say that you anticipated that margin would continue the current positive trends that we've witnessed over the prior few quarters?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I think the question relates to how sustainable our second quarter margins, and we are very pleased that they were up year-over-year and they were improved sequentially from some things we've done. I think when we look at the modeling, we have to factor i
componenttext: I think the question relates to how sustainable our second quarter margins, and we are very pleased that they were up year-over-year and they were improved sequentially from some things we've done. I think when we look at the modeling, we have to factor in the start-up and development costs, plus the spread of this $1 million to $1.5 million costs over the next three quarters for our capacity expansions and rationalizations and better asset utilization. So that being said -- and the environment still is somewhat stabilized in some sectors, as we talked about. I'm giving you a little backdrop on it. But what we do expect in the third quarter in terms of overall deliveries, we expect a good continued modest increase in the Large Aircraft segment and some nominal growth in the Regional and Business Aircraft segment; and also in the fixed wing military, which is C-17 is stable but F-15 and F-18. So we do see some nominal growth there. We still have the issue of where the Apache now did about $7 million this quarter, we're still looking at $6 million to $6.5 million. And without going through all the programs, we see a slight improvement in sales here in the third quarter, but not robust or a step change yet. So as we manage through our psychology, as we recognize the costs we're going to incur, we continue to work on improving our revenue mix and also continued focus on operating efficiencies to try to keep these margins not only where they are, but modestly expand them in this environment.
