[Operator Instructions]  I'd now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Chris Witty, who handles Ducommun Investor Relations. Please proceed, sir.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and welcome to Ducommun's third quarter conference call. With me today is Tony Reardon, President and CEO; and Joe Bellino, Vice President and CFO.I would now like to provide a brief Safe Harbor statement. This conference call may include for
componenttext:
Thank you, and welcome to Ducommun's third quarter conference call. With me today is Tony Reardon, President and CEO; and Joe Bellino, Vice President and CFO.
I would now like to provide a brief Safe Harbor statement. This conference call may include forward-looking statements that represent the company's expectations and beliefs concerning future events that involve risks and uncertainties and may cause the company's actual performance to be materially different from the performance indicated or implied by such statements. All statements other than statements of historical facts included in this conference call are forward-looking statements. 
Although the company believes that the expectations reflected in such forward-looking statements are reasonable, it can give no assurance that such expectations will prove to have been correct. Important factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from the company's expectations are disclosed in this conference call and in the company's annual report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2009. 
All subsequent written and oral forward-looking statements attributable to the company or persons acting on its behalf are expressly qualified in their entirety by the cautionary statements. Unless otherwise required by law, the company undertakes no obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise after the date of this conference call. I'd like to turn it over now to Ducommun's President and CEO, Tony Reardon, for a review of the operating results. Tony?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chris, and thank you, everyone for joining us today. I'd like to give you a brief overview of the quarter, after which I'll turn the call over to Joe Bellino to discuss our financial results in some detail.In the third quarter, a variety of m
componenttext:
Thank you, Chris, and thank you, everyone for joining us today. I'd like to give you a brief overview of the quarter, after which I'll turn the call over to Joe Bellino to discuss our financial results in some detail.
In the third quarter, a variety of market dynamics were in play that impacted our revenue. The global economic forces driving both the Military and Commercial aerospace markets have influenced the build rates and funding dynamics for all aspects of the industry. The DoD continues to face budget pressures, while trying to meet current requirements, and as a result, Ducommun has seen a drop in production of some Military programs, such as the C-17, defunding of NASA and the insourcing of government services. 
At the same time, we are participating in the growth of programs, such as the JSF, and providing the original equipment manufacturers with increased support for foreign military sales. Shipments for the C-17, Chinook helicopter and Apache Helicopter were delayed this quarter, with schedules pushed out into Q4 and possibly early into next year. Please note that I said scheduled slides, not cancellations. Ducommun does anticipate delivering these requirements in the next two quarters.
We also experienced a 32% decline in Engineering Services revenues, as a result of reduced government spending and order delays on a couple of current contracts. In addition, one item to note on a year-over-year revenue comparison is that the third quarter of 2009 included $5.4 million of revenue related to the UCAS development program, which was not anticipated to repeat this year. However, we do anticipate follow-on orders on this program in the future. 
Meanwhile, our Commercial business was stronger quarter-over-quarter, with higher Boeing 747, 777 and 787 sales as well as some signs of improvements in the regional jet market. The continued growth in the world air travel despite a moderating economy supports the increased build rate projections we're seeing in the large commercial transport market.  Ducommun has participation on the Boeing 737, 747, 777 and 787 Aircraft as well as the Airbus A330, A340 and A380 aircraft will help our growth in the quarters to come. However, the higher commercial sales were not enough offset the drop in the Military sales for this quarter and negatively impacted the operating margins. Contributing to the lower margins were slightly higher SG&A costs, as well as investments in R&D programs. 
We view the third quarter as marking the low point in terms of revenue for this economic cycle, with sequential gains going forward. Specifically, we see the Commercial market strengthening at a faster pace than before. And in 2011, we expect to benefit from increased shipments to support the higher build rates for the Boeing and Airbus programs. While business jet demand remains soft, the regional jet market has stabilized, and we forecast that this will lead to slightly higher revenues in the quarters to come. 
On the Military side, while the C-17 and the Apache rates are at lower levels, the rest of our programs remain solid. Specifically, we expect the JSF to continue to be funded. We see strong demands in the Blackhawk and the CH-47 helicopters, and we anticipate demands for the F-18 and F-15 spares to continue. In addition, we are analyzing the recently announced Saudi order to Boeing and Raytheon to see how it will impact the shipments going forward. The order includes 84 new F-15 Aircraft plus 70 upgrades to the F-15s, along with 72 Blackhawks and 70 Apache helicopters. 
Within our Engineering Services division, we see room for improvement in the quarters to come. We believe that our current growth strategy is taking hold, and we are refocused on several markets. Once the federal budget is released, we will be in a very solid position to support ongoing and future development programs. And we continue to bid on new opportunities, and we anticipate gradual increases in revenues going forward.
Our backlog grew to $320.9 million from $305.6 million last quarter, reflecting both new business and long-term follow-on contract awards. Due to our strengthening position as a Tier 2 supplier, we see further increases in backlog in the quarters to come, particularly given the higher Commercial build rates expected next year. Ducommun's investments are paying off in terms of our OEM relationships with increased value-added content, which is why we feel confident in saying that Ducommun is on the right path to improve operating results. Now I'd like to turn the call over to Joe Bellino to review the financial results. Joe?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tony, and good afternoon, everyone. Yesterday, we reported results for the third quarter of $0.55 per fully diluted share compared to $0.59 per fully diluted share a year ago. The third quarter 2010 results reflect the benefit of a $0.19 per di
componenttext:
Thank you, Tony, and good afternoon, everyone. Yesterday, we reported results for the third quarter of $0.55 per fully diluted share compared to $0.59 per fully diluted share a year ago. The third quarter 2010 results reflect the benefit of a $0.19 per diluted share for a change in provisions for unrecognized tax benefits. 
Third quarter sales of $99 million were 9.5% below last year's. But as we look at the segment, we saw our Commercial business increase 16%, but it was not enough to offset the 21% decline in our Military business. In our Ducommun AeroStructures business or DAS, we experienced a 9% decrease in sales. It was primarily from softer sales in Military helicopter products and Military fixed-wing programs that were partially offset by the continued growth in large Commercial Aircraft programs.
Turning to the Technology segment or DTI. We saw a 10% decrease in revenues. This was primarily as a result of a 32% decrease in Engineering Services revenues as a result of reduced government funding. Our manufactured technology product posted a 5% increase in shipments, as a result of increases in replacement radar racks and electronic components.
Turning to operating income by the business segments. DAS's operating income for the quarter, margin was 6.3% compared to 9% a year ago. This was primarily driven by lower operating income in our DAS segment, while our DTI segment continued to show improvement year-over-year.
During the quarter, we absorbed about $800,000 or one percentage point in start-up and development costs for new programs, which we had begun earlier in the year. We expect these costs to be reduced sequentially in the fourth quarter and into 2011. We look at DAS's operating income, we had operating income margins of 9.9%, and that compares to 13.6% of revenue a year ago.  It only adds some further qualifications there though. The lower operating income reflects a more unfavorable product mix year-over-year, driven by decreases in the Military fixed-wing products and Military helicopter programs. The 
bulk of the development costs I mentioned earlier, the $800,000 charge was attributable to the DAS segment. And if we adjusted that, the operating margins for the quarter would have approximated 11.5%, which compares to the 13.6% operating margin from a year ago.
Ducommun Technology or DTI's operating income increased slightly, and the operating margin percentages were 9.8% compared to 8.5%. That's 130 basis points year-over-year, and as a results from increased shipments of radar rack products, increases in technology products and continuing efficiencies that were gained from the lean manufacturing process. 
Selling, general and administrative expenses increased to 13.8% of sales in the third quarter compared to 11.5% a year ago. The increases this year were the result of higher accrued compensation expenses and continuing increased investment in product development programs. 
Turning to our business mix and backlog, during the quarter, the growth in Commercial segment and the decline in Military revenues have shifted our mix a bit. At quarter end, our business comprised of 57% Military, 42% Commercial and 1% Space. That compares to a year ago's numbers where Military was 65%; Commercial, 33%; and Space was 2%. We were pleased to see the backlogs increase sequentially to $321 million from $306 million at the end of the second quarter. We have had no major program losses. And while we have picked up firm purchase orders during the quarter for the 737, Blackhawk helicopter, Apache Helicopter and F-18, we still have experienced delays in follow-on orders for the F-15, C-17 and the Carson Helicopter programs. We expect follow-on orders for those programs to be booked in the fourth quarter or delayed to the first quarter in 2011. We are also optimistic with regard to additional and new program wins, with recent new programs ramping up in 2010. We expect increased backlogs going forward. 
Turning to the nine-month 2010 results, we are earnings for the year, year-over-year, up 17%, as our fully diluted earnings per share are $1.47. It compares to $1.27 per fully diluted share a year ago. Our first nine-month sales of $307 million are a decrease of 6% from last year's nine-month results. And this is primarily attributable to a 32% decrease in Engineering Services and lower Military helicopter programs. All of this of which has been partially offset by continued growth in the large Commercial Aircraft sector. Year-over-year Commercial sales have increased 6%, and our sales to the Military segment have decreased 13%. 
We looked at some of the business segment sales in the DAS unit, although the sales year-over-year have decreased 5%, as the solid growth in the large Commercial Aircraft was not enough to offset the lower revenues from the Military helicopter programs.
On the DTI side, the first nine months' revenues were down about 7%. They reflect the shortfalls in our aftermarket sales and Engineering Services revenues, despite significant growth in radar rack products shipments.
Turning to operating income by business segment, our operating income overall, margin was 7.2%. It compares favorably to 6.8% from the previous year. For the first nine months, the results include a favorable inventory adjustment in prior periods of $1.2 million. And these have been offset by approximately a total of $3.6 million in start-up and development costs to the first nine months, which have generated $8 million in sales. 
Just noting from last year, the first nine months of 2009, the results were negatively impacted by $5.1 million or 1.6 percentage points due to an inventory reserve related to the Eclipse bankruptcy and an inventory valuation adjustment. 
On an adjusted basis, taking into consideration those points that I made, our operating income for the first nine months of 2010 would have been $24.5 million or 8.2% of revenues compared to $27 million or 8.3% of revenues in the prior year.
Selling, general and administration is running at about 12.9% year-to-date compared to 11.6% for the comparable period last year. This was primarily a result of a couple of factors: Higher expenses related to the amortization of intangible assets; slightly higher compensation accruals; and finally, the additional investment in product development programs. Cost controls remain in effect.
Turning to liquidity and capital resources, as the normal reflection of our cash flow and business cycle, we generated nearly $7 million in positive cash flow from operations during the quarter, bringing our year-to-date cash flow from operations to a negative $3 million, but that's $6 million improvement over the comparable period in 2009. In addressing those issues, we continue to focus on effective working capital management, primarily by working to improve inventory turns and increasing our accounts receivable collections efforts. We continue to maintain a low leverage position. At quarter end, our net debt-to-capital ratio was 7%. We expect CapEx for this year to be in the range of $9 million, and that compares to slightly less than $8 million last year. The increase primarily reflects new program growth.
Now with that, I would like to ask Tony Reardon to make some additional remarks. Tony?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Joe. Before turning the call over to questions, let me just again state that while this quarter reflected delays in some Military shipments, we are actually more confident than last quarter regarding our outlook for Ducommun and believe the nec
componenttext:
Thank you, Joe. Before turning the call over to questions, let me just again state that while this quarter reflected delays in some Military shipments, we are actually more confident than last quarter regarding our outlook for Ducommun and believe the necessary growth drivers are in place to see improvement in our business going forward. While some Military headwinds remain, particularly with our sunset programs, we continue to take a disciplined approach to managing our operations. 
As stated earlier, we see a strong Commercial rebound, and the new product development program is fueling top line growth in 2011. We've always been conservative in assessing the market landscape, but we are experiencing greater traction with regard to the Commercial demand trends and believe the company's lean initiatives will result in improved bottom line results. 
We also continue to look for prudent acquisitions and have been actively engaged with several companies over this earlier part of this year. Our goal is to enhance and diversify our product offering and strengthen our role as a leading Tier 2 aerospace provider. With that, I would now like to open the call up for questions. So Lumira please?

We have not quantified it, but if you take a look at the average revenue over the last three quarters, I think you'll pretty connected with get what that looks like. I will give you some color as to what the issues were on the Chinook program. Boeing's actually retooling that program. It has been over the last quarter. We anticipate that we would pick up revenue at the end of the third quarter. And their retooling program has been pushed out a little bit. So we would look to pick some of that up in the fourth quarter. Apache was engineering change-driven initiatives, which subsequently have been cleared. And then on the C-17, it's reporting a new system, SAP, I believe, is what they're putting in there. So that had some delays in their ability to receive, and we're  working through that right now with them. So we'll see how that manifests itself in the fourth quarter.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I will. We're fully capable of manufacturing composite blade, and we're participating on this blade right now with Boeing. So they're in their initial production releases. They have developed the blade and actually flown it. So they're in their initi
componenttext: Yes, I will. We're fully capable of manufacturing composite blade, and we're participating on this blade right now with Boeing. So they're in their initial production releases. They have developed the blade and actually flown it. So they're in their initial production releases. I just got, I believe, it was Bach 3 release [ph] , which included the blade, and we are in full support on that. Unlike in the past, they have decided to make the blade themselves from a full blade. And so, we are actively supporting that and we look for an increased role, as they get into higher production rate. So I would anticipate that as we go down the path or as they go down the path to higher rate production, we'll have, hopefully, a greater role in manufacturing some support for that blade.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the composite side, I think there's one other.
componenttext: On the composite side, I think there's one other.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: SG&A was higher than normal in the quarter. Typically, I see that as a fourth quarter event with you guys. You did mention that R&D costs were up slightly, but can you kind of talk to -- are you trending above goal for the year and catching up on your acc
componenttext: SG&A was higher than normal in the quarter. Typically, I see that as a fourth quarter event with you guys. You did mention that R&D costs were up slightly, but can you kind of talk to -- are you trending above goal for the year and catching up on your accruals or what happened in the third quarter?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Ed, we're right on plan with our accruals, as it relates to -- we talked about three components, the accrued compensation expenses. It's based on what we projected at beginning of the year, for our ALP goals [ph], our annual goals, net income and ca
componenttext: Well, Ed, we're right on plan with our accruals, as it relates to -- we talked about three components, the accrued compensation expenses. It's based on what we projected at beginning of the year, for our ALP goals [ph], our annual goals, net income and cash flow. But the other expenses have been -- we continue to invest really on the technology side and research and development programs, because we feel it's essential to continue to fund and invest in the pipeline of future technology products. And then just one other one, it was really more year-to-date than for the quarter, we still have some higher levels of intangible assets amortizing those that show up in our financial numbers. Are we trending higher? A little bit higher. We're very, very I'd say frugal and really watch our discretionary expenses, and so we're really pleased that we've been able to keep a lid on them.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Are you saying the largest incremental change in a quarter-to-quarter basis progressing throughout the 2010 is really due to research and development costs? I mean, looking back to last year, I mean, it seems like it was pretty much even through the first
componenttext: Are you saying the largest incremental change in a quarter-to-quarter basis progressing throughout the 2010 is really due to research and development costs? I mean, looking back to last year, I mean, it seems like it was pretty much even through the first three quarters. Looking at this year, it looks like you stepped up incrementally despite the fact that revenues came down. So you're outpacing the sequential...

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: We have stepped up. When we saw the economic environment in '09, we put a freeze on all management salaries, and then we lifted those freeze with nominal increases this year starting in March. So some of that's flowing through. But I think we're continuin
componenttext: We have stepped up. When we saw the economic environment in '09, we put a freeze on all management salaries, and then we lifted those freeze with nominal increases this year starting in March. So some of that's flowing through. But I think we're continuing to spend a little bit more year-over-year, quarter-over-quarter on research and development costs. And that shows up in the third quarter numbers as well as the full year-to-date numbers.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: So looking at the book of business that you guys have right now, the new programs that you've won, I guess, what is, obviously, everything moving in one direction, which is up would be great. But what is the key cog, as you see it, to kind of improving yo
componenttext: So looking at the book of business that you guys have right now, the new programs that you've won, I guess, what is, obviously, everything moving in one direction, which is up would be great. But what is the key cog, as you see it, to kind of improving your business model going forward? Is it the narrow-body aircraft because of the volume? Is it the Military side of the business or is it kind of that new program growth that you saw with the regional Aircraft that's really going to move the needle, as we progress into the outer years?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's a little bit of all them. Let me start with the Military side. We do see some opportunities in the foreign military sales, and we see that market strengthening. I think that, for example, on the C-17, what we're seeing is a little leveling of
componenttext: I think it's a little bit of all them. Let me start with the Military side. We do see some opportunities in the foreign military sales, and we see that market strengthening. I think that, for example, on the C-17, what we're seeing is a little leveling of the production rate to anticipate more foreign Military sales than in the past. So we've been out supporting that. But also, the JSF program, it looks like that will continue to grow, and we have some open opportunities that we're looking at there. And then what we're seeing at, on the Commercial side, is that as the rate increases and the projections on the rate increases, in particular, on the narrow body that the tier ones are looking for support in order to be able to meet the rates. And so, we see some growth opportunities there. And as a result of what we've done with regards to higher-level assemblies, we're getting calls for higher-level assemblies to support the larger build rates. So we are optimistic on some of the programs. I think we've had some recent wins that you saw in the 777, for example, that bode well for us. And I think that there's some other opportunities that will be coming out of Boeing in Seattle that we're looking at as well.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: A follow-up to what you just said, from the Commercial side of the business, as the supply chains just get stressed as the production schedule fills up, are there share potential gains that you guys see as capacities come down at some of your competitors,
componenttext: A follow-up to what you just said, from the Commercial side of the business, as the supply chains just get stressed as the production schedule fills up, are there share potential gains that you guys see as capacities come down at some of your competitors, or how do you think about that or what could you add to that?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think more of what we're seeing is that the opportunities with the Tier 1s and the OEMs is their capacity shrinks, as they try to get to the higher rates. I think there's opportunities there. And then I think that from a competitive standpoint, I think
componenttext: I think more of what we're seeing is that the opportunities with the Tier 1s and the OEMs is their capacity shrinks, as they try to get to the higher rates. I think there's opportunities there. And then I think that from a competitive standpoint, I think we're moving into an arena that we can be more competitive with some of the foreign competition that's been in there for a higher-level assembly. So I think we're putting ourselves in a pretty good position to go forward. Having said that, I think we have work to do, and we'll continue to do that. But we're comfortable that we're seeing a lot of good opportunities, and we're working a lot of different programs across the board.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Troy Lahr from Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Troy Lahr from Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering with the margins at the AeroStructures segment, if you could maybe talk a little bit about how you view margins, kind of longer term, what is a sustainable level excluding some of these investment costs and maybe when some of the Military re
componenttext: I'm wondering with the margins at the AeroStructures segment, if you could maybe talk a little bit about how you view margins, kind of longer term, what is a sustainable level excluding some of these investment costs and maybe when some of the Military revenue starts flowing back?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I talked to you a little bit earlier in my prepared remarks to provide that on an adjusted basis, we're running at about 8.2%, 8.3%, which is comparable to last year. I think until we see in the latter half of 2011 a more dramatic expansion of the large C
componenttext: I talked to you a little bit earlier in my prepared remarks to provide that on an adjusted basis, we're running at about 8.2%, 8.3%, which is comparable to last year. I think until we see in the latter half of 2011 a more dramatic expansion of the large Commercial Aircraft cycle, we're probably operating in that range right now. And that depends really on the cycles and the level of sales that we have from quarter-to-quarter. As you heard Tony's remarks about schedule slides, that certainly we and several other industry participants in the supply chain are seeing those. So we have stronger sales than this quarter. Certainly, we would expect those to normally expand, and then those margin would be somewhat affected on lower levels of sales.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: So the 8.2% to 8.3%, you did that this quarter, you're saying excluding?
componenttext: So the 8.2% to 8.3%, you did that this quarter, you're saying excluding?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Correct, yes.
componenttext: Correct, yes.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: That EBIT margin excluding the $800 million in investment costs?
componenttext: That EBIT margin excluding the $800 million in investment costs?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: My remarks, Troy, were related to adjusted year-to-date. When we smooth all of this quarter-to-quarter variability out. And we look at next year, we think we're in that 8.2% to 8.5% operating margin percentage. And when we break that down, we really look
componenttext: My remarks, Troy, were related to adjusted year-to-date. When we smooth all of this quarter-to-quarter variability out. And we look at next year, we think we're in that 8.2% to 8.5% operating margin percentage. And when we break that down, we really look at it by business segment, too. Our DTI segment continues to expand, and it's running about 9.5%. And certainly, we'd like to get at the upper end range of the single-digit 9% or even get it to 10%. And on the AeroStructures side, as you know, historically compared to where we were, we're at lower levels now, but we're running year-to-date at about 11.5% to 12% on an adjusted basis. And so, we would see those kind of parameters by business segment going forward until there's a significant and dramatic change in our sales, which we would expect more so in the second half of next year.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And at DTI, can you may be talk about how much of the revenue shortfall was kind of budget timing issues, customer releasing orders and then how much maybe was kind of insourcing or just reduced demand? I don't know if you can quantify that, but maybe put
componenttext: And at DTI, can you may be talk about how much of the revenue shortfall was kind of budget timing issues, customer releasing orders and then how much maybe was kind of insourcing or just reduced demand? I don't know if you can quantify that, but maybe put some color around that a little bit?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think that what we saw a few, first of all, I think we projected that in the beginning of the year, we have a lower demand there just because of the insourcing. But what really impacted us, I would say, maybe I want to say close to a third of the
componenttext: Sure. I think that what we saw a few, first of all, I think we projected that in the beginning of the year, we have a lower demand there just because of the insourcing. But what really impacted us, I would say, maybe I want to say close to a third of the drop was from NASA defunding, which happened in the beginning of the quarter. And some moves around the constellations, so we were heavily engaged in that. And then some delays in just releasing because, obviously, the budget hasn't been approved month-to-month. And so some of that hit us in the quarter, and we anticipate picking up in the fourth quarter, as they move out and fund the budget.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess it was close to almost $1 million, I guess, $800,0000 for investment costs this quarter. Is that pretty much -- it seems like that's tracking to your plan, you're really not seeing any cost growth in these programs. You're pretty comfortable with
componenttext: I guess it was close to almost $1 million, I guess, $800,0000 for investment costs this quarter. Is that pretty much -- it seems like that's tracking to your plan, you're really not seeing any cost growth in these programs. You're pretty comfortable with where you're tracking?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. And if we go back, and I talked about it for the nine months year-to-date, we have $3.1 million worth of development costs that hit our cost of goods sold and affected our margins on $8 million of sales. But when we look at it, we look at it by quart
componenttext: Yes. And if we go back, and I talked about it for the nine months year-to-date, we have $3.1 million worth of development costs that hit our cost of goods sold and affected our margins on $8 million of sales. But when we look at it, we look at it by quarter, it started out in  the first quarter at $1.8 million; in the second quarter, $1.1 million; now down to $800,000. We would expect those costs to continue to abate sequentially.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Do you think any of those costs will flow through into 2011 or are you pretty much wrapping it up in the fourth quarter?
componenttext: Do you think any of those costs will flow through into 2011 or are you pretty much wrapping it up in the fourth quarter?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's probably in the first quarter, some of it. Some of them will flow, but at lower rates.
componenttext: It's probably in the first quarter, some of it. Some of them will flow, but at lower rates.

componenttext: Can you give us the sales for Boeing Commercial Aircraft? I think in the Q, you just gave us the 737 number.

componenttextpreview: Yes, we have. It is in the Q. And for the quarter, our sales to Boeing overall, we're $26.5 million.

componenttext: And that's Military in it.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Jonathan Richmond [ph] from Imperial Capital [ph].
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Jonathan Richmond [ph] from Imperial Capital [ph].

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that the first thing I think I made a statement earlier, Jonathan, that we have been very active with it in the past 18 months, looking at several companies. What we're seeing in the multiples is that they are increasing. And quite frankly,
componenttext: Well, I think that the first thing I think I made a statement earlier, Jonathan, that we have been very active with it in the past 18 months, looking at several companies. What we're seeing in the multiples is that they are increasing. And quite frankly, what I'm seeing is some of the private equity money coming in to this sector and driving up multiples across the board. So I think if you did an analysis of the last six to eight acquisitions, you'd see they're running somewhere in between, and depending on the business, 7.5x to 10x in terms of sales. So those are things that we're looking at. Those are the types of multiples that have been sold at. So obviously, we're looking for something that's more in line with a poor reset [ph].

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Here's the way we look at it, and I think this is the way we concentrate on the acquisitions. First and foremost, it's the fit for the company and how well does it take us where we want to do from a strategic standpoint. Then in the due diligence phase, m
componenttext: Here's the way we look at it, and I think this is the way we concentrate on the acquisitions. First and foremost, it's the fit for the company and how well does it take us where we want to do from a strategic standpoint. Then in the due diligence phase, much of the [indiscernible]  We take a very hard look at where we think we can get synergies out of the business and how we can reduce that multiple over a 12 to 18 month period to make it more in line with what we need to be to be successful from an accretion standpoint. So with those two factors, the higher multiples don't really scare us away as long as we see the proper synergy in place in order for us to be successful to make that acquisition accretive over a short period of time.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we would expect that we would see an increase on the F-18 sales. It is timing quite frankly.
componenttext: Yes, we would expect that we would see an increase on the F-18 sales. It is timing quite frankly.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the radar racks and I think overall. I think the program itself has had a pretty steady-state production, but it's primarily what you see in the shortfall is on the radar racks.
componenttext: On the radar racks and I think overall. I think the program itself has had a pretty steady-state production, but it's primarily what you see in the shortfall is on the radar racks.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: The fourth quarter is always the end of our business cycle. And so our free cash flow in that quarter is by far the largest amount generated. There have been quarters where we've generated anywhere from $25 million to $35 million of cash flow from operati
componenttext: The fourth quarter is always the end of our business cycle. And so our free cash flow in that quarter is by far the largest amount generated. There have been quarters where we've generated anywhere from $25 million to $35 million of cash flow from operations in the fourth quarter. So what we experienced, Jonathan, is we get a liquidation of our accounts receivable, we collect on those. We pull in inventories in the last six weeks. We try to manage those and get or try to reduce our finished goods. As so all those plus the depreciation, amortization and net income we could generate all line up pretty well to get those kinds of positive returns in the fourth quarter.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Most probably, there's some discretionary amounts in there, primarily accrued compensation expenses related to our overall performance and the level of investment we do in research and development. Your question is where do we expect it. I think where we
componenttext: Most probably, there's some discretionary amounts in there, primarily accrued compensation expenses related to our overall performance and the level of investment we do in research and development. Your question is where do we expect it. I think where we are now, those are more normalized levels, probably in the $13.5 million a quarter for the corporation as a baseline.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Mike French from Morgan Joseph.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Mike French from Morgan Joseph.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Jim Moore for Mike French. First, can you just add a little more color on the steps you're taking for improved operating performance? And then the other one is can you just talk about the opportunities in the Engineering Services a little more as
componenttext: This is Jim Moore for Mike French. First, can you just add a little more color on the steps you're taking for improved operating performance? And then the other one is can you just talk about the opportunities in the Engineering Services a little more as well?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. On the improved performance for the operations, I think first of all we're heavily involved in Lean, and we've been doing that since 2005, quite frankly. So what we'd like to say around here, the more about it, the less we know about it. But I think
componenttext: Sure. On the improved performance for the operations, I think first of all we're heavily involved in Lean, and we've been doing that since 2005, quite frankly. So what we'd like to say around here, the more about it, the less we know about it. But I think that's an important part of how we drive our business from an operational standpoint. We also see that there's opportunities for improvement, if you look at the revenue base in the fourth quarter and the third quarter. There are some Commercial programs that are essentially startups, such as like the 787 where we see opportunities to improve performance going forward, and we'll do that through efficiency challenges in Lean as we step forward. So I think that's the best analysis that I can give you, but those are the things that we have in front of us. In terms of the Engineering Services business, about a year ago right now, we've brought in a new president into that business, and he has done an excellent job of streamlining the operations and refocusing the business around specific markets. And one of them, in particular, would be the nanosatellite market. And so, we're seeing some inroads there and some development programs that they're looking at to participate as well as be more focused on their capabilities with regards to the missile defense market. So we see some opportunities out there, and as the budget comes through. And of course, we'll have to wait and see on the elections and depending how fast that budget comes through, then we'll have a better understanding of how we can improve our capabilities in that area.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And you have a follow-up question from Troy Lahr.
componenttext: And you have a follow-up question from Troy Lahr.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: With the changes that you're talking about on Boeing, on the Apache, do you still expect that to be kind of about a $25 million a year business for you guys, or could that dip as more of the production, it stays in house with Boeing?
componenttext: With the changes that you're talking about on Boeing, on the Apache, do you still expect that to be kind of about a $25 million a year business for you guys, or could that dip as more of the production, it stays in house with Boeing?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that probably over time, we'll see a dip in that, Troy. I don't have the projections going forward. I think that what we're seeing obviously is that, first of all, the new rotor blades coming online and we're participating on that, as I said
componenttext: Yes, I think that probably over time, we'll see a dip in that, Troy. I don't have the projections going forward. I think that what we're seeing obviously is that, first of all, the new rotor blades coming online and we're participating on that, as I said so. That's an important program for us, and we're certainly keen on improving our position on that play. But we will see, I think, a reduction in the existing blade over time. However, I think there are a number of customers out there on the foreign Military side which will stay with the existing blades, so we would see continued production on that. And then the tail rotors at this point in time have not been moved to composites, although I think that's in the wind. And we'll be supporting that going forward. So I would look at 2011 and '12 and probably see some slight reduction in build rates, as we go out. But at this time, I don't have those numbers. So we're actually in the final throes of working for them on rates right now.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And on the F-35, given some of the production delays that might be coming in, what we've already seen, do you think that there's enough F-35 revenue near term to offset some of the F-22 wind down?
componenttext: And on the F-35, given some of the production delays that might be coming in, what we've already seen, do you think that there's enough F-35 revenue near term to offset some of the F-22 wind down?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, for us I think that for sure in that case. F-22 for us was that not a big program. So that's an easy part for us, but in terms of the JSF growth, I think we have some opportunities on that, that we are working on. And I think that from a near-term st
componenttext: Yes, for us I think that for sure in that case. F-22 for us was that not a big program. So that's an easy part for us, but in terms of the JSF growth, I think we have some opportunities on that, that we are working on. And I think that from a near-term standpoint, I'd say that next year, if that's a near term, I'm not sure that we would have very high revenue on that program. But I think out in '12 and '13, I think we'll have things pick up throughout this line.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then on Chinook, should we still think about that as -- I was thinking that, that was kind of a $15 million to $20 million a year program. Is that kind of in the range how we should still be thinking about that once you kind of ramp up and they see hi
componenttext: And then on Chinook, should we still think about that as -- I was thinking that, that was kind of a $15 million to $20 million a year program. Is that kind of in the range how we should still be thinking about that once you kind of ramp up and they see higher build rates, or no?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think so, Troy. We're anticipating that they're going to go to slightly higher build rate going forward and that we've been hampered with their retooling. We actually retooled as well. So that we could help them get to higher rates on the blades. S
componenttext: Yes, I think so, Troy. We're anticipating that they're going to go to slightly higher build rate going forward and that we've been hampered with their retooling. We actually retooled as well. So that we could help them get to higher rates on the blades. So we're working through that. So I would anticipate that we would stay pretty close to that level in that range quite frankly.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then on C-17, I've always kind of viewed that as maybe a $40 million a year program. Does that drop to maybe $30 million or is it $35 million? How should we think about C-17 as you transition and as they lower production over the next, say, few years?
componenttext: And then on C-17, I've always kind of viewed that as maybe a $40 million a year program. Does that drop to maybe $30 million or is it $35 million? How should we think about C-17 as you transition and as they lower production over the next, say, few years?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would use that $30 million number. Quite frankly, we haven't settled down next year with Boeing and that's one of the negotiations that we're sitting through right now. And I think they have some issues that they have to work through with regard to
componenttext: Yes, I would use that $30 million number. Quite frankly, we haven't settled down next year with Boeing and that's one of the negotiations that we're sitting through right now. And I think they have some issues that they have to work through with regard to the foreign Military sales and how that will impact it. We would look at that in that range. So above that drop, they're going to drop their production rate and aiming to get to a steady state volume. They're running at about 15 shipsets right now. They'd be lower than that in 2011 and '12, and then we'll see how the foreign Military sales pick up going forward. So the $30 million range to a little less than that would be probably prudent.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And you have a follow-up question from Edward Marshall.
componenttext: And you have a follow-up question from Edward Marshall.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Two follow up questions for me. One, you talked about your collection services. You also talked about improving it and inventory turns. And I was wondering if you can kind of discuss your goals both this year in kind of the longer-term trend, is what you
componenttext: Two follow up questions for me. One, you talked about your collection services. You also talked about improving it and inventory turns. And I was wondering if you can kind of discuss your goals both this year in kind of the longer-term trend, is what you expect from both of those metrics?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ed, on the collection services, we're talking about accounts receivable collection. We have an internal metric that we're holding our organization accountable to. We try to get at least, and we look at the aging of our accounts receivable, 85% or more of
componenttext: Ed, on the collection services, we're talking about accounts receivable collection. We have an internal metric that we're holding our organization accountable to. We try to get at least, and we look at the aging of our accounts receivable, 85% or more of our receivables should either be current or current plus five days. We fortunately don't have any significant credit risk or credit default situations here, because the customer set is pretty financially secure. We go and look at the inventory. It's a little bit more complex because we have the composition of a variety of things, raw material and a lot of work in process by nature of our business and some finished goods. But in terms of turns, we look at somewhere between in excess of 4.2x, 4.3x a year are our goals. And I think traditionally, we've run less than 4x and so part of our Lean Manufacturing Six Sigma and our focus on operation and working with our supply chain management group. We're all working very hard currently and then next year, despite all these schedule slides to enhance our returns, inventory turn.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then kind of in another direction and looking at -- you talked about acquisitions and multiples going higher. And I guess maybe looking at it from another angle, with multiples increasing, I mean, has it been kind of the Board's decision, maybe in you

My first question would be what are those programs and how does that sort of ramp down over the next five quarters? And you also talked about a sales mix and lower volume, is that mostly just plant utilization issues or is that some of the Military programs had better margin profiles with it?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Donald, on the multiple question, you asked about what kind of program it is, it's a multitude of programs, and it's both on the DAS side and our Technology side. Programs, say for RUAG, Bombardier, or what we call a racer program for the F-16, for Raythe
componenttext: Donald, on the multiple question, you asked about what kind of program it is, it's a multitude of programs, and it's both on the DAS side and our Technology side. Programs, say for RUAG, Bombardier, or what we call a racer program for the F-16, for Raytheon with radar racks, there's a new Embraer program we announced, where we're in tooling stages. There's a couple of other customers, Shenyang Aircraft and others. So it's a multitude of those, and we've been asked the question before but don't you always have those? We do but because of our focus on bringing on many new products in line to replace some of our sunset programs that we've commented about, our activity in the last couple of years has been greater, and our success in securing these programs has been greater than we have historically experienced. It's just at a greater rate. And so we're having to -- the way the accounting is to take those expenses as we ramp up these programs. So that's the impact, and it flows through our gross margin.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, Donald, it's both. For example, the $800,000 we referenced is for programs that we're on. We do have some SG&A funding for development programs that we have in-house that are primarily on our technology side of our business. So one good example o
componenttext: I think, Donald, it's both. For example, the $800,000 we referenced is for programs that we're on. We do have some SG&A funding for development programs that we have in-house that are primarily on our technology side of our business. So one good example of an R&D program that came out as a win is we announced the capture of the engine starts, which are on the 737 program on our technology side this year. And that was a pure R&D program that we fund in-house, and we have programs like that, that we're working on currently, not necessarily switches but programs where we have a selected market, and we have identified the market, and we run through what we call a gate system to identify the R&D project. And then as we fund it, make sure that we solidify the marketing base before we proceed.

componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to Third Quarter 2010 Ducommun Earnings Conference Call. My name is Lumida, and I'll be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions]  I'd now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Chris Witty, who handles Ducommun Investor Relations. Please proceed, sir.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and welcome to Ducommun's third quarter conference call. With me today is Tony Reardon, President and CEO; and Joe Bellino, Vice President and CFO.I would now like to provide a brief Safe Harbor statement. This conference call may include for
componenttext:
Thank you, and welcome to Ducommun's third quarter conference call. With me today is Tony Reardon, President and CEO; and Joe Bellino, Vice President and CFO.
I would now like to provide a brief Safe Harbor statement. This conference call may include forward-looking statements that represent the company's expectations and beliefs concerning future events that involve risks and uncertainties that may cause the company's actual performance to be materially different from the performance indicated or implied by such statements. All statements other than statements of historical facts included in this conference call are forward-looking statements. 
Although the company believes that the expectations reflected in such forward-looking statements are reasonable, it can give no assurance that such expectations will prove to have been correct. Important factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from the company's expectations are disclosed in this conference call and in the company's annual report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2009. 
All subsequent written and oral forward-looking statements attributable to the company or persons acting on its behalf are expressly qualified in their entirety by the cautionary statements. Unless otherwise required by law, the company undertakes no obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise after the date of this conference call. I'd like to turn it over now to Ducommun's President and CEO, Tony Reardon, for a review of the operating results. Tony?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chris, and thank you, everyone for joining us today. I'd like to give you a brief overview of the quarter, after which I'll turn the call over to Joe Bellino to discuss our financial results in some detail.In the third quarter, a variety of m
componenttext:
Thank you, Chris, and thank you, everyone for joining us today. I'd like to give you a brief overview of the quarter, after which I'll turn the call over to Joe Bellino to discuss our financial results in some detail.
In the third quarter, a variety of market dynamics were in play that impacted our revenue. The global economic forces driving both the Military and Commercial aerospace markets have influenced the build rates and funding dynamics for all aspects of the industry. The DoD continues to face budget pressures, while trying to meet current requirements, and as a result, Ducommun has seen a drop in production of some Military programs, such as the C-17, defunding of NASA and the insourcing of government services. 
At the same time, we are participating in the growth of programs, such as the JSF, and providing the original equipment manufacturers with increased support for foreign military sales. Shipments for the C-17, Chinook helicopter and Apache Helicopter were delayed this quarter, with schedules pushed out into Q4 and possibly early into next year. Please note that I said scheduled slides, not cancellations. Ducommun does anticipate delivering these requirements in the next two quarters.
We also experienced a 32% decline in Engineering Services revenues, as a result of reduced government spending and order delays on a couple of current contracts. In addition, one item to note on a year-over-year revenue comparison is that the third quarter of 2009 included $5.4 million of revenue related to the UCAS development program, which was not anticipated to repeat this year. However, we do anticipate follow-on orders on this program in the future. 
Meanwhile, our Commercial business was stronger quarter-over-quarter, with higher Boeing 747, 777 and 787 sales, as well as some signs of improvements in the regional jet market. The continued growth in the world air travel despite a moderating economy supports the increased build rate projections we're seeing in the large commercial transport market.  Ducommun’s participation on the Boeing 737, 747, 777 and 787 Aircraft as well as the Airbus A330, A340 and A380 aircraft will help our growth in the quarters to come. However, the higher commercial sales were not enough offset the drop in the Military sales for this quarter and negatively impacted the operating margins. Contributing to the lower margins were slightly higher SG&A costs, as well as investments in R&D programs. 
We view the third quarter as marking the low point in terms of revenue for this economic cycle, with sequential gains going forward. Specifically, we see the Commercial market strengthening at a faster pace than before. And in 2011, we expect to benefit from increased shipments to support the higher build rates for the Boeing and Airbus programs. While business jet demand remains soft, the regional jet market has stabilized, and we forecast that this will lead to slightly higher revenues in the quarters to come. 
On the Military side, while the C-17 and the Apache rates are at lower levels, the rest of our programs remain solid. Specifically, we expect the JSF to continue to be funded. We see strong demands in the Blackhawk and the CH-47 helicopters, and we anticipate demands for the F-18 and F-15 spares to continue. In addition, we are analyzing the recently announced Saudi order to Boeing and Raytheon to see how it will impact the shipments going forward. The order includes 84 new F-15 Aircraft plus 70 upgrades to the F-15s, along with 72 Blackhawks and 70 Apache helicopters. 
Within our Engineering Services division, we see room for improvement in the quarters to come. We believe that our current growth strategy is taking hold, and we are refocused on several markets. Once the federal budget is released, we will be in a very solid position to support ongoing and future development programs. And we continue to bid on new opportunities, and we anticipate gradual increases in revenues going forward.
Our backlog grew to $320.9 million from $305.6 million last quarter, reflecting both new business and long-term follow-on contract awards. Due to our strengthening position as a Tier 2 supplier, we see further increases in backlog in the quarters to come, particularly given the higher Commercial build rates expected next year. Ducommun's investments are paying off in terms of our OEM relationships with increased value-added content, which is why we feel confident in saying that Ducommun is on the right path to improve operating results. Now I'd like to turn the call over to Joe Bellino to review the financial results. Joe?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tony, and good afternoon, everyone. Yesterday, we reported results for the third quarter of $0.55 per fully diluted share compared to $0.59 per fully diluted share a year ago. The third quarter 2010 results reflect a benefit of a $0.19 per dilu
componenttext:
Thank you, Tony, and good afternoon, everyone. Yesterday, we reported results for the third quarter of $0.55 per fully diluted share compared to $0.59 per fully diluted share a year ago. The third quarter 2010 results reflect a benefit of a $0.19 per diluted share for a change in provisions for unrecognized tax benefits. 
Third quarter sales of $99 million were 9.5% below last year's. But as we look at the segment, we saw our Commercial business increase 16%, but it was not enough to offset the 21% decline in our Military business. In our Ducommun AeroStructures business or DAS, we experienced a 9% decrease in sales. It was primarily from softer sales in Military helicopter products and Military fixed-wing programs that were partially offset by the continued growth in large Commercial Aircraft programs.
Turning to the Technology segment or DTI. We saw a 10% decrease in revenues. This was primarily as a result of a 32% decrease in Engineering Services revenues as a result of reduced government funding. Our manufactured technology products posted a 5% increase in shipments, as a result of increases in replacement radar racks and electronic components.
Turning to operating income by the business segments. DAS's operating income for the quarter, margin was 6.3% compared to 9% a year ago. This was primarily driven by lower operating income in our DAS segment, while our DTI segment continued to show improvement year-over-year.
During the quarter, we absorbed about $800,000 or one percentage point in start-up and development costs for new programs, which we had begun earlier in the year. We expect these costs to be reduced sequentially in the fourth quarter and into 2011. We look at DAS's operating income, we had operating income margins of 9.9%, and that compares to 13.6% of revenue a year ago.  I want to add some further qualifications there though. The lower operating income reflects a more unfavorable product mix year-over-year, driven by decreases in the Military fixed-wing products and Military helicopter programs. The bulk of the development costs I mentioned earlier, the $800,000 charge was attributable to the DAS segment. And if we adjusted that, the operating margins for the quarter would have approximated 11.5%, which compares to the 13.6% operating margin from a year ago.
Ducommun Technology or DTI's operating income increased slightly, and the operating margin percentages were 9.8% compared to 8.5%. That's 130 basis points year-over-year, and is a result from increased shipments of radar rack products, increases in technology products and continuing efficiencies that were gained from the lean manufacturing process. 
Selling, general and administrative expenses increased to 13.8% of sales in the third quarter compared to 11.5% a year ago. The increases this year were the result of higher accrued compensation expenses and continuing increased investment in product development programs. 
Turning to our business mix and backlog, during the quarter, the growth in Commercial segment and the decline in Military revenues has shifted our mix a bit. At quarter end, our business comprised of 57% Military, 42% Commercial and 1% Space. That compares to a year ago's numbers where Military was 65%; Commercial, 33%; and Space was 2%. We were pleased to see the backlogs increase sequentially to $321 million from $306 million at the end of the second quarter. We have had no major program losses. And while we have picked up firm purchase orders during the quarter for the 737, Blackhawk helicopter, Apache Helicopter and F-18, we still have experienced delays in follow-on orders for the F-15, C-17 and the Carson Helicopter programs. We expect follow-on orders for those programs to be booked in the fourth quarter or delayed to the first quarter in 2011. We are also optimistic with regard to additional new program wins, with recent new programs ramping up in 2010. We expect increased backlogs going forward. 
Turning to the nine-month 2010 results, we -- our earnings for the year, year-over-year, up 17%, as our fully diluted earnings per share are $1.47. It compares to $1.27 per fully diluted share a year ago. Our first nine-month sales of $307 million are a decrease of 6% from last year's nine-month results. And this is primarily attributable to a 32% decrease in Engineering Services and lower Military helicopter programs. All of this of which has been partially offset by continued growth in the large Commercial Aircraft sector. Year-over-year Commercial sales have increased 6%, and our sales to the Military segment have decreased 13%. 
If we look at some of the business segment sales in the DAS unit, the sales year-over-year have decreased 5%, as the solid growth in the large Commercial Aircraft was not enough to offset the lower revenues from the Military helicopter programs.
On the DTI side, the first nine months' revenues were down about 7%. They reflect the shortfalls in our aftermarket sales and Engineering Services revenues, despite significant growth in radar rack product shipments.
Turning to our operating income by business segment, our operating income overall, margin was 7.2%. It compares favorably to 6.8% from the previous year. For the first nine months, the results include a favorable inventory adjustment in prior periods of $1.2 million. And these have been offset by approximately a total of $3.6 million in start-up and development costs to the first nine months, which have generated $8 million in sales. 
Just noting from last year, the first nine months of 2009, the results were negatively impacted by $5.1 million or 1.6 percentage points due to an inventory reserve related to the Eclipse bankruptcy and an inventory valuation adjustment. 
On an adjusted basis, taking into consideration those points that I made, our operating income for the first nine months of 2010 would have been $24.5 million or 8.2% of revenues compared to $27 million or 8.3% of revenues in the prior year.
Selling, general and administration is running at about 12.9% year-to-date compared to 11.6% for the comparable period last year. This was primarily a result of a couple of factors: higher expenses related to the amortization of intangible assets; slightly higher compensation accruals; and finally, the additional investment in product development programs. Cost controls remain in effect.
Turning to liquidity and capital resources, as a normal reflection of our cash flow and business cycle, we generated nearly $7 million in positive cash flow from operations during the quarter, bringing our year-to-date cash flow from operations to a negative $3 million, but that's $6 million improvement over the comparable period in 2009. In addressing those issues, we continue to focus on effective working capital management, primarily by working to improve inventory turns and increasing our accounts receivable collections efforts. We continue to maintain a low leverage position; at quarter end, our net debt-to-capital ratio was 7%. We expect CapEx for this year to be in the range of $9 million, and that compares to slightly less than $8 million last year. The increase primarily reflects new program growth.
Now with that, I would like to ask Tony Reardon to make some additional remarks. Tony?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Joe. Before turning the call over to questions, let me just again state that while this quarter reflected delays in some Military shipments, we are actually more confident than last quarter regarding our outlook for Ducommun and believe the nec
componenttext:
Thank you, Joe. Before turning the call over to questions, let me just again state that while this quarter reflected delays in some Military shipments, we are actually more confident than last quarter regarding our outlook for Ducommun and believe the necessary growth drivers are in place to see improvement in our business going forward. While some Military headwinds remain, particularly with our sunset programs, we continue to take a disciplined approach to managing our operations. 
As stated earlier, we see a strong Commercial rebound, and the new product development program is fueling top line growth in 2011. We've always been conservative in assessing the market landscape, but we are experiencing greater traction with regard to the Commercial demand trends and believe the company's lean initiatives will result in improved bottom line results. 
We also continue to look for prudent acquisitions and have been actively engaged with several companies over this earlier part of this year. Our goal is to enhance and diversify our product offering and strengthen our role as a leading Tier 2 aerospace provider. With that, I would now like to open the call up for questions. So Lumira please?

componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, Ed. This is Tony. We have not quantified it, but if you take a look at the average revenue over the last three quarters, I think you get a pretty good idea of what that looks like. I will give you some color as to what the issues were on t
componenttext: Good afternoon, Ed. This is Tony. We have not quantified it, but if you take a look at the average revenue over the last three quarters, I think you get a pretty good idea of what that looks like. I will give you some color as to what the issues were on the Chinook program. Boeing's actually retooling that program. It has been over the last quarter. We anticipated that we would pick up revenue at the end of the third quarter. And their tooling program has been pushed out a little bit. So we would look to pick some of that up in the fourth quarter. Apache was engineering change-driven initiatives, which subsequently have been cleared. And then on the C-17, it's reporting a new system, SAP, I believe, is what they're putting in there. So that had some delays in their ability to receive, and we're  working through that right now with them. So we'll see how that manifests itself in the fourth quarter.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: The Apache, you mentioned that they're retooling that blade to be a composite blade, are you guys capable of doing a composite blade? My understanding is maybe the Carson Helicopter blade is a carbon fiber blade. Can you kind of talk about that?
componenttext: The Apache, you mentioned that they're retooling that blade to be a composite blade, are you guys capable of doing a composite blade? My understanding is maybe the Carson Helicopter blade is a carbon fiber blade. Can you kind of talk about that?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I will. We're fully capable of manufacturing a composite blade, and we're participating on this blade right now with Boeing. So they're in their initial production releases. They have developed the blade and actually flown it. So they're in their ini
componenttext: Yes, I will. We're fully capable of manufacturing a composite blade, and we're participating on this blade right now with Boeing. So they're in their initial production releases. They have developed the blade and actually flown it. So they're in their initial production releases. I just got, I believe, it was Bach 3 release [ph] , which included the blade, and we are in full support on that. Unlike in the past, they have decided to make the blade themselves from a full blade. And so, we are actively supporting that and we look for an increased role, as they get into higher production rate. So I would anticipate that as we go down the path or as they go down the path to higher rate production, we'll have, hopefully a greater role in manufacturing some support for that blade.
