componenttext: SG&A was higher than normal in the quarter. Typically, I see that as a fourth quarter event with you guys. You did mention that R&D costs were up slightly, but can you kind of talk to -- are you trending above goal for the year and catching up on your accruals or what happened in the third quarter?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Ed, we're right on plan with our accruals, as it relates to -- we talked about three components, accrued compensation expenses. It's based on what we projected at beginning of the year, for our ALP goals [ph], our annual goals, net income and cash f
componenttext: Well, Ed, we're right on plan with our accruals, as it relates to -- we talked about three components, accrued compensation expenses. It's based on what we projected at beginning of the year, for our ALP goals [ph], our annual goals, net income and cash flow. But the other expenses have been -- we continue to invest really on the technology side and research and development programs, because we feel it's essential to continue to fund and invest in the pipeline of future technology products. And then just one other one, it was really more year-to-date than for the quarter, we still have some higher levels of intangible assets amortizing those that show up in our financial numbers. Are we trending higher? A little bit higher. We're very, very I'd say frugal and really watch our discretionary expenses, and so we're really pleased that we've been able to keep a lid on them.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Are you saying the largest incremental change in a quarter-to-quarter basis progressing throughout the 2010 is really due to research and development costs? I mean, looking back to last year, I mean, it seems like it was pretty much even through the first
componenttext: Are you saying the largest incremental change in a quarter-to-quarter basis progressing throughout the 2010 is really due to research and development costs? I mean, looking back to last year, I mean, it seems like it was pretty much even through the first three quarters. Looking at this year, it looks like you stepped up incrementally despite the fact that revenues came down. So you're outpacing the sequential...

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: We have stepped up. When we saw the difficult economic environment in '09, we put a freeze on all management salaries, and then we lifted those freeze with nominal increases this year starting in March. So some of that's flowing through. But I think we're
componenttext: We have stepped up. When we saw the difficult economic environment in '09, we put a freeze on all management salaries, and then we lifted those freeze with nominal increases this year starting in March. So some of that's flowing through. But I think we're continuing to spend a little bit more year-over-year, quarter-over-quarter on research and development costs. And that shows up in the third quarter numbers as well as the full year-to-date numbers.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: So looking at the book of business that you guys have right now, the new programs that you've won, I guess, what is, obviously, everything moving in one direction, which is up would be great. But what is the key cog, as you see it, to kind of improving yo
componenttext: So looking at the book of business that you guys have right now, the new programs that you've won, I guess, what is, obviously, everything moving in one direction, which is up would be great. But what is the key cog, as you see it, to kind of improving your business model going forward? Is it the narrow-body aircraft because of the volume? Is it the Military side of the business or is it kind of that new program growth that you saw with the regional aircraft that's really going to move the needle, as we progress into the outer years?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's a little bit of all them. Let me start with the Military side. We do see some opportunities in the foreign military sales, and we see that market strengthening. I think that, for example, on the C-17, what we're seeing is a little leveling of
componenttext: I think it's a little bit of all them. Let me start with the Military side. We do see some opportunities in the foreign military sales, and we see that market strengthening. I think that, for example, on the C-17, what we're seeing is a little leveling of the production rate to anticipate more foreign Military sales than in the past. So we've been out supporting that. But also, the JSF program, it looks like that will continue to grow, and we have some open opportunities that we're looking at there. And then what we're seeing at, on the Commercial side, is that as the rate increases and the projections on the rate increases, in particular, on the narrow body that the tier ones are looking for support in order to be able to meet the rates. And so, we see some growth opportunities there. And as a result of what we've done with regards to higher-level assemblies, we're getting pulls for higher-level assemblies to support the larger build rates. So we are optimistic on some of the programs. I think we've had some recent wins that you saw in the 777, for example, that bode well for us. And I think that there's some other opportunities that will be coming out of Boeing in Seattle that we're looking at as well.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: A follow-up to what you just said, from the Commercial side of the business, as the supply chains starts to get stressed as the production schedule fills up, are there share potential gains that you guys see as capacities come down at some of your competi
componenttext: A follow-up to what you just said, from the Commercial side of the business, as the supply chains starts to get stressed as the production schedule fills up, are there share potential gains that you guys see as capacities come down at some of your competitors, or how do you think about that or what could you add to that?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think more of what we're seeing is that the opportunities with the Tier 1s and the OEMs is their capacity shrinks, as they try to get to the higher rates. I think there's opportunities there. And then I think that from a competitive standpoint, I think
componenttext: I think more of what we're seeing is that the opportunities with the Tier 1s and the OEMs is their capacity shrinks, as they try to get to the higher rates. I think there's opportunities there. And then I think that from a competitive standpoint, I think we're moving into an arena that we can be more competitive with some of the foreign competition that's been in there for a higher-level assembly. So I think we're putting ourselves in a pretty good position to go forward. Having said that, I think we have work to do, and we'll continue to do that. But we're comfortable that we're seeing a lot of good opportunities, and we're working a lot of different programs across the board.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Troy Lahr from Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Troy Lahr from Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering with the margins at the AeroStructures segment, if you could maybe talk a little bit about how you view margins, kind of longer term, what is a sustainable level excluding some of these investment costs and maybe when some of the Military re
componenttext: I'm wondering with the margins at the AeroStructures segment, if you could maybe talk a little bit about how you view margins, kind of longer term, what is a sustainable level excluding some of these investment costs and maybe when some of the Military revenue starts flowing back?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I talked to you a little bit earlier in my prepared remarks, Troy, that on an adjusted basis, we're running at about 8.2%, 8.3%, which is comparable to last year. I think until we see in the latter half of 2011 a more dramatic expansion of the large Comme
componenttext: I talked to you a little bit earlier in my prepared remarks, Troy, that on an adjusted basis, we're running at about 8.2%, 8.3%, which is comparable to last year. I think until we see in the latter half of 2011 a more dramatic expansion of the large Commercial Aircraft cycle, we're probably operating in that range right now. And that depends really on the cycles and the level of sales that we have from quarter-to-quarter. As you heard Tony's remarks about schedule slides, that certainly we and several other industry participants in the supply chain are seeing those. So we have stronger sales than this quarter. Certainly, we would expect those to nominally expand, and then those margins to be somewhat affected on lower levels of sales.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: So the 8.2% to 8.3%, you did that this quarter, you're saying excluding?
componenttext: So the 8.2% to 8.3%, you did that this quarter, you're saying excluding?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Correct, yes.
componenttext: Correct, yes.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: That EBIT margin excluding the $800 million in investment costs?
componenttext: That EBIT margin excluding the $800 million in investment costs?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: My remarks, Troy, were related to adjusted year-to-date. When we smooth all of this quarter-to-quarter variability out. And we look at next year, we think we're in that 8.2% to 8.5% operating margin percentage. And when we break that down, we really look
componenttext: My remarks, Troy, were related to adjusted year-to-date. When we smooth all of this quarter-to-quarter variability out. And we look at next year, we think we're in that 8.2% to 8.5% operating margin percentage. And when we break that down, we really look at it by business segment, too. Our DTI segment continues to expand, and it's running about 9.5%. And certainly, we'd like to get at the upper range of the single-digit 9% or even get it to 10%. And on the AeroStructures side, as you know, historically compared to where we were, we're at lower levels now, but we're running year-to-date at about 11.5% to 12% on an adjusted basis. And so, we would see those kind of parameters by business segment going forward until there's a significant and dramatic change in our sales, which we would expect more so in the second half of next year.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And at DTI, can you maybe talk about how much of the revenue shortfall was kind of budget timing issues, customer releasing orders and then how much maybe was kind of insourcing or just reduced demand? I don't know if you can quantify that, but maybe put
componenttext: And at DTI, can you maybe talk about how much of the revenue shortfall was kind of budget timing issues, customer releasing orders and then how much maybe was kind of insourcing or just reduced demand? I don't know if you can quantify that, but maybe put some color around that a little bit?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think that what we saw if you, first of all, I think we projected that in the beginning of the year, that we would have a lower demand there just because of the insourcing. But what really impacted us, I would say, maybe I want to say close to a t
componenttext: Sure. I think that what we saw if you, first of all, I think we projected that in the beginning of the year, that we would have a lower demand there just because of the insourcing. But what really impacted us, I would say, maybe I want to say close to a third of the drop was from NASA defunding, which happened in the beginning of the quarter. And some moves around the constellations, so we were heavily engaged in that. And then some delays in just releasing because, obviously, the budget hasn't been approved month-to-month. And so some of that hit us in the quarter, and we anticipate picking up some of that in the fourth quarter, as they move out and fund the budget.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess it was close to almost $1 million, I guess, $800,0000 for investment costs this quarter. Is that pretty much -- it seems like that's tracking to your plan, you're really not seeing any cost growth on these programs. You're pretty comfortable with
componenttext: I guess it was close to almost $1 million, I guess, $800,0000 for investment costs this quarter. Is that pretty much -- it seems like that's tracking to your plan, you're really not seeing any cost growth on these programs. You're pretty comfortable with where you're tracking?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. And if we go back, and I talked about it for the nine months year-to-date, we have $3.1 million worth of development costs that hit our cost of goods sold and affected our margins on $8 million of sales. But when we look at it, we look at it by quart
componenttext: Yes. And if we go back, and I talked about it for the nine months year-to-date, we have $3.1 million worth of development costs that hit our cost of goods sold and affected our margins on $8 million of sales. But when we look at it, we look at it by quarter, it started out the first quarter at $1.8 million; the second quarter, $1.1 million; now down to $800,000. We would expect those costs to continue to abate sequentially.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Do you think any of those costs flow through into 2011 or are you pretty much wrapping it up in the fourth quarter?
componenttext: Do you think any of those costs flow through into 2011 or are you pretty much wrapping it up in the fourth quarter?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's probably in the first quarter, some of it. Some of them will flow, but at lower rates.
componenttext: It's probably in the first quarter, some of it. Some of them will flow, but at lower rates.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you give us the sales for Boeing Commercial Aircraft? I think in the Q, you just gave us the 737 number.
componenttext: Can you give us the sales for Boeing Commercial Aircraft? I think in the Q, you just gave us the 737 number.

componenttext: Yes, we have. It is in the Q. And for the quarter, our sales to Boeing overall we $26.5 million.

componenttext: And that's Military in it.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010

componenttext: That was approximately, I would say the number is about $20 million for the quarter, was our sales to Boeing Commercial Aircraft.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Jonathan Richmond [ph] from Imperial Capital [ph].
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Jonathan Richmond [ph] from Imperial Capital [ph].

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that the first thing I think, I made a statement earlier, Jonathan, that we have been very active in the last 18 months, looking at several companies. What we're seeing in the multiples is that they are increasing. And quite frankly, what I'
componenttext: Well, I think that the first thing I think, I made a statement earlier, Jonathan, that we have been very active in the last 18 months, looking at several companies. What we're seeing in the multiples is that they are increasing. And quite frankly, what I'm seeing is some of the private equity money coming in to this sector and driving up multiples across the board. So I think if you did an analysis of the last six to eight acquisitions, you'd see they're running somewhere between, and depending on the business, 7.5x to 10x in terms of sales. So those are things that we're looking at. Those are the types of multiples that have been sold at. So obviously, we're looking for something that's more in line with where we sit.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Here's the way we look at it, and I think this is the way we concentrate on the acquisitions. First and foremost, it's the fit for the company and how well does it take us where we want to do from our strategic standpoint. Then in the due diligence phase,
componenttext: Here's the way we look at it, and I think this is the way we concentrate on the acquisitions. First and foremost, it's the fit for the company and how well does it take us where we want to do from our strategic standpoint. Then in the due diligence phase, much of the [indiscernible] DAS New York, we take a very hard look at where we think we can get synergies out of the business and how we can reduce that multiple over a 12 to 18 month period to make it more in line with what we need to be to be successful from an accretion standpoint. So with those two factors, the higher multiples don't really scare us away as long as we see the proper synergy in place in order for us to be successful to make that acquisition accretive over a short period of time.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we would expect that we would see an increase on the F-18 sales. It is timing quite frankly.
componenttext: Yes, we would expect that we would see an increase on the F-18 sales. It is timing quite frankly.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the radar racks and I think overall. I think the program itself has had a pretty steady-state production, but it's primarily what you see in the shortfall is on the radar racks.
componenttext: On the radar racks and I think overall. I think the program itself has had a pretty steady-state production, but it's primarily what you see in the shortfall is on the radar racks.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: The fourth quarter is always the end of our business cycle. And so our free cash flow in that quarter is by far the largest amount generated. There have been quarters where we've generated anywhere from $25 million to $35 million of cash flow from operati
componenttext: The fourth quarter is always the end of our business cycle. And so our free cash flow in that quarter is by far the largest amount generated. There have been quarters where we've generated anywhere from $25 million to $35 million of cash flow from operations in the fourth quarter. So what we experienced, Jonathan, is we get a liquidation of our accounts receivable, we collect on those. We pull in inventories the last six weeks. We try to manage those and get our -- try to reduce our finished goods. As so all those plus the depreciation, amortization and net income we could generate all line up pretty well to get those kinds of positive returns in the fourth quarter.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Most probably, there's some discretionary amounts in there, primarily accrued compensation expenses related to our overall performance and the level of investment we do in research and development. Your question is where do we expect it. I think where we
componenttext: Most probably, there's some discretionary amounts in there, primarily accrued compensation expenses related to our overall performance and the level of investment we do in research and development. Your question is where do we expect it. I think where we are now, those are more normalized levels, probably in the $13.5 million a quarter for the corporation as a baseline.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Mike French from Morgan Joseph.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Mike French from Morgan Joseph.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Jim Moore for Mike French. First, can you just add a little more color on these steps you're taking for improved operating performance? And then the other one is can you just talk about the opportunities in the Engineering Services a little more a
componenttext: This is Jim Moore for Mike French. First, can you just add a little more color on these steps you're taking for improved operating performance? And then the other one is can you just talk about the opportunities in the Engineering Services a little more as well?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. On the improved performance for the operations, I think first of all we're heavily involved in Lean, and we've been doing that since 2005, quite frankly. So what we like to say around here, the more about it, the less we know about it. But I think t
componenttext: Sure. On the improved performance for the operations, I think first of all we're heavily involved in Lean, and we've been doing that since 2005, quite frankly. So what we like to say around here, the more about it, the less we know about it. But I think that's an important part of how we drive our business from an operational standpoint. We also see that there's opportunities for improvement, if you look at the revenue base in the fourth quarter and the third quarter. There are some Commercial programs that are essentially startups, such as like the 787 where we see opportunities to improve performance going forward, and we'll do that through efficiency challenges in Lean as we step forward. So I think that's the best analysis that I can give you, but those are the things that we have in front of us. In terms of the Engineering Services business, about a year ago right now, we brought in a new president into that business, and he has done an excellent job of streamlining the operations and refocusing the business around specific markets. And one of them, in particular, would be the nanosatellite market. And so, we're seeing some inroads there and some development programs that they're looking at to participate as well as be more focused on their capabilities with regards to the missile defense market. So we see some opportunities out there, and as the budget comes through. And of course, we'll have to wait and see on the elections and depending how fast that budget comes through, then we'll have a better understanding of how we can improve our capabilities in that area.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And you have a follow-up question from Troy Lahr.
componenttext: And you have a follow-up question from Troy Lahr.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: With the changes that you're talking about on Boeing, on the Apache, do you still expect that to be kind of about a $25 million a year business for you guys, or could that dip as more of the production stays in house at Boeing?
componenttext: With the changes that you're talking about on Boeing, on the Apache, do you still expect that to be kind of about a $25 million a year business for you guys, or could that dip as more of the production stays in house at Boeing?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that probably over time, we'll see a dip in that, Troy. I don't have the projections going forward. I think that what we're seeing obviously is that, first of all, the new rotor blades coming online and we're participating in that, as I said
componenttext: Yes, I think that probably over time, we'll see a dip in that, Troy. I don't have the projections going forward. I think that what we're seeing obviously is that, first of all, the new rotor blades coming online and we're participating in that, as I said so. That's an important program for us, and we're certainly keen on improving our position on that blade. But we will see, I think, a reduction in the existing blade over time. However, I think there are a number of customers out there on the foreign Military side which will stay with the existing blades, so we would see continued production on that. And then the tail rotors at this point in time have not been moved to composites, although I think that's in the wind. And we'll be supporting that going forward. So I would look at 2011 and '12 and probably see some slight reduction in build rates, as we go out. But at this time, I don't have those numbers. So we're actually in the final throes of working for them on rates right now.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And on the F-35, given some of the production delays that might be coming in, what we've already seen, do you think that there's enough F-35 revenue near term to offset some of the F-22 wind down?
componenttext: And on the F-35, given some of the production delays that might be coming in, what we've already seen, do you think that there's enough F-35 revenue near term to offset some of the F-22 wind down?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, for us I think that for sure, in that case. F-22 for us was that not a big program. So that's an easy part for us, but in terms of the JSF growth, I think we have some opportunities on that, that we are working on. And I think that from a near-term s
componenttext: Yes, for us I think that for sure, in that case. F-22 for us was that not a big program. So that's an easy part for us, but in terms of the JSF growth, I think we have some opportunities on that, that we are working on. And I think that from a near-term standpoint, I'd say that next year, if that's near term, I'm not sure that we have very high revenue on that program. But I think out in '12 and '13, I think we would have things pick up [indiscernible].

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then on Chinook, should we still think about that as -- I was thinking that, that was kind of a $15 million to $20 million a year program. Is that kind of in the range how we should still be thinking about that once you kind of ramp up and they see hi
componenttext: And then on Chinook, should we still think about that as -- I was thinking that, that was kind of a $15 million to $20 million a year program. Is that kind of in the range how we should still be thinking about that once you kind of ramp up and they see higher build rates, or no?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think so, Troy. We're anticipating that they're going to go to a slightly higher build rate going forward and that we've been hampered with their retooling. We actually retooled as well. So that we could help them get to higher rates on the blades.
componenttext: Yes, I think so, Troy. We're anticipating that they're going to go to a slightly higher build rate going forward and that we've been hampered with their retooling. We actually retooled as well. So that we could help them get to higher rates on the blades. So we're working through that. So I would anticipate that we would stay pretty close to that level in that range quite frankly.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then on C-17, I've always kind of viewed that as maybe a $40 million a year program. Does that drop to maybe $30 million or is it $35 million? How should we think about C-17 as you transition and as they lower production over the next, say, few years?
componenttext: And then on C-17, I've always kind of viewed that as maybe a $40 million a year program. Does that drop to maybe $30 million or is it $35 million? How should we think about C-17 as you transition and as they lower production over the next, say, few years?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would use that $30 million number. Quite frankly, we haven't settled on next year with Boeing and that's one of the negotiations that we're sitting through right now. And I think they have some issues that they have to work through with regard to t
componenttext: Yes, I would use that $30 million number. Quite frankly, we haven't settled on next year with Boeing and that's one of the negotiations that we're sitting through right now. And I think they have some issues that they have to work through with regard to the foreign Military sales and how that will impact it. We would look at that in that range. So about that drop, they're going to drop their production rate and they need to get to a steady state volume. They're running at about 15 shipsets right now. They'd be lower than that in 2011 and '12, and then we'll see how the foreign Military sales pick up going forward. So the $30 million range to a little less than that would be probably prudent.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And you have a follow-up question from Edward Marshall.
componenttext: And you have a follow-up question from Edward Marshall.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Two follow up questions for me. One, you talked about your collection services. You’ve also talked about improving inventory turns. And I was wondering if you can kind of discuss your goals both this year in kind of the longer-term trend, as what you ex
componenttext: Two follow up questions for me. One, you talked about your collection services. You’ve also talked about improving inventory turns. And I was wondering if you can kind of discuss your goals both this year in kind of the longer-term trend, as what you expect from both of those metrics?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ed, on the collection services, we're talking about accounts receivable collection. We have an internal metric that we're holding our organization accountable to. We try to get at least, and we look at the aging of our accounts receivable, 85% or more of
componenttext: Ed, on the collection services, we're talking about accounts receivable collection. We have an internal metric that we're holding our organization accountable to. We try to get at least, and we look at the aging of our accounts receivable, 85% or more of our receivables should either be current or current plus five days. We fortunately don't have any significant credit risk or credit default situations here, because the customer set is pretty financially secure. We go and look at the inventory. It's a little bit more complex because we have the composition of a variety of things, raw material and a lot of work in process by nature of our business and some finished goods. But in terms of turns, we look at somewhere between in excess of 4, 4.2x, 4.3x a year are our goals. And I think traditionally, we've run less than 4x and so part of our Lean Manufacturing Six Sigma and our focus on operation and working with our supply chain management group. We're all working very hard currently and then next year, despite all these schedule slides to enhance our returns, inventory turn.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then kind of in another direction and looking at -- you talked about acquisitions and multiples going higher. And I guess maybe looking at it from another angle, with multiples increasing, I mean, has it been kind of the Board's decision, maybe in you
componenttext: And then kind of in another direction and looking at -- you talked about acquisitions and multiples going higher. And I guess maybe looking at it from another angle, with multiples increasing, I mean, has it been kind of the Board's decision, maybe in your decision maybe to look at some of the non-core assets that you guys hold on your portfolio and maybe take a look at as multiples start to increase to kind of shed some of those non-core assets that may make sense? Is that kind of in the plans or has it been chopped around a little bit?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ed, I really can't comment on that. We have not gone down that path, so I just really don't have anything to add to that.
componenttext: Ed, I really can't comment on that. We have not gone down that path, so I just really don't have anything to add to that.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And you have a question from the line of Donald Porter from DGHM.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And you have a question from the line of Donald Porter from DGHM.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I had a question on the gross profit line. So part of that is the start up and development costs you talked about. My first question would be what are those programs and how does that sort of ramp down over the next five quarters? And you also talked abou
componenttext: I had a question on the gross profit line. So part of that is the start up and development costs you talked about. My first question would be what are those programs and how does that sort of ramp down over the next five quarters? And you also talked about a sales mix and lower volume, is that mostly just plant utilization issues or is it that some of the Military programs had better margin profiles with it?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Donald, on the multiple question, to start with, you asked about what kind of program it is, it's a multitude of programs, and it's both on the DAS side and our Technology side. Programs, say for RUAG, Bombardier, for what we call a racer program for the
componenttext: Donald, on the multiple question, to start with, you asked about what kind of program it is, it's a multitude of programs, and it's both on the DAS side and our Technology side. Programs, say for RUAG, Bombardier, for what we call a racer program for the F-16, for Raytheon with radar racks, there's a new Embraer program we announced, where we're in tooling stages. There's a couple of other customers, Shenyang Aircraft and others. So it's a multitude of those, and we've been asked the question before, well don't you always have those? We do but because of our focus on bringing on many new products in line to replace some of our sunset programs that we've commented about, our activity in the last couple of years has been greater, and our success in securing these programs has been greater than we have historically experienced. It's just at a greater rate. And so we're having to -- the way the accounting is to take those expenses as we ramp up these programs. So that's the impact, and it flows through our gross margins.

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is the R&D that you're spending for current programs that you're on or is there any R&D that's kind of speced [speculated]?
componenttext: Is the R&D that you're spending for current programs that you're on or is there any R&D that's kind of speced [speculated]?

headline: Ducommun Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, Donald, it's both. For example, the $800,000 we referenced is for programs that we're on. We do have some SG&A funding for development programs that we have in-house that are primarily on our technology side of our business. So one good example o
componenttext: I think, Donald, it's both. For example, the $800,000 we referenced is for programs that we're on. We do have some SG&A funding for development programs that we have in-house that are primarily on our technology side of our business. So one good example of an R&D program that came out as a win is we announced the capture of the engine starts, which are on the 737 program on our technology side this year. And that was a pure R&D program that we fund in-house, and we have programs like that, that we're working on currently, not necessarily switches but programs where we have a selected market, and we have identified the market, and we run through what we call a gate system to identify the R&D project. And then as we fund it, make sure that we solidify the marketing base before we proceed.
